												allright so i just finished the main game in 14 hours.what i think about it?let me first tell you that i have played and finished both Lords of Shadow 1 and Mirror of Fate, so this would be a great and useful review as i can compare this installment to the others.first the negative part:1 - the game is a tad shorter than Lords of Shadow 1 but it is longer that Mirror of Fate.2 - this game is easier than LoS 1 and MoF, but the last boss is such a pain..3 - not many puzzles, if any it will be a kid's puzzle.4 - story is weaker than LoS 1 but somewhat alot better than MoF.5 - the modern city is not very interesting.now the positive part:1 - graphics are very very good.2 - combat system is simplified and it is more useful than LoS 1, no longer you have combos that are useless in combat.3 - great story, still not as good as LoS 1. meaningful and relevant to the previous installments (LoS1 and MoF)4 - no crashings, no freezings and no technical issues what so ever.5 - amazing design of the Dracula's castle.6 - Great soundtrack and voice acting, still i think LoS 1 was a bit better.7 - rotateable camera angle in-game, which was somewhat painful in LoS 1.8 - so many secrets and playablitiy, just like LoS 1 and even better than that.9 - great boss fights and boss designs.10 - state of the art character design, level design, theme, atmosphere and off course bosses.frankly i dont get why on earth metacritic gave this game a 58 out of 100.if i would to give LoS 1 98/100, then i would give this game at least 85/100.i strongly recommend this game to you, defo worth the price and time.do not look at the metacritic score, it is an amazing game.i hope my review was useful to you guys, all the best and enjoy this astonshing game.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
Don't bother suffering the reviews by critics and gamers alike who have written this title off because of their views of the first game.Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is easily in the running for my 2014 game of the year. You've undoubtedly seen the low reviews from people who claimed poor graphics. These claims are groundless, and trampled by some of the screenshots you can uncover in the community hub for this game. The graphics are staggeringly good, and some areas have such incredible photorealism that you have to look twice just to make sure you're looking at a texture.The free-form camera works great. No longer can whiners throw a fit that they can't see elements of the battle, as you can now rotate 360 degrees in virtually every setting. It not only grants you a breathtaking view of the scenery; it allows you to tactically view your surroundings and analyze your best moves mid-combat.Platforming and quick-time events have been significantly altered to combat the same list of complainers who hated them in the first game. Platforming now directly shows you where to go, and no longer forces you into long-winded movements where every step is a new jump. You now streamline climb like spider-man over most surfaces, and the ones too far grant you a swift, and simple jump to the new object. Quick-time events have been cut in quarters. No more cinematic sequences where defending yourself during a movie becomes normal. They're limited to combat, and the rare gameplay-to-cinema segue.Controls are as easy as they were in the first game, with a few minor improvements. Button rotations have made combat noticeably smoother, and grant the player less hectic moments of desperate survival. Moves now have instant-cancellations, (another complaint from the first game) which allow the player the freedom to be as quick and reflexive as they want to be. If you die in combat-- you're just not up to snuff that round. No more blaming the devs.The music. What can I say? I've never been so excited to tear into a new game just to hear the musical composition behind it. Oscar Araujo does it again with a score so moving and epic that it pulls players back into its immersive world of magic and demons with a slew of trumpet blasts and harmony-driven pieces that are sure to win over even the most jaded action-gamers.There's never been a better time to jump into the world of Castlevania. I loved this game's predecessor, and I can still hold firmly to my nostalgic love of a classic Castlevania devoid of all the work MercurySteam has pumped into it in recent years.However, the "Lords of Shadow" series has brought life into a franchise that has desperately needed fresh-blood (forgive the pun).I strongly urge anyone to pick up this title, even if you're only looking for a new action-game. The battles are challenging; you'll be forced to reconsider how you take on countless enemies that you think you know well enough from the first game.The story is moving. Piecing together questions and answers from both the first game as well as Mirror of Fate, LoS 2 brings about a conclusion that is sure to yield an uproar from the masses for more of this tale.You are no longer a pure-hearted man. Gabriel has become a ruthless, violence-embracing monster who is indifferent to suffering and who will stop at nothing to obtain the freedom he desires. Many of his choices in the game will makes fans of the holy-hero cringe as he shows how his transformation into the Prince of Darkness has affected his moral judgment.This game is worth your money, and it's worth your time. If this game stretches even HALF the length of the first game, then it's going to be a ride you'll never forget.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 continues the story of Gabriel Belmont and his transformation into the dark lord; Dracula.Upon starting the game you'll immediately be plunged into an epic battle as Dracula's castle is besieged by the Brotherhood of Light. During this time you'll be trained in the art of combat, mastering Dracula's three weapons as well as evasive maneuvers. The weapons vary and each of them fill a specialized role. After the initial opening, you'll be unleashed into an open world with two dimensions to travel between, Dracula's Castle and a modern Gothic city built upon its ruins. The art direction and audio is phenomenal, featuring an amazing cast of voice actors; Robert Carlyle, Sir Patrick Stewart, and Jason Isaacs to name a few. The soundtrack is also really well done, fitting the mood of the game flawlessly. The environments are absolutely beautiful, allowing plenty of room for exploration while searching for the various upgrades, lore and abilities.The story, when combined with the previous two entries is engaging and helps propel you through the 15 hour game, although the ending is a bit abrupt as well as disappointing. Veterans of the Hack n' Slash genre will want to begin on the harder difficulty as it's a bit simple when compared to games like Devil May Cry and Bayonetta. Between, fighting, exploring, puzzle solving, and platforming there's a lot of fun to be had.While the stealth segments seem to be a major complaint for a lot of reviewers, they don’t detract from the overall game. I’ll admit that I was skeptical at first since stealth really has no business being in a Castlevania title, but they play out similarly to puzzles opposed to traditional stealth missions. They’re also few and far between.The menu system is highly polished and will document every type of creature you fight against. It also acts to manage your upgrades and abilities as you level. Plenty of Lore and backstory is provided along the way from diaries as well.While it'd be nice to have a triple A classic Symphony of the Night experience, LoS2 is great in its own way and playing as “The Dragon” with this new take on the legend is a blast. Don’t believe some of the critics, Lords of Shadow 2 is a must-play.For a longer and more detailed review, here’s a video my friend and I put together:

Posted: July 28, 2015
												It usually happens I find myself torn between a diamond in the rough and problematic technical or some other aspect of the game, but with Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 it's somewhat different. Time to see if I can put into somewhat coherent paragraph or two as to why that's the case.Let's start off by saying I was one of the people who enjoyed the original Lords of Shadow for what it was – not necessarily a creatively original masterpiece, but a game of astounding production values, competent writing and tight narrative punctuated by stellar voice work and lastly, and perhaps most importantly, it was a very meaty game which lead to some even saying it was too long for its own good. Fast forward to sequel and you can see it basically falters in each of these categories.Interestingly enough game seems to swing between two polar opposites with its visuals because on one hand you have this classic Castlevania look comprised of foreboding yet mystical gothic castle to romp through, as well as its assorted menagerie of beasties to but heads with and solve painfully few puzzles compared to the first game, but on the other you have to contend with extremely bland modern-day warehouses and science laboratories ad nauseam alongside some fairly uninspired enemies ranging from more classical demons and Satanists to, what really should've been more interesting that ended up, futuristic soldiers and cybernetic abominations roaming the streets. But honestly, it's this weird disjointed narrative that undoes the game the most in my mind because you can clearly tell there was meant to be more there instead of just going from A to B and meandering in-between retreading locations with nothing but brief radio contacts from time to time. And lastly – game is simply short compared to the first one and that probably ties into my previous point. Rumors abound regarding game's troubled development were apparently well founded. That's not to say game is bad because, as you will have most likely noticed despite my continued rambling on regarding its negatives, this is marked as a positive review overall. It's still Lords of Shadow and if you liked the original you'll probably like this considering you can overlook its weak story. Gameplay feels familiar and skippable QTEs are god-sent, both of which are points in game's favor for me, not to mention combat and item system was expanded and enemy variety despite their designs actually means you'll end up facing quite a bit of different behaviors. Story establishes the mood very early on as one of Dracula's somber and more resigned journey, one profoundly personal despite all other events that unfold over the course of the game. Had it been properly fleshed out and Robert Carlyle's more subdued performance given time to develop, occasional hamfisted melodrama notwithstanding, it would've been a much, much better final product. I also heard some nay saying about mandatory stealth sections in the game to which I say it's about time to drop hand-holding. Barring for one section involving leaves and crazed Satyr these were a welcome diversion for me and fitting considering MC's condition story-wise.One last caveat I feel should be posted is that playing the original game and Mirror of Fate is recommended before tackling the sequel.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												As a huge fan of Lords of Shadow 1, I sadly find myself rather disappointed in the sequel.  It seems like every change they made to the gameplay is for the worse.First let's talk about the much lamented stealth sections.  They truly and unequivocally suck.  They are relatively infrequent and certainly not insurmountable, but they simply are not entertaining, often annoying if not outright frustrating, and aren't even logically consistent with the rest of the game. One moment you're ripping the heart out of a monster the size of a building, the next you're hiding from two grunts with guns. I can not fathom the developer's reasoning behind their inclusion to the game.  Who played Lords of Shadow 1 and thought "You know what would make this game better? Insta-fail stealth segments!"Then there's the combat.  I found the combat in Lords of Shadow 1 quite satisfying even it could be simple at times.  It seems they wanted to up the challenge here, but they did so by making the enemies get staggered less, attack at a much faster rate, and having more attack you simultaneously. The problem with this is not that it makes the game too hard, but you need to guard or dodge so frequently that you rarely have time to execute anything more than the most basic attack combo.  Several of the more powerful attacks have such long windups or leave you open so long that they're nearly useless.  As a result, I'm finding the combat to be less varied and far more tedious than the first game.  Too much time is spent dodging and not rattling off impressive combos.There are also little bits of level design that make me wonder at what point the developers stopped asking whether it was fun in favor of just coming up with tasks for the player to do (much like the stealth sections).  For example there are several timed switches where you'll hit a switch to open a door, and as you get close to the door several enemies will appear.  Spend time fighting the enemies (and likely you'll have to) and you won't make the door in time.  So you walk back to the switch, hit it again and this time you can cross the area unmolested.  It's the most egregious form of repetition to pad playtime and makes no sense in a game that's sufficiently long regardless.  It's the kind of thing that makes you feel like the designer isn't respecting you as a player.If that wasn't enough, even the camera is disappointing.  Some reviewers whined about the fixed cameras of the first game, when the problem was just a few bad angles.  They switched to a controllable behind the back camera here, and while it's perfectly functional, the game has lost the epic vistas and panning shots of the first game that you only get with fixed (or more accurately: not player controlled) camera angles.  As a result, despite environment design that feels roughly on par with LoS1, the game has lost much of the grand feeling of it's predecessor.Now on the plus side, everything that doesn't have to do with the mechanics of the game are at least as good as the original.  The art design and aesthetics are great even if you don't get to appreciate them as much with the narrow camera.  The characters and cinematics are absurd, but in a way that feels fitting and not like it's trying too hard - though it can get close at times.Taken by itself, the game isn't awful, I still found it reasonably entertaining on the whole.  It's just that everything about how it plays feels worse than the original and it's especially disappointing to see so many mistakes made by the developer after the success they had with original.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: Castlevania Lords of Shadow 2 

			Views: 1,575		

			Josh possesses the dark lord himself in Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2. Here's what he thought. Review by: Josh Please like and subscribe for more reviews, gameplay, and discussions!		

	Mercury Steam's hack and slash take on Konami's long running vampire slaying franchise proved to be a bit divisive by rebooting the franchise's lore and staying away from the loot gathering of the massively successful side scrolling titles starting with Symphony of the Night. With Lords of Shadow 2, Mecury Steam is drawing their controversial take on the franchise to a close, putting players in the worn out boots of Dracula himself as he faces off against Satan and his army of minions. Attempting to inject a bit of metroidvania design and hopping back and forth between Dracula's castle and modern times, is this the compromise between the side scrolling titles and the foundation laid by Lords of Shadow? After a recap of the events of Lords of Shadow and Mirror of Fate, players are treated to an epic prologue that has Dracula defending his less than humble abode from a tremendous siege which culminates in an encounter with his son, Alucard.  The game then flashes forward a thousand years to find a very weak Dracula awakening in a cathedral in modern times greeted by Zobek. Zobek offers Dracula the chance to end his cursed existence in exchange for the death's of Satan's acolytes. In typical video game fashion, Dracula must regain his lost powers and battle a few inner demons in addition to Satan's minions. While the sections that have Dracula revisiting his castle provide some appreciative depth and introspection, the plot unfolding in modern times is rather underwhelming and even a bit silly. The game is at it's narrative peak when it recaptures the spirit of Gabirel's sober journey in the first game, reflecting on Dracula's numerous sins and the decimation of the Belmont family.  Perhaps the largest change to Lords of Shadow 2 comes in it's structure. Dracula moves between present day and his castle and, eventually, players can revisit areas previously explored. It makes the game more metroidvania-like thank it's predecessor but hoping back and forth between the two areas leaves the geography feeling fragmented and backtracking only becomes available much later in the game making this still feel somewhat like a linear level based affair. Combat remains largely intact from the previous games with light and dark magic now complimented by two additional weapons: the chaos claws and the void sword. These along with Dracula's shadow whip can be upgraded by purchasing various moves and utilizing them. It's a system that rewards using your entire move set and is an excellent addition to a genre where many rely on a couple effective all purpose combos. Relics have been added as consumable items that give Dracula the ability to restore his health, transform into a dragon for massive damage and gain extra experience. Tragically, the gameplay does take a major step back when it comes to the puzzles. Standing in for the first game's brain teasers are a gauntlet of stealth bits that have Dracula posessing enemies, cowering in the shadows and transforming into a rat in order to navigate small cracks and crevices. Most of these are easy and don't feel rewarding in addition to being at odds with playing as a powerful and feared vampire. A couple of the stealth sections can prove to be frustrating and one visit to a forum exposes one pre-boss fight stealth section as a stopping point for many. Boss fights are also completely unchallenging which is a shame since Lords of Shadow provided an excellent difficulty balance.  Fortunately, those who invest in the DLC will be treated to gameplay and puzzles that are more in line with the original Lords of Shadow making it an excellent piece of content for fans even though it's narrative additions are minimal. On the PC, Lords of Shadow 2's beautiful art direction is showcased by higher resolution textures and runs silky smooth at 60fps. Despite the fact that it doesn't offer the lastest graphical bells and whistles, this Direct X 9 title is more than pleasing to look and all of it's details can be appreciated since the fixed camera of the first game has been ditched. The Castle in particular is a stunning place to be and it becomes almost frustrating that the entire game doesn't take place there since the modern city seems a bit bland in comparison. Enemies can also be a bit bland and repetative but the bosses generally make up for this minor short fall. The soundtrack to Lords of Shadow 2 is also magnificent with beautiful somber orchestral compositions and delicate piano pieces. It adds a huge amount of ambiance to the game and is perhaps this year's best soundtrack. Lords of Shadow 2 is unequivocally not as good on the whole as it's predecessor though it shows a few major improvements that are easy to appreciate. It's a lengthy experience that offers superb combat, excellent visuals and a top notch soundtrack. For a Castlevania fan, it generally outweighs the lame stealth segments, repetitive enemies and underwhelming open world design. Even for it's biggest detractors, the Lords of Shadows games are proof that Castlevania can exist in three dimensions.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
 “What is a man, but a miserable pile of secrets.” Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is an action adventure game developed by the company MercurySteam, and the sequel to the 2010 game Castlevania: Lords of Shadow. Atmosphere & presentation: + Sinister depiction of the game world with dystopian elements.+ Each stage has its own atmosphere and iconic art style of the Castlevania series. + Obsessive attention to detail regarding level design. + Extensive concept art section with hundreds of pictures and sketches. o Solid sound effects. o Due to the console based origin a gamepad is recommended, in order to play the game.    Combat & gameplay: + Combat system is solid and reliable. + Good camera handling in combat and exploration sections.+ Exploration of the surroundings is rewarded with bonus powers and useful trinkets.o Variety of enemies is rather small and champions are too weak. - The stealth sections are an atrocity. An insult to the legendary abilities of the Lord of Shadows.  Characters & story: + Certain characters and story elements from Lords of Shadow and Lords of Shadow – Mirror of Fate are reintroduced and further developed. + The downloadable content “Revelations” introduces Alucard as a playable character and provides some surprising background information.o Compelling storytelling in the beginning, but it loses momentum towards the end.    - Inconsistent character development of Dracula.- The final boss is a cliché.  Summary: The second instalment of the Lords of Shadow series offers beautiful visuals and a solid combat system. However, the rest of the game does not reach the level of quality of its predecessor. Despite the strong start it loses its momentum in the middle of the game, and the solution of the conflict between Dracula and his antagonist can be considered a cliché. To add insult to injury, the forced stealth sections are an unnecessary and partially frustrating element.  Achievements: Estimated time for 100 % completion: +40 hoursSingleplayer achievements: 56Multiplayer achievements: none

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												So, I actually liked it a lot more than I expected. The overall impression of it everywhere seemed to be very negative (regardless of what you think about metacritic, 58/100 doesn't exactly inspire confidence), but I ended up liking it quite a bit.The combat is fun, even though it sometimes feel like the enemies have too many unblockacle moves, so instead of sync blocking you are dodging maybe more than I would prefer. Still, Dracula is nimble and there are enough new moves doled out every now and then to keep things interesting all the way through. Void and Chaos powers replace the light and dark magic from the first game, but more in name than function. You still get orbs from keeping your combat focus going, in order to fill out those magic meters, and one of them is more powerful and the other one is less, but heals with every hit landed. It's essentially the same system as the first LoS, but some very minor differences. Probably the biggest difference with combat is not even directly related to combat, but it's the free camera. And they handle it well, the combat camera is smart most of the time (unlike say, the camera in MGRR), and doesn't get in the way. All the finishers take too long though, I get it, you are Dracula, but suck that blood a little faster, thanks. But overall, good stuff.Presentation is probably the most uneven thing in the entire package. Environments and locations can be gorgeous, but they can also be ♥♥♥♥ing boring. Boring sewers and industrial plants, but also gorgeous gothic (or something) architecture and fantastic vistas. Dracula seems incredibly tiny in this world too. The grand scale of everything works well in the non-industrial setting, big majectic doors and windows etc, but in the industrial setting it just looks comical. Music is the same, Araujo does some good work with some tracks, but others are just a big meeh. I remember reading an interview from him where he says that he didn't really have a lot of freedom in the end, that he had tried to approach the music from other angles but was told that it needed to be more cinematic. Some of it works, some of it doesn't. The story is really really dumb, somewhat poorly written, but it does its job of pushing you towards your next objective.The worst part are the sections where they probably thought that they should add some variety in the gameplay design or something. Obviously the much talked stealth stuff is one part of that. They have absolutely no place in this game, they are just poor. But they are also really easy and short, so I'm not sure how the press was so badly hung up on them. Yes, they suck♥♥♥♥♥ but it takes like 2 minutes to go through. The elevator action section is dumb as well, again, not because it's hard or anything, but a timed switch to restore power in order to use an elevator is not fun. And I imagine the director had played Uncharted and told that we need something like that, heart pounding set pieces. The results are absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥ There's one section where the floor falls under you, push forward and push A for awesome. The entire train section is hot garbage, but especially the part where you dodge the roof lights or whatever. And then there's the QTE's, which you can turn off from the settings. If you played LoS, you'll probably remember that most boss fights had some easy quicktime event sequences in them, sometimes in the middle or in the end, and usually if you failed the boss would gain a little health back, rinse and repeat until you were quick and timely enough. That's still here, but if you turn them off, it will just play that whole section as if you were successful. And I very much recommend it. What does it tell you about this hot feature that they added an option to just disable them?The game is very linear, but it has a hint of that non-linearity with all the secrets you can find. That speaks to me in some primal level and I can just get lost in the world, just running around and looking behind every corner and such to find everything. It just speaks to me man. Of course I would recommend you do this only after you get all your powers back, can't get them all without all your powers. There's also some combat challenges, and I played through couple tiers of them... but didn't bother with the rest. It gets into a little more complicated stuff than I have patience for (you can only hit this dude while he is frozen, while simultaneously killing smaller dudes every 20 seconds etc etc). For me it takes the fun out of it.So overall, I'd say my experience with the game is positive. I paid ~20$ for it and I'd say it's worth at least that if not more.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Well if you're here then probably you have already looked up some "professional" reviews about this game. And most of them call it inferior to the series or just simply say it's mediocre. This game made me to stop listening to these reviewers. I didn't really want to buy it, but I fell in love so hard with the story they presented in LoS1 and MoF I needed to know the conclusion and I felt like I wouldn't be satisfied if I just simply watched it on YouTube. So here I am amazed by this fantastic game...+CombatIf you are coming from LoS1 (if not then please play it before this one) you already know the basics. They basically tightened it up, made it much more responsive and fluid then it was. There are new moves and combos, too. And this time we get a much more "user-friendly" skill page then in LoS1.+Story and narrativeThese were the second biggest positives I encountered in this game (the 1st one is ofc the combat). Of course there are plot twists, and most of them hit hard (you know it's good when your jaw drops). There are many interesting characters; there will be some who you'll hate and many who you'll love. It made me care about a side-character in ~20 mins and when it turned out he may die I felt really bad. But the ultimate peak for me was the Toymaker. It is that kind of rare time in gaming when a good story and a well-imagined narrative meets. I won't spoil it for you, you have to experience it by yourself. And most importantly it got rid of that bad narrative element that they used in the 1st game, which made up every little thing so dramatic that it felt like it just changed the whole world, but in reality it had no impact on anything.+CameraThankfully they got rid of the fixed camera presented in the first game. Don't get me wrong, fixed camera can work pretty well (like the old Resident Evils), but a high-speed action came certainly doesn't need it. Surprisingly it's also dynamic. So like when you're just walking, it comes quite close to you (kind of like RE4). But during combat it goes much further so you can see better.+PlatformingJust like the combat, they kept it and made it better. Thanks to the accurate controls it's much more fluid and if you failed a lot of times during platforming in LoS1 (like me) than fear no more, it's much better. A little bat swarm will always indicate where you can jump to and during climbing you can (optionally) highlight where you can climb to.+SoundtrackI know it's subjective, but it's still amazing. It's not that kind of music that you will download and listen to regularly. It just fits so well the game, that it greatly boosts its already good atmosphere. It's epic and beautiful at the same time. And when it needs to be, then it's emotional.+BossesThey are pretty diverse and just enough challanging.+DesignThe graphics are good, but the design is the thing that's important. When you're in the castle dimension it's simply breathtaking. Every little detail in every little painting and statue and thing in the castle...Everything feels just in place, that I risk that even in 8-bit it would still look beautiful. Now about the modern dimension...For a city design it looks good, but I couldn't wait to get back into the castle from the modern world.And the list could go on and on (good portray of Dracula, references, etc.), but let's talk about some not that good aspects of the game.+/-Stealth segmentsNow this is the most criticized part...I don't hate them but neither love them. It's all about if you mind being taken away from the fast-paced gameplay and use your brain and patience a little bit. But the biggest issue with these is the fact that mostly there's only one way to do them! But people hate it like it's all over the place but you have to be stealthy like 5 times in this game...But I loved the parts when I could be a rat, it still really gave me the feels of being smarter and more powerful then my enemies.-No detailed mapYou get 2 kinds of map in this game: one that shows the districts and one that shows your surrindings.-Rare bugsI encountered two kind of biggie bugs during my playthrough and I looked up if anyone else has encountered them and I didn't find anyone, so they must be really rare.In conclusion: As a fan of Hack 'n' slash games and the first two LoS games I have to say that this is a must have. The game is very well optimized, so no worries about that. It has it's bad moments, but they're still mediocre at worst. I love this even more than the 1st one actually. The story and drama feels kind of weak if you don't really care about it, but once you start to think about what just happened you'll be amazed. Don't listen to the critics (probably Konami just didn't pay for good reviews), this game deserves much more than that (8/10 minimum).P.S.: I feel like it's needless to say about this kind of games, but a controller is strongly recommended (I played with a Steam Controller and it was very comfortable and precise).

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												(DISCLAIMER: Objectively, as a game, Castlevania LoS 2 is a good, overall,  game that has some flaws. However, as a follow up to Castlevania LoS, it is terribly disappointing. My recommendation is based on the game itself, not my disappointment as  a sequel to the original.)	Let's start with the GOOD. The combat has been refined in a very nice way and thusly feels a bit more responsive. As in the last game, with the points/experience that you receive from defeating enemies, you can use that to buy additional moves for your weapons, but this time, you have the addition of the chaos claws and void sword AND they have their own moveset on top of the same function as shadow and light magic respectively. Thusly, giving you many combo possibilities. Dodging is smooth, although I would have preferred a roll like the original, or the turning into smoke like Laura in the original game as well. I'm glad for the addition of the free rotating camera that was lacking in the first game.	Platforming has also been improved and is much smoother than before.	The graphics, very,very nice. However, it seems a bit of a waste since the most of the environments are dank, dark and very similar; unlike the original game where there was a lush forests, autumn ruins, icy castles, dark dungeons, crazy grand canyonesque platforming. Just wasted potential overall, but a great graphics engine nonetheless.	Now for the BAD: STEALTH, man oh man, this game never needed stealth to begin with so I don't know why it's even here. Not that I mind stealth, it's just done very, very poorly in this game. The stealth sections were very tedious and boring. It was repetitive and not necessary to the game.	Speaking of not necessary, the section where you have to hide from Pan's brother so you don't get one-shotted....ridiculous! You're freaking Dracula, the prince of freaking darkness. Satan is even scared of you in the game, yet, you have to hide from this guy? Again, since this was a stealth portion, it was terrible and necessary.	The modern setting, I'll admit that I was excited to check out a modern setting in LoS, but honestly, it felt so out of place, especially the robots and commandos in exo suits. The sections you get to go back to the castle felt much more appropriate and epic. 	The story, the story this time around, lacked a sense of urgency and purpose. This is probably partly due to that you're now Dracula and you don't care weather thousands of people live or die. I through most of the game, it felt as if I was just trudging along just getting through the game, instead of feeling like I'm making real progress. The story lacked any real revelations, twists or turns, like the original had. It was very one track and lacked anything with real substance. There is no internal struggle like in the first game, any real tragedy with character investment, the story felt like it had a beginning and an end but missing pieces in the middle, not necessarily plot holes, but more so they needed to add elements to make it really interesting.Overall, the game is ok with some flaws. I did have fun with the combat, especially in the intro of the game, but after that, it felt like it was all downhill from there; lack luster story, repetitive environments, terribly implemented stealth. Sadly,  Castlevania LoS 2 just couldn’t meet the standards set by the first. As a huge fan of this series, I'm hugely disappointed. As a gamer, it's a “not bad” game.7/10

Posted: March 2, 2014
												I'm a diehard Castlevania fan. I was also one of the few who defended Lords of Shadow 1 when it really alienated the Castlevania name. I enjoyed the first game a lot, and I was really excited with the idea of a second game. Unfortunately, I can't recommend this title. It does have great ideas, and I love NWO references (like a reptillian creature, and that a pharmaceutical company is in leagues with Satan). In any case, I'd like to think that this is the Simon's Quest for the Lords of Shadow series. The gameplay is okay, but it has no idea what it wants to be. It wants to be a hack/slash adventure, yet it wants to be a platformer, and yet there are stealth sections which ultimately hurt the game. As a customer, I wanted the Castlevania that built on Lords of Shadow 1, not whatever this is currently. The game falls VERY flat in the end. I was not satisfied with the story, despite the massively epic build up from E3. With that said, I don't recommend the game at full retail value. Maybe if it drops down to 30 or 20, I would say go ahead. As it stands, it truly is one of the weakest. Pros: Robert Carlyle as Dracula, other voices were great too. Decent story Cons: Doesn't know what it wants to be, multi-vision projectToo few enemies Doesn't offer the excitement that LoS1 providedFlat endingFelt rushed

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												8.5/10Overview: Third Person Action Adventure The Good+ The setting is a mixture of a modern city in ruins and Draculas old castle. Both settings provide a nice contrast with each other and are fun to explore+ The first major difference from the original is the ability to control the camera as opposed to having a fixed camera in the first game. + The second major change is all the levels are interconnected with each other. This provides for a much more immersive and seamless experience with gameplay. + Combat is more refined than the original and just as fun. You have light magic that does less damage but heals you whenever you damage an enemy and chaos magic that does significantly more damage but is slower and has less range. Effectively dodging and switching between your magic meters is fun and engaging. If you played the first game, the combat should offer little surprise to you. One key difference is by using attacks over and over again you can increase your mastery of a certain weapons making them stronger. + Boss battles have always been a highlight for this series and this game is no exception. Bosses are unique, well designed and will require you to use all your techniques in battle to defeat them. + the game has plenty of collectables scattered throughout the world+ The game features 16 optional challenges to further extend your game time. Each challenge has a series of objectives that has to be completed in order to complete the challenge. + option to disable quicktime events The AverageThe story is not awful but it didn't really do much either. It doesn't help that most of the dialogue spoken by the villains is bad. This game has some REALLY annoying enemies that will test your patienceThe BadFor some odd reason the developers decided to include stealth sections in the game. I like stealth games and I like it when developers try to mix up the gameplay but this was just a bad effort. The stealth sections feel very out of place and are not always clear in what you have to do making for some really frustrating trial and error. It also feels very odd that you play a badass destroying most enemies in your path only to reach a section in the level where you have to avoid enemies. ConclusionThis game fixed two of my biggest gripes from the first game. The fact that the levels are interconnected and the ability to actually control the camera make for a much better gameplay experience despite the awful stealth sections. I was a bit baffled that reviewers panned this game pretty badly as I think this game improves the first game in many ways. If you enjoyed the first game then there is no reason why you shouldn't love this game as well, unless of course the modern day setting doesn't appeal to you.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Some spoilers ahead:Finishing Lords of Shadow 2 left me with a bitter aftertaste.From the very beginning of the game, you will be forced into stealth missions, evading generic vat-grown monstrosities in high-tech labs. The game's combat system, one of it's greatest strengths, is mercilessly defenestrated here, and as you find yourself sneaking behind an invulnerable guard for the fifth time, you start to wonder at what point it was that you stopped having fun.But then you cross over into a castle area, and the familiar atmosphere coupled with the excellent swordplay (whipplay?) makes the game seem like a worthy sequel once again. The combat is fast and fluid, with the accelerated orb gain (compared to the first game) playing a great part in that. The platforming is much more forgiving, although the inclusion of (even more) platform highlighting was really not needed.As soon as the game manages to realize you're having fun, however, you encounter the acolytes of Satan. These unfortunate excuses for characters that seem to have been created by pulling edgy tropes from a hat will casually wipe the floor with you - that is, until you use a clever trick to defeat them. Unfortunately, this is a sign of things to come, as well as one of my biggest issues with the game. You are Dracula, the Prince of Darkness. You've ruled this Earth from the shadows for centures, while Satan cowered from you ever since his last defeat. Well, it sure doesn't feel like it, since you'll spend most of your time in LoS2 running away from large fights and powerful enemies. Gabriel Belmont feels no more powerful than he was in the first game - weaker, in fact, due to the fact that you start the game with no skills or abilities.Still, I went on with the game, hoping that the story would make it worthwhile. I cleaved my way through research facilities and desolated city streets, castle ramparts and dungeons. The narration was served to me in droplets, as if the whole story was an afterthought - an idea that I haven't quite managed to fully dismiss. Eventually, after maybe 12 hours of gameplay, the story started going somewhere. A major revelation was shown, and it had me genuinely interested.Then it abruptly ended. There was a boss dull boss fight, set on an epic stage only to serve as a distraction from its lazy design (I'll use this opportunity to coin the term "forced epic"). It was over, Dracula said a cheesy one-liner and the credits rolled. That was it. The cluttered mess that the story had become turned into a Gordian knot not even Dracula's Void sword could sever, and it seemed like the developers didn't even bother trying. No shocking twists after the credits, not this time, only a lingering feeling of disappointment. There's a certain sense of irony that the only distinct feeling this game managed to evoke in me, that of sadness, was not over Gabriel's fate, but rather over the missed potential that this game had once held.Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is a game as empty as its protagonist's soul. Avoid it, especially if you were a fan of the original.

Posted: September 8, 2015
												As a Castlevania fan (and I mean all of them), I recommend this game sincerely to fans of the series, gothic atmospheres, vampire and other mythical lore and fast-paced action games.I've played this game before on a different system, but I needed it again for the PC. That's how much I love it.The negatives about this game often are about the stealth parts and the modern day sequences. I also find those less appealing, but it makes me appreciate the castle sequences even better. The environments are beautiful and open for exploration. Once you've got the majority of your abilities the exploration becomes the best part of the game, for me at least. Some people say the story is so so, but I love the amount of effort they put in the lore. A lot of the story is hidden in the pages of the bestiary and abilities. Accompanied by amazing artwork and good music (though, earlier Castlevania's had better music), it makes it a atmospheric experience of storytelling. My opinion might be influenced by my love for the series, but I can still recommend this game just for the amazing leveldesign, atmosphere, awesome bossbattles and rich mythological lore.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												This game is an underrated gem. Not sure where the bad reviews are coming from. Most of the game takes place in an interconnected castle that will remind players of the metroidvania games. The combat is simple and satisfying and rewards variety and good timing. The boss battles are epic, and each one is unique and requires the player to learn a specific strategy. Sound design, music, graphics and presentation are all fantastic. Stealth sections provide a change of pace and though they are not as fun as the exploration and combat portions of the gameplay, they are few and far between.  Happy I decided to pick this up despite the abysmal reviews.... If you are fan of the first Lords of Shadow then you absolutely must play this game. If you haven't played the Lords of Shadow series, definitely pick up the first as it is also a classic IMO. The series gets a lot of hate from Castlevania fanboys, and whilst it is definitely true that it deviates from many of the series tropes, I don't consider it a bad thing at all.  A lot of care and devotion was poured into this series and it's a shame it has not gotten the positive reception that it deserves. Bottom line is if you are a fan of 3d action/adventure games you need to play this game.

Posted: January 10, 2015
												Eu sunt Dracul!After I was highly disapointed by the console port of Lords of Shadows 1 I must say I really like this game. It got a 58 Metacritics score, but since I'm a sucker for Metroidvania and God of War-like games I gave it a try.And boy am I glad I gave it a chance. I have to admit the game needs some time to get you. The first two hours are kind of lame (The fight against the angelic robot and the boring sneaking part). But after the tutorial and the first visit to the science facility the game unfolds its beauty. The artdesign is fabulous, overall graphics, shadows and lightning are fantastic. Even more important, the controls are smooth even for a non gamepad-player like me. Combat is challenging throughout the game. After unlocking more and more combat options the normal fights as well as the boss fights are immensely fun to play (The whole toymaker part is a lesson in gamedesign for other devs). You can adjust the camera by mouse so there are no more fixed angles and even jumping is fun again. No more QTE, thank you for that dear devs. The game is kind of an open world game, you can constantly roam your castle and the modern world and unlock secret after secret while advancing through the game. The speakers and the music are nearly over the top. The speakers are so good and the music fits so fantasticly well it's scary.And last but not least this game is dark, no emo vampire he's the kind of vampire I want to watch in movies or play as in a game.My rating would be a 86 (edited), it's one of the best games of this kind I ever played.So give it a try and don't let yourself get fooled by the not so brilliant beginning.

Posted: September 21, 2014
												  The game's not quite bad, but not near as good as the first one. Everything different from the first episode is for the worse. First of it, the cyberpunk setting feels cheesy, and the designs cheap.  The very structure of the game, wich is now a real metroid-vania, will just have you spend hours in long, frustrating trips across the area. No real maps, not enough shortcuts, and no real way to help you create a mental map of the whole place (not like dark souls for example). Plus you'll have to endure excruciatingly slow scenes designed to hide the loading away from your righteous wrath. Tons of them. It's what I remember the most about the whole game experience.  The combat is still good, yet not as good as before. The new beautiful FX will quite often hide important informations on enemies, resulting in a punch in your face, and the sad disappearance of your focus bar. And the combat sessions have been fragmented in shorter fights, wich doesn't allow you to make this focus bar really useful. What were they thinking ?  Every new feature, like stealth, are absurdly bad.   All in all, it's not a bad game, it's still beautifully crafted, challenging and the core fighting gameplay is still good. But everything else seems to have been designed by a drunk guy. That's really sad. And you'll have to endure hours of this♥♥♥♥♥♥between every neat fight or exploration of cool (or less cool) places. That's too bad, really.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Portals? Ratula? Demons with guns? Explosions? Blood vomits? Blood and gore?  Space Marines? Belmonts? Kicking Tldr: Scroll DownThis game was a fun ride and not as bad as other reviews made it out to be, There was some really strong points and weak points to the game but it was not a flop compared to the other games out there. Please do think for yourself, watch some videos and some gameplay and play for yourself Heres my review on why this was a fun game to play.  I enjoyed all 15 hours of it and thats not finding Everything.The Story was not suspenseful as LOS this time around, It started off flaring and action packed and for some reason just ended in a sorta fizz. You'll start as Gabriel in his castle fighting against the army of brotherhood, After so you'll be treated with some story telling from the Ds version of the game and past forward into the future. You are Gabriel Belmont thousands of years laters in the future you'll be fighting Satans army while experiencing the past and the future in the game at the time. Play the game to find out more. The story was really not the game strong point this time around.The music of course was amazing as usual and really brings out the game, alot of the symphony and the epic music world music makes you feel really pumped playing it, Even if you're walking through an empty hallway. The voice acting is great along with returning Patrick Stewart. Has a very epic sensation to it and goes really well with the game.Gameplay  The fighting and combat is fast and action packed, fighting enemies is sort of like a puzzle and requires strategy and thinking You cannot go in mashing, I tried and ended up looking like a fool and getting ripped by the mobs. You'll have to think the game revolves around your shadow whip, Vorpal blade which heals when you hit enemy and your Chaos gaunlet  which breaks defense when you use it against certain enemies along with dodging and guarding mechanic.The game itself has alot more jumping puzzles and Puzzles itself. This time along with some stealth which is medicore. There is alot more platforming. The real treat is that also the world is a bit more explorable this time around, with many sections of the future + past at the same time.Used an xbox controller for this game, tried the keyboard and didn't work too well for me, also note the port had Xbox showing buttons popped up which needs to be fixed for players. This time the camera is also no longer in a fixed position, it is  now controlled by the player though could be better if you could actually hit a button to face your enemy. The graphic itself has HD textures given to you, which is great but doesn't change the fact that it was  A PORT. though still a great game and looks quite decent. The level design looks phenominal, the detail put into it if you look carefully and how the buttons and switches in the game works the way they do, The future might look a little bleak and grim maybe a  bit different than what many expects but did look ok.TLDR +Good music and voice acting+Great environments design+Fast action paced combat that requires players to think before mashing+Lots of puzzles and platforming+Boss fights were really fun, and bosses look cool very unique.+ Not a linear game this time around, has explorable areas that can be revisted with warp points.-Story was mediocre-The stealth sections of the game was mediocre also can be very fustrating at certain points for some.- Could had offered more than just looking for items in the  world, sidequest could had been great.-No multiplayer, no real replay value of any sort except finding the stuff you haven't found or playing harder difficulty.-Unescessary qtes on buttons.- Game was way too easy even on hardest difficulty you could choose in the beginning.

number of helpful: 25 of 37 people (68%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Recommended? Maybe.....After giving Castlevania Lords of Shadow 1 a glowing review, it really pains me to give this a thumbs down.  I was really hopeful that this sequel would follow in its footsteps as a worthy successor. Unfortunately this game is marred by a clunky camera system, weird game mechanics that don't always work right and an irritating save/checkpoint system that punishes you heavily for failure by making you repeat the same sequences and boss fights over and over again until you get them exactly right. By contrast, the first game's checkpoint system was much better in saving your progress (even during boss fight stages) and all the artifacts and items you picked up you kept after you got them. If you died at a particular place, you would just restart at that place with all of your previous progress saved. Not here, you're forced to proceed a great deal further in most instances in order for everything to be saved. Make a mistake and you're going all the way back to the beginning of the sequence or fight. It's just frustrating and not fun.The story is just OK. Nothing that really draws you in and connects you to its ficitional world like the first one. The levels take place in a bizarre alternating transition between the past and present which makes the game feel like a cross between its gothic horror roots and the futuristic setting of Doom 3. In the modern levels Dracula will be operating elevators, powering modern machinery and battling mechanized bad guys that are equipped machine guns, grenade launchers and electronic counter measures, it just feels out of place. The main characters aren't as memorable nor do they stir up the same level of emotion as Lords of Shadow 1.It's also much harder to go back to previous levels and pick up many of the artifacts you'll need to make your character strong enough to face the tougher enemies in the late game after you unlock the special powers required to get to them. There isn't an individual level selection system like the first game. Instead you have to select a previous location and then find a special room which allows you to teleport to an area of the that location where you think you might have left something behind. It takes way more time to do and just means more repetition of the same convoluted areas over and over.I'd say it's worth picking up only on sale and only if you're a fan of the first one (having completed it) and Mirror of Fate and have an interest in the story. That's alot of ands. At the time of this writing, I haven't finished it and I intend to see it through but after 15 or so hours I'm getting ready for it to be done.Overall 5/10

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												I think I need to add this to the "games that most people hated which I actually enjoyed" list. Admittedly, I'm biased because I really dig Castlevania, enjoyed the first Lords of Shadow and Mirror of Fate, and am a sucker for the idea of playing as Dracula himself. But even at its most frustrating moments, Lords of Shadow 2 isn't nearly as bad as Edge Magazine (which gave it a 4/10) or any of the other mainstream reviews would have you believe. Bloodsucking awesome stuff:+ I feel like combat's speedier and more responsive than it was in the first Lords of Shadow, and there's less reliance on quicktime events. This might have to do with the fact that I'm just more experienced with the combat system after playing through the first game and Mirror of Fate, but I had a lot of fun beating up some of the bosses, which leads me to the next point...+ The boss battles (with the exception of the finale) are grand as hell! You've got some classic mainstays in there, like Death and Medusa, whose inclusion instantly make this game seem "more Castlevania" than its prequel.+ On that note, the first Lords of Shadow got criticism from many people who felt it was Castlevania in name only (though in a surprising twist, I've noticed that the first game is now retroactively considered great in the wake of the poor reception the second got). This isn't the case here - from the getgo, when you start out as Dracula in your castle sipping a glass of blood, Symphony of the Night references start popping up everywhere. These plus the haunted atmosphere and the inclusion of Alucard just make the game *FEEL* more like a proper entry in the series. + Lords of Shadow 2 is beautifully presented, and like its predecessor, has some of my favorite menus ever in a video game. (I'm just a sucker for any menu that resembles an old torn book and has little hand-drawn animations showing your available attacks.) The music feels like it's from the long-lost Castlevania movie that got stuck in development hell, and the environments are amazing...at least for the flashback sections of the game. Not so bloodsuckingly awesome+ The game has two worlds, Zelda-style - a flashback castle that sort of exists in Dracula's mind (or in another dimension, it's never really explained) and a modern setting. And while the castle is gorgeous, the modern levels are laboratories, deserted hospitals and dirty streets that resemble Gotham City in the Arkham games at their best but are just forgettable at their worst. + With the strange duo world thing comes the plot, which I actually enjoyed for the majority of the game, even though there's one big twist near the end that is really the most comic book thing ever, and I don't mean that in a good way. But the ending is very weak. Let's just say that the final boss battle doesn't exactly hit the heights of previous fights, let alone the epic clash of Gabriel Belmont versus Satan from the first game, and even though there's a big redemption story that builds up for Dracula over the course of 30-some hours, the whole thing concludes like a wet fart in the night. Also...Victor Belmont, what a waste.+ Unlike Lords of Shadow 1, this sequel's a Metroidvania. This is good in theory, but on the negative side, enemies are still damage sinks, which interrupts the joy of exploration, and the shackles of the level-based structure of the first game are still there. Many times you can only traverse areas in a VERY SPECIFIC WAY that the game wants you to take - ie, even though Drac gets a double jump, he can't jump over this crappy little ledge to get the collectible on the other side even though you can CLEARLY see he should be able to reach it. No, you have to take the long route around and use your mist form to pass through a gate (and the mist form can only be used in a few key places too) because the game's been programmed that way. Mirror of Fate had this issue as well, but it wasn't as noticeable because that game was 2.5D. In a 3D environment, it's very obvious.+ Tying into this element of restrictiveness, the stealth sections that got slammed by every reviewer ARE quite annoying. If you dunno what these are - there are a few enemies, like some huge armor-plated guards and Pan's brother, who can kill Drac in two shots, even though in every cutscene the Prince of Darkness easily demolishes much bigger foes. The only reason Drac is vulnerable to these guys is because the designers needed an excuse to make the players complete so-so puzzles where you need to change to rat form or cling to walls to sneak by them. It's kind of a ham-fisted way to switch up gameplay, but luckily it's only about 5% of the game. Lords of Shadow 2 got massacred upon release, but I'm glad to see it's at least getting positive reviews on Steam two years later. I still liked it enough to go out of my way to find every collectible, which is rare for me. It's biggest flaw is that it has the restrictive design of a PS2 game, but was released in 2014, a year which also saw innovative titles like Shadow of Mordor which introduced fresh gameplay mechanics. (OK, I agree that Mordor was overrated - but it did offer a solid open world, and the Nemesis system WAS great.) Reviewers were expecting more when this came out, frankly, and rated the game as such. As it stands, it's still not a horrible way for the Castlevania franchise to end, and worth a look for more open-minded fans who aren't opposed to Castlevania games not made by Koji Igarashi. If you're interested, I wrote some longer thoughts on this game and the negative reception it got here: http://pixelgrotto.tumblr.com/post/150812695901/musings-goodnight-sweet-prince-eurogamer

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												Lords of Shadow 2 proves to be much like its predecessor. It's very much a "bigger, better, more" sequel. An open world connected by shortcuts, more weapons and spells to use, and the addition of new relics and items to toss about. Unfortunately, the story and lore about about as mishmosh and nonsensical as the first games if you give them even a second thought, so if you're looking for a compelling addition to the Castlevania chronicles, like the first game, you're going to be sorely mistaken.For being "the epic conclusion" to the Lords of Shadow saga, very little is actually concluded.Luckily, the combat is smoother, faster, more fluid, as are all the platforming aspects. While the trappings and aesthetics are lacking, underneath beats the heart of a solid, fun action game. Like the first game, I feel like if it had been called anything buta Castlevania game, the story would get a pass. The game itself though, is fun enough to be a recommendation for anyone who enjoys action games.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												This game is a mixed bag, and by no means outright terrible. There are however many flaws which strike me.Gameplay in and of itself, with the exception of the glaring annoyance of nonsensical stealth sections is decent enough, and all of the provided mechanics are put to work equally in the combat and in exploring the world itself. This works well enough though it doesn't appear to me to be anything revolutionary or exciting.  Stealth sections very much break the established flow, despite being short and ridiculously easy to get past they are at odds with the rest of the game, disabling your ability to perform any attacks short of stunning opponents and trying to escape. It doesn't make sense when the game plays up the fact you're a character with ridiculous combat ability, and you're regularly destroying enemies twice the size or so of the guards in the stealth section which utterly wreck you in seconds if you get caught. The mechanics the stealth sections use, possesion and transforming into a swarm of rats don't seem to be used to their utmost. Particularly possession, why not allow the player to actually do something with the apparently invincible guard they're controlling aside from use an eye scanner to open a door? As for turning into a group of rats, when the rat you're controlling dies - you possess the next rat in your entourage.  If all the rats die, you die.  This is used to -some- effect in the first stealth section where you have to navigate tunnels and avoid hazards, keeping your other rats alive. As well as again later on very briefly.  I don't particularly like this kind of gameplay, but the idea was good and for the effort spent in making it functional it seems very underused. The game world itself is nice looking and well designed in most respects but it's fairly linear, it does allow backtracking throughout though mainly for the purposes of revisiting past areas with new abilities to grab missed collectables, which is more in tow with the series prior, although likely not quite as interesting. If you like collecting lots of crap (increases to various gauges, unlockable challenges, item limit upgrades, artwork) and trying to 100% games, that's a pro and you might enjoy it. The upgrade system for the main set of combat abilities is good, and offers some interesting options.  Enemies are fairly varied, interesting and the bosses are pretty fun. Though the hardest difficulty is locked until you've beaten the game. One flaw is that enemies and bosses (and anyone in combat with you) will quote the same 3-6 lines of dialogue over and over as you fight them to the point of it becoming annoying.  I like about as many of the character and enemy designs as I find unappealing, even then knowing that the ones I do like aren't very memorable and don't actually get that much focus.Story is a big no sale for me, which is a shame because signifigant portions of it could be considered competent and plenty of time has clearly been spent on it. The main setting is uninteresting and feels generic as a plot point (despite the actual work which went into designing it.) Most of the characters motivations seem either generic, pointless, obvious or some combination of all three. The best segments are generally spent in the castle sequences, but the whole premise behind that is fundamentally pretty simple and renders itself unnecessary on the whole. There's a lot of background information in the journal which updates with entries on your abilities when you get them, and each enemy type/character when you kill/meet them respectively. This is nice if you like these kind of details.PC controls work well enough, although onscreen prompts still use controller buttons which is lazy. There is a contextual control reference dropdown bound to F1 which shows what action, what button it's mapped too and what key represents that button, which is at least something. Being provided with a HD texture pack and features like being able to disable QTE's is great. Even if I found this game average I feel at least somewhat vindicated in supporting it for providing things like this. If you're sensible, You'll wait to get this until it's on sale or gets a price drop. It's entertaining, stable and more or less what it presents itself as, but no grand masterpiece unless you're a person who'd particularly enjoy the areas where the game excels and be capable of enjoying it despite its problems.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												I got this for 10 bucks on the Humble Bundle store after having a lot of interest in it beforehand. Having played the original Castlevania, SOTN, Aria of Sorrow, and a portion of LOSMOF HD, I can say this game stands up to the general dark vibes. I was a bit hesitant of a 3D Castlevania game, but it worked quite well. Once I got used to the keyboard controls and whatnot, the game was not difficult at all, with the exception of a few very frustrating puzzles and a couple bosses.It plays a lot like the older Devil May Cry games, including the 4th game in the series, even some of the camera zooms on doors and other things were very reminiscent of those games, which I loved. The game promotes using different attack patterns, by using a "mastery" system for each skill you buy with Souls. This system gives you points in whichever skill you are using, and when maxed out, can be used to upgrade the weapon itself. I found myself using more varied combos and different attack patterns, instead of just cheesing the bosses with Guillotine. I digged how Dracula / Gabriel is portrayed, and the other characters are well done as well. Though, be advised that the controls are not shown as keyboard keys, and will instead be like, "push A" and so on, corresponding to an Xbox 360 controller. This got extremely frustrating in the beginning before I knew what the buttons translated to on the PC, but once I got used to it, everything worked well. Is this game worth the $40 dollars? I am not sure really, it depends how much you want a game like this. I personally feel that the game is very good, and was well developed, even if by a different company than the original games

												Game time breakdown...50% engaging combat, fun bosses, though last third of game increases difficulty in unfun ways (too many unblockable attacks at once, getting locked in continuous hitstun, etc)25% mildly enjoyable linear command-prompt platforming with very minor short branches to "explore"15% constricted stealth filler sequences ranging from boring to infuriating10% (QTE) cutscenesThe game is padded out to 15-20 hours. With the stealth stripped out and the more frustrating combat encounters trimmed away there's probably an amazing 8 hour game trapped in there somewhere. Heh, instead of a big DLC-bundled-GOTY-Edition-Re-Release a year from now I would love to see a LoS2 GOTY Edition that's *shorter* and *leaner* than the original release and better for it.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												The only other Castlevania game I played to completion prior to this one was C:SotN, widely regarded as the best Castlevania in the series. Without knowing until after I finished this Lords of Shadow series follows an alternate timeline from the others in that series, and without playing Lords of Shadow 1, I enjoyed it a lot. The game catches you up to the story of Lords of Shadow well, and I enjoyed the plot and flow of the game.Gameplay (fighting) is pretty hack-slash with comboing using the whip, or sword/chaos claws but is quite simple. I've read people compare it to God of War, but having not played that series I wouldn't know. I wasn't expecting anything amazing in combat but I did find it fun to play despite not a huge variation in enemies. At least most of the enemies weren't annoying, but I did dread getting into fights. There was a fair bit of platforming, some stealth missions which I hated, and some nice simple puzzle-solving. There as good flow and variation during the story to keep it fresh.Exploration in this game is pretty lacking. Missions/the story is pretty linear/guided, and unless you wanted to upgrade your weapons/skills (not necessary if you played on an easier difficulty like me, I just wanted to play this game casually) there was no point in re-visiting areas. You can access 'new areas' in levels with upgraded abilities later in the game, but there's really no point unlike in Castlevania:SotN because you won't be getting new weapons/skills/etc. doing so. Don't expect some Skyrim/TES bonuses from going off the beaten pathVisually, this game is pretty good. Nice background scenery, the castle looks beautiful. The modern city is kind of 'meh', but I did appreciate how the game looked. Some of the audio tracks are great too, but you will run into a lot of the same music.Overall, I had fun with the game and enjoyed it for what it was. I admitedly got frustrated with some parts of the game and would just quit playing 10 minutes in if I couldn't advance through the story fast enough to do other stuff but my yearning for knowing what happened in this game kept me coming back. I won't be playing it beyond the story mode and doing a NG+ mode or anything like that. Buy it on sale for 10-15 dollars but I wouldn't pay full price for it.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is lying to you, there are not Lords of Shadow in this game. But luckily there is a castle, so I guess it's not all bad. Okay, half a castle.You play as Dracula...What, really? Yeah, you play as that guy you've been beating up since the 80's. Now, when I played Lords of Shadow I explained that I am not familiar with Castlevania outside of a little bit of Symphony of the Night. Now that I've played more than an hour of the original games I have a better understanding of the series. And now I come to you saying that Castlevania: Lords of Shadow as a series feels more like a fairly competent fan fiction than it's own universe.After an annoying tutorial sequence, you wake up in the DISTANT FUTURE OF 1999, at least I think it's 1999. Dracula awakens form his long slumber looking much like I do after a Saturday night, minus the incredibly handsome. After getting beaten up by a large T-rex looking monster, you are saved by a man in armor  who's wielding a suspiciously Japanese looking sword, lets just call him Scrungus Humungous for now. So Scrungus takes you back to his master Zobek, who is Patrick Stewart but also a jerk. He tells you that Satan is using his Acolytes to revive him so he can dominate the world. Zobek tells you that if you can pull Satan out of hiding and defeat him, he will give Dracula the eternal rest he longed for. So yes, this game is about Dracula fist fighting Satan. I should probably explain the game now.Much like the first game, LOS is a action beat-em-up much like God of War. You have three weapons, a whip, a sword, and your dukes, but your dukes are on fire, how rad is that? Both the sword and your fire fists are on a meter of sorts while your whip is good to go at any moment, not unlike a whip in that weird teachers basement. Your enemies come in different shapes and sizes, with a nice touch that they all have lore and back story to them. But other than a few special moves they all attack the same outside of the very few bosses you run into. Standard attacks can be both blocked and countered, leaving the enemy open for a critical attack. But every now and then, or more than often, all the time, the enemy will use a heavy attack which you will have to dodge. Outside of a few items and changing weapons on the fly, that's about as complicated as combat gets. So I'm going to say some bad stuff now.Like I said before, I finally got familiar with Castlevania as a whole, and now a lot of elements just leave a bad taste in my mouth. Outside of Dracula originally being Gabriel Belmont (Spoilers by the way, if you've never watched any of the trailers), the Belmont lineage kind of gets turned into that soup the weird lady hands out down town. Dracula and Alucard (That's Dracula backwards) are both Belmonts and the rest of the lineage kind of takes a back seat.  Actual spoilers by the way.You actually DO meet another Belmont named Victor, but he dies roughly 10 minutes after you meet him, so whatever. This is honestly kind of stupid, in the original series, Dracula was a man named Mathias Cronqvist, so not only did they change who Dracula actually IS but they also flat out replaced him with their own new character for the series: Gabriel. What was the point of this? I'm not in the fanbase but did anyone actually ask for Dracula as a playable character? It doesn't add anything because your best healing is the same healing you used in the last game because Dracula biting fools doesn't really cut it. If they really wanted you to play as a Vampire why didn't they just have you play as Alucard as you did in Symphony or that other part of Mirror of Fate? Alucard already plays better than his father does in the DLC and has a more interesting set of skills. Did they think that people really liked Gabriel so much as a character that they wouldn't want to move on to another Belmont? Perhaps continue the narrative in another way that doesn't include reusing an original character you made specifically for your reboot? It doesn't really even feel all that Castlevania like, really, outside of a few name drops and shout outs from previous games. And for a game with as much padding as Lords of Shadow 2, it sure as hell is rushed at the end. And by that I mean it just kind of ends, it's all over and then Dracula goes to take a nap. I'm not kidding, that's how it ends. Roll credits. I've watched bum fights with better closure than that. Should you play Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2: The Reckoning: Fury Road? This is actually hard. Because the game has a really strong start but then kind of fades away at the half way point. A lot of plot points are just kind of shoved aside or hand waved before the game comes to an end and it drags on just long enough for the combat to become frustrating and boring. Just like my sex life. But on the other hand, it's nowhere near as offensive as other reboots like, lets say, DmC, or my sex life. I just feel like it could have maybe cut out a lot of the fat and busy work and focused on it's strongest point. Just like my sex life. LOS2 is getting pass, but just barely, I would get it while it's on sale at five bucks or less. It's not great, but it's nowhere near as offensive as a lot of other reviewers made it out ot be. If you absolutely NEED a vampire game right at this moment, though? You can get the Legacy of Kain series for much cheaper.Fortressmania 2: Kings of Shade gets 3 badly voiced sections from Symphony of the night out of 6. Dracula backwards is Alucard.The curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

												I never played the first one in the series, so I couldnt compare how it stood against the first game. However this game by itself is easily worth the price. I loved the gothic castle enviornments, voice acting, story line and combat. What I didnt enjoy were the stealth sections, which I felt while not hard or time consumine, were simply unnecessary. content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												I want to meet every single developer who worked on this masterpiece even though their work environment was terrible and just congratulate them. I want to thank them for this game. For the amount of love they have put in this. It is so rare to see such games nowadays. If it wasn't for the terrible studio managers, this game would have been so much better. The whole team behind this game has my respect. What they have made is mind blowing - and the result isn't even as good as what they could make. Once again, it was the terrible studio managers that made this game a "mess". However, even at it's current state, Lords of Shadow 2 is a true masterpiece. The visuals are stunning, the level design is one of the best I have ever seen. The orchestral music is just beautiful. Animations are smooth and responsive. The story will hook you up. You will find yourselves playing non-stop for 7 hours just to see what is going to happen next.The voice acting is professional! The story has many plot twists and interesting character development. There are just so many great things about this game. I have no idea where the negative reviews are coming from. If you are reading this, please do yourself a favor and buy this game. It is a challenging, beautiful and fun 20-30 hour ride that you will never forget.

												It's Castlevania! That is probably the main reason you are thinking of playing this game. If you love Castlevania you'll find the game enjoyable enough. If you merely like Castlevania this game may not be very good. The medieval castle scenes are all awesome. The voice acting is good, if not great at times. The story is a fair continuation of where we left off after the first Lords of Shadow game (LoS). The modern city scenes are a tad bland and boring, though. The combat mechanics are even more fun than in the previous LoS game. The boss battles are tad easy, although there is always a higher level of difficulty to be selected. Some of the puzzles are damnably frustrating though, such as the garden with Agreus. I feel the pros far outweigh the cons though and this is a good addition to the franchise.
