content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Initially, definitely significant to mention is... *ahem*  F@CK NEGATIVE REVIEWS. Really now, many gaming magazines (see Edge #d0uche_detected) have underrated it... (4/10). Even "Octodad" or "The Banner Saga" got a higher score than LoS2... I can only assume that they were trying to elicit attention through these means... anyway --> TO THE POINT!   Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2, The Dragon Returns! :O \o/ Such a good game... but how come it has so many opponents this time, in contrary to its predecessor? lel.. Well, let's begin with the reasons I deem this game worthy of its money:+ Gorgeous Graphics+ Satisfying durance+ Wide variety of actions, skills, collectibles, missions, enemies etc.+ Very well contemplated and made plot (they have taken really good care of it), plus there is an awesome plot twist!+ The combat mechanics (endless moves, powers and upgrades)+ THE PROTAGONIST! Anyone who has played LoS 1, can definitely recall Gabriel being... uuhm... TOO QUITE! Honestly, he scarcely spoke, we knew almost nothing about him or his personality. Unlike that, this time, Gabriel (or what is left from that♥♥♥♥♥♥ starts to reveal who he really is, his character, his desires, and generally he now IS appropriate for a protagonist. (Moreover, his voice actor, Robert Carlyle, has done an undoubtly good job "incarnating" dracula)+ Yup, MANY stunning bosses ^^+ The soundtracks ;3 (♥♥♥♥♥yaeh)   ....But, there is always the other side...- A number of fans maintain that they face several problems (like the game can't start, or gets stuck at a certain point of the game). Also, in spite of the aforementionted problems, EVERYONE may face glitches (small or B I G ones)- It could become monotonus at some point, especially when you get to roam the same area over and over again... - The enviroments you play in... (yeah it's a whole new era, and yeah no more majestic forests etc., BUT, it is the plot that demands that! You are no longer Gabriel, but a creature of the night, you live in the 21st century, you can't move with the sunlight. The very game itself has "darkened". This is the reason some fans don't even consider this "negative" point at all, while others miss the old castlevania enviroments)- Despite the fact that there are many boss battles, some of them end really quickly, and it is not that difficult to understand how to defeat them. - There are TOO many (and a bit complicated) moves in the combat system, that you just don't have time to remember, use and make good use of them (some are just beautiful and expensive, nothing more, nothing less)- The final boss battle... (relatively short and easy to cope with)   To sum up, this game has both various advantages and disadvantages. But I would still recommend you to purchase it, it is really stunning, fun, and worthy of your time. Yeah, it is true that there are some disturbing drawbacks, but the advantages still surpass them. ***(This review is based on my personal view on this game. If your own view happens to be in opposition to mine, don't be a♥♥♥♥♥♥ thanks ^^)***

number of helpful: 11 of 18 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												One of the best interpretations of Dracula's castle, marred by a clumsy early game and the occasional design choice of dubious quality. The characters are enjoyable, the boss fights are true highlights, and the combat remains the meat of the game. We finally get to explore Dracula's castle in a modern 3D environment that does it justice, there are too many instances where a new area makes you pause just to admire the scenery. It is like the level designers took the concept art (which always looks so much better) and then implemented it literally, and somehow made it even better. I like the anti-hero that Gabriel became, even if they fumbled a bit in justifying how he got to that point. The original LoS had puzzle sections which some players did not care for. LoS2 eliminates those in favor of "stealth action" puzzles, which even fewer people cared for. Whoops. There's about three or four of those sections in the game, and they're really not as big of a deal as they're made out to be, but they do remain pretty funky standouts. The biggest error LoS2 makes, which I haven't really seen mentioned anywhere, is being a wildly lavish game that was hamstrung by console design. There aren't any loading screens, but there are enough terminal areas where things are being loaded in the background that it's painfully obvious what's going on. At least there are no chupacabra levels. It's clear the designer's hearts were in the castle levels. The modern era is "fine", but really lacks anything interesting. And monsters shouldn't have guns, they break your concentration meter easily and are barely telegraphed.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												It's a great game.  Alot more dark than the first game, but for what it is, it's very well presented.  There's more to do, and bigger areas to explore.  The story is a lock-step continuation of the first game, and you'll see some familiar faces and some inuendo for your imagination to figure out.  I find the dark style a little unwelcome, but that's just me.  It doesn't have to be bright and sunny, but it could have more supernatural monsters, or ... you know, just something.The fighting in this is much improved.  Some of your moves are similar to the first game, but they do more of what they are supposed to, and less scripted.  If you do a Guilotine for example, some enemies will dodge, some will block, and some will take the full brunt, instead of a guaranteed hit every time.  So those familiar moves feel so much more realistic.  Even small enemies require some strategy.One almost deal breaker was the onscreen prompts.  I started out using a keyboard-mouse, and it displays xbox prompts -ONLY.  It took me forever to associate B with "f" and Y with Mouse2.  You can get used to it though.If you liked the first game, you'll find this one better in alot more ways than not.  Qualitywise, hugely better.  Graphics, way better, Fights, hugely better.  Mood, eh... but I think the story compensates for that alot.  It looks like the DLC "Revelations" is going to have alot of what I'm looking for.  Great game all around.

number of helpful: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Continuing from the first Lords of Shadow, which had a strong sense of adventure, always moving on, traveling from one end to the other and, apart from the dlc(which I'd advice you to simply ignore entirely), never forces you to backtrack. A feeling of being on an grandious, epic, adventure through ancient lands and fairy creatures as well as monsters. It's was not the most ideal re-imagining of the Castlevania brand, there were the low's but also the high's, and the high's outweighed the low's IMO... that is until they actually continued from the epilogue and explained it.Lords of Shadow 2 is an oddly excellent example of a game who's budget coupled with one man's over-confidence(from the success of the first game) turned arrogance, effectively ruined any ounce of a future this particular franchise ever had. There is quality here, don't doubt it, it's just found sparsely between thick stretches of game-design that will utterly boggle the mind, how Enric Álvarez, the series director who, literaly, stood for every gameplay design and story sequence in LoS2, how he ever convinced himself this was good. The combat is more of less the exact same, apart from a few weapons, with an added options to turn off quicktime-events.The game is split up between modern-times, where you travel through a city which was built around Dracula's grand castle, and past times, before humanity apparently conquered the dark prince, a mystery you will only solve a half-hour before the credits roll. Execution is everything. The story telling, the characters, the level design, the various game mechanics, the leveling system to the weapons... all of it is just horribly miss-matched and all over the place. There are stealth sections equiped with enemies in god-mode. You simply aren't able to fight them and they take you out with projectiles in two hits. These sections are numerous and extremely tedious. You're supposed to be Dracula, taking on Satan himself... but you are apparently a small ant compared to this simple mob. Laughable. PR said that they were going to fuse the first LoS with SotN(one of my favorite games ever) and the thought had me riveting with saliva. I could even see it in front of me.I loathed the story almost completely. Resented every aspect of the modern levels. Not a fan of this Alucard either apart from purely visual perspective. He even retconned the story from the first game in a pretty stupid way. I bought this at full price day one. I did not listen to reviews. If you think you want this game, re-evaluate, come back after a week or so and if you still want this game... wait for a steamsale, no sense of wasting more money than you have to.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												I completed the game and basically the game doesn't have a very good story (totally ignored other people complaints about this games story, thinking it couldn't be that bad) Who could of pictured Dracula as a anti-hero, can i call him that? He comes off as bad but develops into a semi heroic character. I don't think developers will ever grasp the concept of being evil as a main character. If someone plays as a bad guy, he has to remain that way, i mean he/she has to be totally deprived of emotions and feelings. Dracula here has these and it basically takes away from the evil that the character is known for in the castlevania series. I'm content with saying he is basically a sissy compared to the Dracula in other Castlevania games. If i play as a evil bad guy, i want to bad all the way to the end. The art direction i notice is down right horrible. The art direction on satan in particular is down right terrible. I think i could of design a better version of him thats not too similar to the bible depiction of him. The armor on a couple of particular characters, dracula included are pretty much weird to me. They have the same similar design and shape, which consist of sharp wave like rig. The combat is decent, but i just don't understand why the devs didn't add more skills to draculas default whip, they had room to. They could have even recycled some of gabriels whip skills from lord of shadows. While playing i kept thinking i could do one of my favorite skills from the first Lord Of Shadows but then reality hit.. Final battle could of been done better, instead they went for a semi-cliche kind of approach, which is expected in other games. If you're a castlevania fan, you'll expect a really cliche climatic Castlevania final battle, which isn't a bad thing. I guess these guys didn't play the castlevania games, when putting this one together. If it was me i would of added a bit of fanservice to the game. I can say artwise, though the graphics are pretty good, the devs dropped the ball hard on this game. It's a ok game if you just want combat, decent boss battles, but dont expect a great blow your mind game experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												Lords of Shadow 2 is a very good, but not quite a great game. It has some flaws, but it has fun gameplay and a rich atmosphere. It's mostly a character action game with some open world elements.Firstly, the good stuff. Most of the time playing this game you will be either in combat with enemies, or exploring the world. Combat is very fun and engaging, albeit not the deepest of the genre. It can't rival the likes of Platinum's work, but still creates a fun system that keeps you wanting more. It has a nice rhythm to it as it requires you to always keep an eye on enemies and properly timing blocking to keep your combo up, which is crucial for the "Focus" system. This system is also what gives you the power needed to use two of the three main weapons. These two weapons also have special effects, such as freezing enemies or burning away their armour, but break your Focus. It creates this flow to combat that feels very fluid and back-and-forth, meaning you can't get lazy and just endlessly wail on enemies without opposition, especially on higher difficulties. The different weapons also feel distinct from each other outside of their special effects. They each have different range, speed, and power, and there are plenty of combos in each weapon that all have a use in different combat situations, which are unlocked in an RPG style experience system.The aesthetic of the game is also great. Everything has a dark and intricate look to it, with stunning Gothic architecture and really interesting world and boss design. The soundtrack is also fantastic, with a sweeping orchestral sound that fits the melodramatic and dark feel of the game. This makes simply being in the game world and moving around it a lot of fun. It does a good job of helping you soak in the atmosphere, both in and out of combat. The kinaesthetics too, are fantastic. The weapons all have a very satisfying feel to them. A sense of power and impact, but also vibrancy. They leave trails colour that arc around in the air as you swing your weapons, or explosions when they hit enemies. Some of the more powerful moves are especially impressive in how they surround you in a storm of whirling lights that destroys everything in the area.The structure of the game world is pretty interesting as well, and quite unique for the genre. Unlike the first game in the Lords of Shadow series, this game is set in two moderately sized open-world areas. It is somewhat inspired by the traditional Castlevania style of level design, but isn't really the focus of the gameplay here. Yet it still manages to achieve this feeling of place to the game world. You can explore around the worlds seamlessly, without any loading screens, and many areas are connected, and sometimes loop around on each other. This also aids the sense of atmosphere to the game, and gives the game much better pacing than the first as well. Here, you're not thrown back to the main menu to sit through a long loading screen every fifteen minutes. It's nowhere near as dense and maze-like as the older Castlevania games, or something like Dark Souls, but for what it brings to the type of game it is, it's a great addition.There are also some areas of the game which are clearly lacking, though they are not anywhere near significant enough to ruin the experience.Firstly, there are the much lamented stealth sections. These are pretty bad, but not game-breakingly so. They feel half-baked and somewhat forced in to the game, by taking away your ability to fight while entering a stealth section. The mechanics of the stealth sections are also shallow, and it’s not exactly clear when you are detected or not. When you are, although it's not an instant failure, it might as well be, given that you will be attacked by enemies that can kill you in two hits or so, even with all the health upgrades. But even so, these sections are relatively rare. They make up only what is probably 5% or less of the actual main story. On top of that they are all incredibly short and easy. All they require you to do most of the time is sneak to the other side of a small room. Usually that involves nothing more than distracting one enemy, or possessing another. Additionally, once a stealth section has been cleared, you will never have to do it again if you return to the same area. Another problem is the story. It's a confused mess of underutilised characters and poorly explained plot devices. This game was set up as a big finale to the Lords of Shadow story, and unfortunately it mostly fails at that. There are a lot of characters in the game which don't get as much time as they need to really make the impact they could. They often appear only as bosses, given a short introduction and forgotten immediately after. While the boss fights themselves are fun, from a story perspective they feel like they are being given the short straw. There are also some elements of the story that are fairly crucial to the plot which aren't explained well at all. For example the Mirror of Fate, from the game of the same name, also plays a prominent role in this game, but its significance isn't explained here, and its role seems unrelated to the game it was introduced in. But despite this, there are a few good moments. A conversation or two that hit on some interesting points, although they are never explored as they could be, still bring out some good character moments. Even so, the story isn't a huge part of the game. It can be mostly ignored, and it's not as if the series had a particularly great story to begin with. The best part of the story was mostly the tone and feeling of it, which in both the previous games and this one, are mostly achieved through the aesthetics.So overall, Lords of Shadow 2 is a pretty good game. Far from perfect, but certainly undeserving of the baffling critical mauling it got. If you were a fan of the previous Lords of Shadow game(s), then this should be right up your alley as well. It's far from the best game in the world, but much like its predecessors, it is a flawed gem.As a side note, I recommend that if you have played the first game, but not Mirror of Fate, you should also play that before this one. The stories are quite closely connected, and as previously mentioned, this game expects you to be familiar with it. Although it’s not as good as LoS2, MoF is short and can be beaten in a day if you focus on only the main story.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
 Interesting game with many Pros and Cons. BLUF: Recomended IF you wait for a Steam Sale/game patching.Heres what I found to be the best and worst of the game, in order of presedence. Positives    Good story line   Very good visuals, particularily the scenery (it seemed this is where they put their most effort into.)   Fluid, responcive, satisfying combat. Completley reminicent to the God Of War series.   Good characters/voice acting. I personally enjoyed watching all of the cut scenes.   Partialy destructable enviornment. Cans clutter and such.   Challenging boss fights.  Negitives       It wants you to play with a game pad. The game does not seem to be designed for a mouse and keyboard. Every Single Time there is a quick time event the UI will come up telling you to spam things like the left trigger to an Xbox controller. Made me have to consult the key mapping way way too often.       Claims to be partly open world when it really is not. You get to revisit previously traveled to destinations. Mainly rooms and hallways in a completley linear path.      Dracula does not act like Dracula. You find yourself with menial tasks, and small obsticals that make little sence. You're supposed to be the Prince of Darkness.. Satan is concerned with how powerful you are.. but hold on I have to run down stairs to turn on a power switch to activate an elevator to go to the next floor. Tell me that's somthing a Vampire Lord would do.      Silly stealth sections. Again, knowing forwell that Satan fears you, you decide to morph into a rat and sneak around a guard or two, here and there. Must be one hell of a guard.  Insta kill if they find you btw. On that note, you never face them in open combat.       Invisible walls. If a spot is not game essential, you're not going there. Don't expect an Assassins Creed style of play here.      The game holds your hand the whole way through. The camera will usualy show you exactly where you need to go, how to get there, and have either a glowy thing waiting for you or a char shouting to you with explanations. Yet, some parts you just havent the foggiest bit of a hint of where to go.      Low replay value. There are elements present to keep you busy after the main story is over, however I can't see entertainment value lasting with that; or starting a new save; albite there are always diffrent difficulty levels if you're into that.      The only way to die in this game is in a giant explosion of blood. The enemies almost always blow up, or burst into blood. I think that greatly takes away from the feel of it.   Another game that likes to kill off just about everyone. You catch onto the trend of: Oh a new guy. Guess he's the next boss..  but this ones my opinion, maybe you just like all that murder.One list seems to be bigger than the other. Hrm.So to wrap up, The game has a solid foundation, and is fun; 15 ish+ hours gameplay. However there are some problems that sound like somebody put money over quality. I may have been nitpicking but this is a $60.00 game, and theres another $10.00 or so worth of DLC.Nothing is perfect, but if you're going to put somthing out at full price don't do it half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Regrettably, that seems to be what this is. They came so close but just didn't go all the way. As I said up top; Sure I'll recomend this title.. but not right now. This is somthing that you will enjoy playing, but not with the current pricetag/greavences.P.S.Is it just me or do the DLC costumes just look like a recolored version of what he's already wearing??

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												Castlevania LoS2 Is what I would define as bad oatmeal. Strong elements of several kinds without a smoot transition is what makes the experience feel forced, or what may force you to have harsh feelings about the game. (Like I did)Merging strong storytelling with exploration using cutscenes is a big no in the experience category. When you find a new area or get past or to a boss or story area, you get a cutscene that either  shows you everything you want to find on your own, or tells you a story that moves you from the area before you can finish exploring. Other games manage this type of merge by using character narration or slowing the walk speed. Strong combat elements with excessive backtracking: Having to down half a dozen enemies who are tiered to what part of the main story you are on just because you are looking for something is what I hate most about the game. The lack of loot and a equipment system makes me lose the edge for excessive combat, but in addition to that, almost every enemy has a ranged attack that has huge hitboxes that they are all too happy to use deciding you would like to skip the battle. Most battles near the endgame or after you gained a new traversal ability are begun with a groan because you've been shot off a ledge to the point where you do want to fight just so you can enjoy the game. The mastery system ends way too early to entice excessive battling and credits are easy to get provided you dpend them properly upgrading skills you'll most likely use. The open world element is trashed by an isolated map system and the same looking load elevators and hatches. Find things in this game is met with repeatedly going the wrong way and passing points where you cannot backtrack through the area after you jumped down. The areas are intertwined somewhat and only one or two pllaces have this problem, but that tied with the block the area rests in being behind one of like 5 blue elevator doors makes the experience irritating and repetitive.But after you swallow those strong flavors and seperate them by improvising, you can stop to appreaciate the art and fluidity of the combat and the thought they put into hiding the upgrades. And then when all that is getting good... The game is over. It's metroid all over again. Get the screw attack, Find stuff, kill the last guy. I just hope there is a secret boss or something. The alucard dlc is honestly why I bought the game. For some reason, everything dracula backwards is in seems to get more polish than the game itself... for some reason, that's still true. Alucard has proper last gen hair animation, a shiny coat, skin that is also pale but not sickening to look at, skills that are practical, a sword and movelist that probably drove the fans crazy, and one of the coolest ideas for a puzzle element ever. It doesn't break pace ever, and it makes you feel like you're a strong character. Instead of being dracula where you never even got to beat one of the guards that caused you so much trouble without taking over their body and dropping their gun. It's one of those games that gets better when you play it. The start is slow, and the search is tedius, but after you play through it, you realize it is really a fantastic idea made into a just okay game. Where in my opinion, Lament of innocence probably takes the cake for a castlevania game, and alucard still takes the cake for the coolest vampire. Dracula should have stayed dead... Could have been a way better game.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Remember everything: a vampire is said to be ageless and immortal, yet it is an aged, anemic, amnesic Dracula we see at the begin of Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2's story, after the flashbacked prologue reminiscing Golden Paladin Roland de Ronceval and the Brotherhood of Light's fatal assault on the Gothic castle five hundred years ago. Gabriel-Dracula, now a thousand years old, awakes at the exit of the Cathedral into the nocturnal streets of Castlevania City, built upon the remains of his old Castle. He won't be astray much time but soon be meeting the two characters guiding him through the plot: young Trevor Belmont, the never known son, and Zobek, Lord of the Dead and former nemesis, now an influential businessman.It apparently has been one of the developers' worries to enhance the game where the first Lords of Shadow has most been criticized: so the camera can freely be moved in a 360-degree angle now, the framerate is increased, and the formerly linear setting and storyline made place for an open-world design offering a greater variety in the pacing chosen. Also the gameplay has notably been improved and the sound, vibrant combat mechanics using the default X360 controller is thoroughly satisfying to use (Quick-Time Events can be deactivated in the Game Options menu).Well-executed are also the necessary climbing and jumping sections that seem largely scripted, in addition to some occasional platforming elements which are usually easy to achieve thanks to a generous savepoint system.Swarming bats indicate audibly where to proceed to the next ledge or ladder which is useful during as well as after beating the game, in addition to the White Wolf Medallion and the Map rooms for quick-traveling, to continue exploring the medieval Castle and the modern City.Both the epic bossfights and the numerous collectibles (580 in total) give the game its replay value, in order to try oneself on a higher difficulty level or get one's skills and gauges maxed out.No doubt, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is an ambitious game: what sets in quite like another God of War replica and stumbles at the gloomy entrance of Castlevania City's Sciences district, soon evolves into an extraordinary, creative Gothic action-adventure, with breathtaking visuals, atmospheric music (Óscar Araujo), and an unforgettable plot that relies heavily on the franchise's previous releases.Story-wise, Castlevania is an epic family drama the likes of Star Wars: akin to Anakin Skywalker, Gabriel Belmont changes sides as he becomes the Prince of Darkness which opposes him to his own son Alucard (Luke), albeit those family bonds seem to be the only human trait left as he shows indulgence towards Victor, leader of the Brotherhood of Light and last of the Belmont bloodline.The story finds a worthy conclusion in Lords of Shadow 2, but the myth is probably just too good to simply let it die: “Who knows what fate has in store.”Read the full user review on: http://www.gamespot.com/castlevania-lords-of-shadow-2/user-reviews/2200-12606707/

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 has polarized its' audience upon release: while the game is mostly well received by the gamers, it's has been a subject to negative criticism by the game media.So is Lords of Shadow 2 a worthy sequel?There has been some changes since the prequel, some for the worse and some for the better.Lords of Shadow 2's core element is the combat which is very smooth and features a free movement camera. Gameplay wise the arcadish mission selection approach has been replaced by an open world with transitions from the present, modern age  to the medieval ages.There's also a stealth mechanics introduced in the sequel, which is largely criticized by many people.But is this new feature really THAT bad? I think not, while it certainly breaks the pace of the game, the number and difficulty of these segments are LOW, that it shouldn't bother many people. And certainly not a reason not to play the game because of these parts.That being said, this game is a very solid and entertaining entry in the franchise, which also concludes the Lords of Shadow trilogy!PROS:- Graphics are gorgeous, and performance wise the game is very well optimized!- Soundtrack is excellent, and so is the voice acting!- The game design also well done in Lords of Shadow 2. This includes the architecture, level, creature and boss designs.- Combat is easier, than Lords of Shadow 1, but still very satisfying.- Boss fights are easier than Lords of Shadow 1, but at the same time very entertainining.- Platforming segments are more fluent this time.- Lot's of content and collectibles providing huge replay value.NOT PRO, BUT NOT CON EITHER:- Due to the newly introduced open world approach, the arcadish level selection feature is gone in Lords of Shadow 2. This means boss fights cannot be replayed, unless you start a new game! CONS:- While the story is good, the story-telling is not so coherent as it was in the last game.- Some characters weren't introduced properly (lack of screentime)- Xbox button prompts, and console HUD. This wasn't an issue in the prequel, so there's no excuse here!- The difficulty decreased signifantly in all aspects. This includes platforming, combat and boss fights as well.- Puzzle elements were mostly removed from Lords of Shadow 2. It's a pity, the prequel had some nice puzzles.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Castelvania: Lords of Shadow 2 is a wonderful ride from start to finish, with very few road bumps along the way. If you're a fan of action games, exploration games, or loved the first Lords of Shadow, there is plenty here to be happy about. However, if you were NOT a fan of the first game, there is little reinventing of the wheel here to pull you into the franchise.Gameplay: 8/10The exploration from the modern areas to the realm of Dracula's Castle is fluid. Dracula moves very intuitively, response time is great, and once the game really starts to open up its areas you really get this sense of a large scale fluid world. The negative here would be the platforming, or lack there of. Platforming in LOS2 is mostly just wall climbing from grapple to grapple. It can feel a little dull at times.Combat: 9/10The combat system from the first Lords of Shadow returns, but with a HUGE overhaul. It has been streamlined to perfection in almost every area. The pace at unlocking skills feels perfect, the variety of Dracula's weapons is interesting enough to keep combat feeling fresh, and the combinations of moves Dracula can perform make combat easily the most enjoyable experience of LOS2.Story: 8/10Continuing where LOS1's ending left off, the story of LOS2 is a great epic. There are moments in the story that had me jaw drop, the highs are fantastically done. However, there are low points. There are a few twists that you can see happening a mile away that occur, and there are two specific points in the story that really bring down the overall score. Without spoiling for those who haven't played, the two negatives I attribute to story are in the case of a character being VASTLY underused, and the game's ending.Music: 9/10It's awesome. Orchestral awesomeness. The somber tones, the high symphonies, everything. It's not classic Castlevania, but it deserves praise all its own.Graphics (PC): 8/10Even if there is occasional tearing and the odd lightning hear and there, LOS2 is very pleasing to look at. The game looks great.Other notes: As many have read, there are *stealth* sections in this game. I am not even going to dignify them to allow a drop in score, because they are NOT broken, NOR are they impossible. They slightly disrupt the flow of the game in some parts, but if you utilize ALL of your abilities (Shadow Daggers, Bats, Mist form, Possession) and use your brain, these sections are laughably easy. The most infamous response to these sections have been from Kotaku, who's reviewer got stuck on one particular section for FOUR hours. I completed the same section in less than two minutes. Use your abilities, and these sections are trivial.Overall: 8.75/10LOS2 is a great game that is sadly being underplayed by major media sources. It is NOT game of the year, sure, but this is a solid title that can stand on its own and a wonderful edition to the Castlevania franchise. Mercury Steam should be proud of LOS2, because they made a good game. I enjoyed my 14 hour playthrough, and will continue to play it for 100% and achievements.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												It's a big improvement of the first game. No doubt about that. Also I would love to like this game but it's decent at best. I'm pretty sure they made it as irritating as they could. I'm going to list the MAJOR grievances I have with this game.EXAMPLE: At one point in the game, you have to ride an elevator. So you kill a bunch of enemies and go to the elevator to find out it has no power. Then you go back to the entrance and start the generator. All enemies respawn and you kill them again. When you're finally at the elevator there's still no power since the generator has a timer >: ( So back to the entrance again and start the generator AGAIN! Then back to the elavator a final third time. Frustrates me to no end.The game constantly pulls this sort of thing. EXAMPLE: You see a powerup just out of reach. You move through the entire area of jumping puzzles and climbing to get to the top. That's where the way to the powerup is found and you have to jump down all the way to the beginning to get it.Unnecessary and long cutscenes is also gravely irritating. I love cutscenes when they tell story and fill a purpose.When you fast travel you get a 15 sec cutscene when he "opens" the device, a second cutscene (10 sec) when he enters, and a third (10 sec) when he exits. That is not fast. When you enter the shop there is a annoying cutscene every time.To be fair though you can skip the cutscenes by entering the pause menu and selecting skip cutscene but that is also slow and annoying.Oh! I broke my keybord in half in pure rage recently when playing the challenges in this game. You don't get full health or magic between tries. You don't even get back the levels of hp and mp you had when you entered the challenge if you retry. And the goals in the challenges are not set to be fun. They are set to be as irritating as (un)humanly possible.And the chupacabra character. I seriously want to punch the creator of that guy. I'm dead serious.Other than that it's a pretty decent game. Combat is mostly fun and the whole idea with the castle(won't say more) was actually great. The lore is a good read and the existance of dodo birds is a great relief for any perfectionist. Also the freedom to run around the city and castle however you want (after you've unlocked the area) is a welcome change in the series.Oh! Also the story is pretty bad.If it's on sale and you're bored, buy it. Otherwise stay away!

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is an action-adventure game, the sequel to the 2010 game Castlevania: Lords of Shadow, and the 34th installment in the Castlevania franchise (37th if one includes the 3 Pachislot games). The game was developed by MercurySteam and published by Konami. It was released late February 2014 in both North America and Europe and on March 2014 in Australia. A Japanese release was released on September 4, 2014. A downloadable chapter has also been released in March from the same year.GameplayAs in the previous game, the player controls Gabriel Belmont, now known as Dracula, as he fights through an open world. During the game's opening sequence the player is able to control Dracula while he still possesses all his powers as well as all of his weapons. Dracula's main weapon is his Shadow Whip, a weapon that is comparable to the Combat Cross from the original Lords of Shadow. Replacing the magic system from the previous game are the Void Sword and the Chaos Claws. The Void Sword can replenish Dracula's health when used while the Chaos Claws can be used to break through enemy defenses and deliver powerful attacks. The story mode in Lords of Shadow 2 has been stated to be far longer than the previous one. The game is mainly an open world allowing the player to choose what route to take. Lords of Shadow 2 features a movable camera, something that was not available in its predecessor.My opinionThe game is fun, but it's optimized poorely. The controls with keyboard are pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥and FPS drops make it even more worse and PLUS horrible stealth mechanic ruins most of the fun. I fixed of the problems by using Razer Onza controller. This game has a good plot which I don't want to spoil, but if you're unfamiliar with the previous game- don't worry, there's a short re-cap in the start of the game.  The slasher elements make the gameplay live and interesting and the level up system doesn't award those who use only one combo, which makes you use different variations of attacks. The game is great for the money that are asked for it.Would recommend to:*Fans of Slashers*Fans of Vampires*Fans of games with great story*Fans of lags/horrible controlls/bad stealthWould not recommend to:*Old fans of Castlevania (Way before the first Lords of Shadow was released)

content:
Posted: February 16
												tl;dr - Enjoyable hack-and-slash game in nice gothic environments.If playing with a Steam Controller, take note - some of the cutscenes are so long that the Steam Controller falls asleep and the game immediately pauses, asking you to connect a controller.  Find a way to get your controller to not sleep, you should be OK.Graphics - played nicely at 144fps on a GTX 980 Ti, no hitches, very smooth. Storywise, overall, it's as decent as a hack-and-slash can get. There are plenty of evocative names and mythological tie-ups, I felt they were well presented. I don't think it's necessary to play the prequel to this, there is a somewhat incoherent recap of the occurences, but it doesn't matter too much. I am one of the few people who is not a fan of the prequel to this game, but I'm happy with this one.The presentation of in-game lore was nicely done.  You have a book with nice drawings, short texts, there are diaries and even your power-ups have descriptions.  At times I felt some of the boss fights were a bit short, they just ended too quickly.   The final fight felt short and straightforward too.  I think perhaps the fights weren't meant to be difficult, just a means to move on.  Some of the mob-fights, however, were of satisfying difficulty.  Some reviewers are not happy about the stealth parts of the game.  I can relate, it's understandable, thankfully those parts are not too long and you can quickly get over it.  You can also return to those areas later.

												In my opinion, most of the video reviews I came across don't give this game the credit it deserves. In a sentence, this is an excellent third person action game, with very nice and enjoyable combat mechanics, which is what matters to me most in this kind of games.Once you get a good feeling of the combat system (might take a while though), defeating hordes of enemies becomes very satisfying. Comparing it to the benchmark -in my opinion- of the category Batman Arkham City/Origins, you don't get to feel as invincible as Batman (although you're supposed to be even more badass), but the combinations and the options you have in the battle are more engaging.Most of the critics seem to point out how it is unfit for Dracula to be in a modern era context. Some others seem to dislike the story ending. Let me say that, although this is my first Castlevania game (since the original one on SNES :P ) and I didn't follow the earlier episodes, the story seemed to me to be brilliantly scripted, especially due to its clever ending (no spoilers), where everything is explained.If you are like me and are searching for a third person action game in the style of Batman Arkham series, where nice combat mechanics is your priority, then I think this is a game you will enjoy.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												I'm going to start by saying that my overall experience with this game is more positive than negative. While there are a few issues that detract from the overall experience, they are not serious enough for me to not recommend the game. Some key points follow.The combat system is an evolution of the one in the first game, with significant refinements that make for a very smooth experience. For example, you can dodge and parry attacks even in the air. While the skill trees for each of the weapons may seem labyrinthine at first, if you put some thought into how they're structured and how each of the moves are executed, you'll start to realize how elegantly designed Dracula's moveset is. Gone are the difficult-to-execute combos in the first Lords of Shadow; you now have a broad range of attacks that are easily performed with plenty of versatility for nearly any combat situation.Setting and environmental design is generally excellent. Both in the castle and in the city, there's a great sense of scale, and the level of detail put into the environment is absolutely incredible. Overall, it's designed in the open-world "Metroidvania" tradition, with plenty of exploration and discovery. Many level design cues have been taken from the Assassin's Creed series, which isn't a bad thing since I've always liked their level design; likewise, when not in combat, Dracula himself handles a lot like Connor from Assassin's Creed III. However, it is not completely flawless; ......in particular, some of the stealth sections need improvement. While the ones involving Golgoth Guards aren't exactly bad, Agreus's maze and Carmilla's blood curse puzzle are questionably designed, leaving the player very little room for error which can lead to frustration.The story is good, but not great. Dracula as a character has some very nice background but scenario design can be a bit better and the ending is a bit too open-ended.Again, neither of the last two points are enough to take away my recommendation. It's sad that these (relatively minor) flaws in an otherwise well-executed game led to such negative critical reception from several expert reviewers. Playing as the Prince of Darkness himself has been an unforgettable experience for me and I ultimately enjoyed the game. Recommended.

content:
Posted: February 20
												Mercury steam sequel of their reboot of the Castlevania series takes the ip back to its root of exploring an entire whole castle, where different sections have unique style, mechanics and monsters. It is probably the closest someone got to make a full 3D experience of Castlevania Symphony of the night. As for the first reboot the game is also at its core a spectacle fighting game.The story of the game is suspended between two moments in time. In the present, your character, Dracula, wakes up after a very…very long sleep and faces a the evil deeds that are being made in what remains of his castle, now part of a whole city with a high tech facility rule by evil itself. Dracula also has to gain back his lost powers and it will do so traveling back in time to his old castle. Unlocking new areas and abilities will allow Dracula to travel more and more freely to every part of the levels in the typical Metroidvania style. Enemies will respawn every time in the same place giving you always some challenge. It may though get to become repetitive (a common problem with backtracking in this type of game design). What will not become tiresome is how beautiful the environments are! Especially the old castle, simply stunning. The same effort was not exactly put into enemy design, which are a bit more repetitive than in the prequel (no more mounting on orcs or giant spiders!)The combat system is solid, strikes have impact force despite being almost all whip based and allow for a decent amount of combination, crowd control and power strikes, but not as much as tytles like Devil May Cry or Bayonetta. Mobility during combat is now much improved compared to the prequel, you can dash as much as you want in any direction, which really gives you the sensation of being a superpowered mischevious vampire that moves swiftly and strikes hard! The combat itself did not changed much from the first game. Magic attacks now use a sword and gauntlets instead of different colors of the whip attack, changing a lot the range of actions, but the combo scheme is copied into every weapon set (whip, sword and gauntlet alike).The interesting combat mechanic of the series, the focus mechanic, comes back. This mechanic builds up a meter for chaining combos and variation of techniques used (as the meter of score for Devil May Cry) and is set back to zero if you are hit. Instead of just being linked to a score rating this focus meter is directly linked to the combat. Once it is filled enemies start giving magic refill, which you can absorb to fill up one of your two magic style (healing/defense style with the sword or heavy attack style with the gauntlet). Timing your block properly is probably the most efficient way to build up focus meter and create opening to attack even stronger enemies. The sync block mechanic (such is the name of this timing block thing) will create a sort of light explosion which will stagger enemies and slow time for a bit, great visual effect and good for planning your reposte.I had the impressions that enemies and boss design had a step back compared to the prequel, but it may be due to the amount of time you will have to backtrack (especially for completionists).In conclusion, I liked playing this title as much as the prequel, it is probably a more direct 3D successor to Castlevania than the first Lords of Shadows. It has some flaws for sure, but it a solid title if you wish for a good spectacle fighter with a Castlevania flavor.  I really hope a third title comes out taking the good of Lords of Shadows 1 and 2, combining them and smoothing the mistakes. That would really be a great game…but unfortunately it is Konami we are talking about…so don’t hold your breath.

Posted: May 25, 2015
												- Graphics :Very very good. Few glitches here & there. Still wondering why Dracul would have a shadow but no reflection (because they're kind of the same thing...). But a very nice and polished game graphically speaking. Artistic direction is... you know, quite nice. The environment are less numerous than in the previous game considering we really have two sets : the castle & the modern town, but both are cool to explore (yes, even the modern world).- Sound & Musics :Voice acting is yet again very good, musics are kind of below the quality of the first game's ones.- Gameplay :A bit better than the first game : it's still the same thinking but with more variety (you got a whip, your fists & a sword this time), the moves are really fun to launch and there's more strategy this time. The boss fights have also improved.... 'xcept the last one...- Storytelling :So, it's the conclusion, and all in all it's not that bad but there's one thing that totally ruined it for me : the ending. The last battle & the ending following that is one of the worst I've seen. Last battle : too easy and not at all making you feel involved in it. And the ending was totally rushed, it just sucks. This whole ending was completely rushed.- Length : Half the time you'll need to complete the first LoS, this game is much shorter (partly due to the fact that it's much easier)CONCLUSION :IT'S NOT A BAD GAME. You need to remember that. BUT:  it's lacking a lot in the storytelling (especially nearing the end) & in environment. I still recommend it because the whole experience isn't a bad one... not just the epic game everyone was expecting.....

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												If you're reading this review, you've probably played the original Castlevania: Lords of Shadow. If not, go check out that game first before you buy LoS 2, since this game relies VERY heavily on the backstory from the original LoS.For those of you who have played the original LoS and finished the game, your next question is probably going to be: how does LoS 2 compare to the original?I was a very big fan of the original LoS, and my review of that game gave it a 9 on 10, with high praise for its beautiful landscapes and art direction, for its incredible musical soundtrack, its professional voice acting, and for its ambition in telling the origin story of Castlevania. I felt its weak points were the holes in the story that sometimes just didn't make any sense, and the odd puzzles that forced you into a puzzle menu to play the associated minigame.LoS 2 retains all of the things that I felt made LoS a wonderful work of art, and also retains the higher resolution graphic textures that are unique to the PC version. It still runs easily at 120 fps for those who are using 120hz monitors and want to lock the VSync to the refresh. No screen tearing, no artifacts, just beauty. But be sure to disable the motion blur in the graphic settings (setting it to LOW is 100% disabled).The game looks stunning, the backdrops and scenery are jaw-dropping, the animation is superb and flows like water. New weapons in the game have their own detailed animations and combos, and open up a whole new God of War-like variation to weapon variety that wasn't present in the first LoS. The music is modernized but retains the original LoS theme throughout many of the compositions, keeping true to the original soundtrack (the composer is the same as the original LoS, so he knows exactly how to bring back variations on the old tunes). If you were a fan of the original, then I strongly recommend buying this game. In my opinion, this game is as good as the original, if not better in a number of ways. It isn't just a brand new story slapped on top of the old one, but rather it builds entirely on the story from the first LoS and gives it a full tribute in everything that it does. It is a very worthy sequel to the original game.As a final score, I give Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 a rating of 9 on 10.  The only reason it did not score a 10 on 10 was due to the introduction of a new stealth mechanic that wasn't entirely fleshed out enough. Thankfully it isn't used that frequently, but it can get frustrating when you're in the mood to kick♥♥♥♥♥and you're forced into a medicore stealth mode.I'd also like to thank Mercurysteam and Konami for releasing this game on PC, and for releasing it at the same time as their Console launches! They have shown us PC gamers a great deal of respect. Thank you!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												The original text was published on Kanobu on 25.02.2014I don’t know if a secret contest is taking place among the slasher game developers for the most over-the-top prologue*; but if there is one, then Lords of Shadow 2 is a shoe-in for the grand prize. First game of the series reboot by MercurySteam has greeted you with a slow gothic fantasy. This time the game gets right into the action. The protagonist is Dracula himself. He uses his own blood as a whip. His castle is under attack by an army of thousands. This army has a giant humanoid robot. The stakes are high, rivalries are thousands-of-years-old, prophecies are dark, and angels are fallen. And then there’s the usual removal of all those nice abilities which used to allow you to perform a complete massacre on poor grunts of the army which was attacking you.The combat system looks exactly like the one of its predecessor: accentuated counter-attacks and two bars of special energy used to break blocks and heal. Both kinds of magic now have unique weapons, but controls are still the same. What stands out is a free-floating camera as opposed to static angles from the first game. A lot of delightful improvements to what already worked perfectly before aren’t the biggest surprise. The game looks back at the series’ legacy and remembers where the second part of metroidvania term came from. The world is a holistic labyrinth with inaccessible high passages and grates standing in your way. This promise of big and small secrets is the foundation for everything else here. The story progression path goes in big stretches only occasionally offering to come back to the earlier places. You could replay levels in the first game to access locked upgrades once you’ve acquired the required ability, but you also had to go through the repetition of story scenes and routes weren’t particularly interesting.The second installment simply blends the secrets in the world as a part of a bigger picture. The scenery is grotesque most of the time and is occasionally filled with details for you to look at for some time. Half of the locations are in the future, of course, so it adds up to a final result of a truly bizarre over-stylized collage.The wild outlook in accompanied by an equally wild script. It defies logic in favor of having more and more bizarre characters and spectacular action scenes. If there’s a fight on a moving train it’ll end with a crash, explosions and acrobatics. You can’t just kill the giant boss — you have to rip out its heart. It is completely normal for the protagonist to ride a giant gas bottle because he needed a new entrance in the building. The headcount of unlucky enemies of Dracula is in a thousands range. Relentless postmodern carnival wouldn’t give you a break, so at some point you just can’t be surprised by anything. Raisa Volkova, the daughter of Satan? Sounds completely normal!Lords of Shadow 2 wants to go further than its predecessor so desperately and tries so much new stuff, that sometimes it ends with stuff that is just too cringeworthy. Clumsy stealth sections simply don’t hold up to the pace of the game and are irritating rather than entertaining.Still, you get transformations into blood mist and rat pack out of this torture. Two more instruments for world-exploring toolset. You can see in it the reminiscence of what Symphony of the Night did to Rondo of Blood. The story of the series also goes in circles on the moebius band of time-travelling nonsense. The game may pass a self-parody for the long franchise with a few dozens of titles in it. And that may be a good thing sometimes.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												8/10 Not the best action game you're ever going to play but definitely worth considering if you're a fan of the genre. Stealth parts nearly ruins it, but the sound/visual quality is very good compared to other games. Story makes virtually no sense compared to the first LOS but the combat system is well worth the purchase, a lot deeper than other games, and along with a lot of collectibles make it worth a second playthrough.  Plays similar to GOW for puzzles/platforming to compliment the fighting which isn't a bad thing since there isn't that many games like this on PC. Like the first game though, took a lot of ideas from other games, but didn't really interograte them quite as well e.g. the pharmaceutical industry and the monsters; the failored light/shadow combat system (DMC), the stealth system (Dishonored), and the open exploration (Metroid-ish).Ending was slightly disappointing. Just seemed that the whole story wasn't well thought out enough plot wise. The DLC is worth a look too if you liked the main game.  Doesnt deserve all the bad press it got, and definitely look forward to going through a second time with a better laptop to really indulge on the visuals. Difficulty has been nerved compared to the LOS.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												I have been a fan of this series since the first game was released on NES. Although I liked the lore/story of the first Lord of Shadows a lot, I felt the first game was a little bloated with filler and lacked a strong third act. Lords of Shadow 2 is a better game and sequel.  Its a great twist with the changing of time (past/present) through the game and the mulitple, over the top boss fights (I really like a game with boss fights). I would highly recommend this to fans of the series. Unfortuantely, if you have not played the first Lords of Shadow the story is a continuation and will not make sense. PROS: Beautiful graphics/music to match. Awesome environments in the past and present time spans. CRAZY boss fights! Better story than the first. CONS: Too many skills and weapon upgrades that are not necessary. I used about four out of each set.             The transport system to teleport from each part of the city is far and inbetween.             Final boss was a little underwhelming.

												This is a very fun to play, yet poorly written game. The visuals are incredibly good, voice cast is awesome and voice acting is overwhelmingly amazing, combat is fun and diverse. content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												Poor sequel to LOS1. Too many cutscenes & too many QTE's but not enough gameplay.This is a very poor sequel to LOS1 (a superb game). Such a shame same developer as well but there you go a bloated tedious in places by the numbers God Of War clone set in the LOS universe. If you like QTE's instead of gameplay & designs borrowed from Dark Souls, Devil May Cry & Darksiders then you may like this but the gamplay is terrible due to the atrocious confusing level design & a dual nature (future/past). The Castlavania castle sections are superb the rest of the game is quite frankly filler to pad it out to twice  as long as it needed to be & the stealth sections are some of the worse seen in many years. I hope Konami can listen to consuer feedback & offer a patch to skip those stealth sections as they are nothing but frustating. You can skip the QTE's I hope a patch lets you skip the stealth sections as those alone hurt the game a lot bu the overall feeeling is of a developer who rushed this out the door. I have not even mentioned why they chose to have the main character as Dracula (I know how LOS1 ended) its so odd & adds nothing at all really. PC textures are also pretty poor in places after the great work on LOS1 you would expect at least the same on LOS2 but the developer has not put any real effort into the PC its barely different to the console versions apart from FPS.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												This game improves upon everything they did in first game.  No more fixed camera, and there's a decent arsenal of subweapon to experiment with.  They way you level up weapons and techniques encourages variety in combat.  Unlike the first game the Light and Dark magic forms have their own weapons.  Void Sword and Chaos Claws once leveled up can be used long enough so you can experiment with them instead of just using them when you know you the extra health or damage.  Also since the game is open world it's much easier to backtrack and find secrets you may have missed on your first time through.  That was the biggest pain about LoS1 since you have replay an entire stage.  Though at least the chapters were divided up into multiple areas.Hard to understand all the hate for this game, but I can understand some of it.  The story is a bit whacky, and the events that bridge the two games have their own 3DS game (which was ported to console and PC), but that game is really lackluster.  Kind of depressing since the summary they give in the beginning of this game is really interesting.  Almost wish that game would've been Lords of Shadow 2, then make this game Lords of Shadow 3.  My biggest complaint about the story is how they treated Victor Belmont.  I assume he's suppose to be Richter, but given that you meet him and 20 minutes later he sacrifices himself, I'm glad he's not Richter.  Really wish there was more of him in the game.Environments in the present day segments are pretty dull.  No real variations in it, just greyed out industrial areas.  The other parts of the set Castlevania's past feel alive.  Definitely feels like the devs had fun making those areas.  Enemy designs also don't feel very varied either.  Boss design is on point though aside from the final boss.  *SPOILER WARNING* Final boss is Satan inside Alucard's body.  I was hoping for something a little more unique.  And since you only see Alucard for the last little section of the game (though technically he is there for the entire game disguised as the Zobek's second in command) it's disappointing that he's only there for that last little bit.Speaking of Alucard.  his DLC is solid too.  It has actual cinemas unlike how the DLC for LoS1 was handled.  He doesn't have new weapons for the magic modes, but the DLC is just long enough you don't notice it.  The only disappointing thing about the DLC is Alucard doesn't have any attacks for his Bat Swarm or Spectral Wolf abilities in combat or with magic.  Would've been a nice touch.  Oh yeah, the actor that plays Rob Stark from Game of Thrones does his voice if you're wondering why he sounds familiar.

number of helpful: 14 of 27 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Where do I start?The goal here was to improve upon on a good game that many claimed to be a "God of War" clone. Which it had similarities, sure, but to call it a clone is blasphemous. In fact, it possessed many qualities that made it superior even. The story, and acting was much better, for instance. The original had so many things going for it, and I for one, thought the fixed camera really showed you how beautiful the environments were. Lush forests, large abandoned temples, etc. Those things are replaced by castle, and rainy, dark alleyways. Not much variety there.The gameplay itself suffers from the new and 'improved' camera system. I feel like the fixed camera was done away with because we're sitting here saying to ourselves "It's 2014, we're past this. Resident Evil was frustrating." The truth is, it functioned very well in LOS, and you didn't have to fight that while also fighting swarms of enemies. That's the real issue with the new camera. You have a very claustrophobic point-of-view, and can't admire the environment even if it was really a sight to behold.  In fights, it backs out a little, but sometimes getting caught in an awkward corner and trying to manuever the camera while unleashing a planned combo at the time is not very fun. It turns making a well-timed block into a "I can't see if the enemy is attacking" kind of fight.The other issue is the story. The ending of LOS set the bar very high for this game, which is a little unfair, admittedly. I do feel like the game lost some punch in its delivery when it canned the narration from Patrick Stewart. And sometimes during the cutscenes, it doesn't feel like the acting is very into it. Very subdued, and uninspired.I could say more, but I can barely stomach the amount of time I've put into this game as it is.In shorter terms; Every area where LOS2 planned to improve upon its predecessor, it instead falls flat on its face.

number of helpful: 44 of 87 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												I wanted to love this game. I really did. Don't buy it unless you have a morbid curiousity to see what happened after the very entertaining first game. If you haven't played the first, go buy that instead.The first Lords of Shadow was an unexpected surprise for me, with gorgeous art and a fairly well told story backed up by solid action. Combined with a ridiculous twist and cliffhanger at the end, I was pretty excited to see where MercurySteam took the series next. On paper, it sounds pretty good. Expand the combat systems from the original game, continue the story, and place it in an open, Symphony of the Night style world that favors exploration.Then they went and cocked it all up. The action is barely distinguishable from the first, despite the huge change in character. You now have subweapons, but they are essentially palette swaps of the default whip with the properties of either the light or dark magic from the first game.The story is hilariously badly written, and at times borders on nonsensical. Character motivations frequently are completely impenetrable and illogical, and the ending of the game provides very little closure. The first thing that you see when the credits roll is that one man 'wrote and directed' the game. If I were him, I certainly wouldn't take credit for this wet fart of a story for fear of the death of my career.Classic metroidvania backtracking and openness is a great idea, but the biggest problem is that the map system is absolutely not up to the task. Modern metroidvanias like Shadow Complex frequently combine the classic 'grid' style map with indicators of an item that you have seen but were not able to access. LoS2 has a woefully inadequate 'world map' that is simply the names of different areas with the number of secrets you have yet to access. With all the shortcuts, twists and exits in each area, neither the world map or the local map (that basically confines its view to the loaded in level chunk with no indication of where exits go) is sufficient to make hunting for upgrades anything but a chore.And then there are the infamous stealth sections. God, the stealth sections. I'm typically against the death penalty, but whoever added those to the design doc needs to be publically executed. I want to watch. There are apologists for them, saying that they're 'more of a puzzle' than a stealth section. That may be true, but they're still a really ♥♥♥♥♥♥, inconsistant puzzle, using mechanics that do not smoothly integrate into the game. If you thought the 'boat stealth' sections from ACIV were the worst in recent memory, boy do I have a surprise for you.Alright, I've got that out of my system. Don't buy this for 60 bucks. Please don't.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Lords of Shadow 2 continues where Lords of Shadow left off, almost literally, with an aged Dracula awakening during modern times, weakened and missing his memories from the past thousand years or so. Soon, Zobek comes to Dracula and informs him that Satan is preparing to return. Zobek offers Dracula eternal rest in return for destroying Satan’s acolytes, thus preventing Satan return. With the two coming to an agreement, Dracula sets out to recover his full power and prevent the return of Satan.As one of its strongest aspects, Lords of Shadow 2 expands on the excellent combat system from the original Lords of Shadow. Many of Dracula’s combat moves are very similar to those used in LoS, this time with a vampiric twist. Instead of the Combat Cross Dracula wields whips made from his own demonic blood. Instead of the light and chaos magic from the first game, Dracula has the Void Sword and Chaos Claws. The Void Sword can restore Dracula’s health with each successive hit, while the Chaos Claws increase the Dracula’s combat strength. Similar to the magic system from LoS, both the Void Sword and the Chaos Cross have their own pool of magic which can be restored by chaining combos, which drops magic orbs.Chaining combos is not as easy as it sounds however, as even the weakest enemies have ranged attacks, as well as strong unblockable attacks. Thankfully, Dracula’s dodge and parry will mostly keep the player safe as long as they are mindful of enemy patterns. Lords of Shadow 2, like Lords of Shadow before it, shows the player no mercy when they fail to dodge or parry an attack. In fact, even with some of the weakest enemies, a failed dodge can mean getting hit by a string of unblockable attacks until the enemies combos are over. This can lead to a somewhat abrupt death if the player does not manage to restore Dracula’s health immediately.Combat does feel more forgiving in Lords of Shadow 2 this time around, however. For one, checkpoints are more frequent and areas before large fights generally have an artifacts which allow Dracula to recharge his health and magic before heading into the fray. Helping to make things easier this time, secondary combat items such as daggers no longer require collection and instead recharge after a few seconds. There are also a host of consumable items in LoS2 that do everything from restore health and make attacks stronger to slow down time and give unlimited magic. These items make the difficulty curve in Lords of Shadow 2 feel more manageable, despite its sometimes unforgiving combat.Unfortunately, the game is not always about its fantastic combat system. Sometimes, the game slows to a crawl as Dracula is forced to use stealth to proceed. These segments see Dracula using some of his abilities such as possession, rat transformation, and bat swarm to progress. At first, the stealth segments make sense as Dracula is weak and needs to possess either scientists or cyborgs to progress. As Dracula recovers his powers however, it becomes unclear why he is forced to sneak about. Dracula can destroy one of Satan’s acolytes but is unfit to face a simple cyborg? It makes little sense.One particular stealth segment towards the middle of the game is particularly frustrating. Dracula is forced to sneak about a maze full of dry leaves as a boss actively hunts for him. If the boss hears Dracula step on the leaves, the boss finds Dracula and forces him back to the start of the maze, taking a portion of the player’s health. This is made worse by the boss actively pursuing Dracula regardless of the noise made, sending Dracula back to the start if he simply comes into line of sight. The segment is made all the more insulting since Dracula and the said boss fight almost immediately following the maze. What was the point of the maze at all? Why did Dracula run if he could simply stand and fight?Some of the frustrations involved with Lords of Shadows 2 also stem from what should have been its greatest strength: the open world. Without spoiling too much, the game basically revolved around two semi-open worlds: the city and Dracula’s castle. The game looks beautiful and the levels are mostly well designed, but the navigation map struggles to keep up. Sometimes the player is left with nothing more than a vague arrow pointing somewhere off-screen. I found myself several times wandering in circles only to discover a small ledge I strained to see or a far off switch I was supposed to hit with a dagger. These moments can be frustrating, and may be played off as exploration/puzzles but mostly just feel like poor design.In regards to puzzles, LoS2 is a little bit disappointing. While the volume of puzzles seems to have increased significantly from the previous entries, the quality seems to have gone down. Most of the puzzles boil down to pull this switch/use that power. Rarely do the puzzles reach the height of those in the original Lords of Shadow, if at all.That’s not to say the game doesn’t have its inspired moments though. Part way into the game, Dracula unlocks optional arena style challenges where the player can put Dracula’s powers to the test. These can be a lot of fun and test the player’s skill by doing such things as banning the use of a specific power or setting a time limit to kill enemies.There are also moments where the game shines creatively such as a first person feeding segment, some clever sliding puzzles, and an interactive play. Equally enjoyable are several segments in the game where Dracula fights with a companion at his side. Dracula may be required to work with his companion to platform past obstacles or to solve puzzles, which really feels great. These moments are too few and far between, unfortunately.On the more positive end of things, the boss fights in Lords of Shadow 2 are actually an improvement on Lords of Shadow and seems to take a page from Mirror of Fate. The fights feel more epic, with larger bosses, and fewer quick time events.  The QTE are mostly limited to escape animations but are sometimes used for boss finishers. Wisely, Mercury Stream has provided checkpoints before boss finishers which makes the QTE less frustrating. Wiser still, you can turn off QTE entirely if you so choose. With boss fights less reliant on QTE, the game flows a lot better, and it gives the player more of a sense of involvement during boss fights.As someone who actually enjoys the Lords of Shadow universe, I felt slightly let down by its supposed conclusion. While the ending was satisfying enough, it felt a bit abrupt and unexpected. The story also pays almost no attention to the events of Lords of Shadow, only vaguely referring to the game’s events. Instead, the game focuses more on events from Mirror of Fate. This combined with the sudden demise of some key characters and a lack of explanation regarding how the player comes to arrive at Dracula’s castle, make the story feel unrealized at times. This is further compounded by an ending that doesn’t necessarily feel appropriate for the series, especially given the general direction of the entire game’s story and portrayal of Dracula throughout.As the player progresses through Lords of Shadow 2, they see Dracula coming to terms with the monster that he has become - how becoming Dracula has affected him, his family, and the world around him. Unfortunately, that character progression just doesn’t live up to the ultimate ending, leaving loose ends right at the moment that it seemed everything was going to be tied up.Overall, Lords of Shadow 2 was an enjoyable experience despite some questionable gameplay additions and a lackluster ending. There’s a lot of content to Lords of Shadow 2 and a lot of fun to be had, including a New Game+ mode. Hopefully the upcoming Alucard DLC just ties up some of the loose ends that LoS2 left unraveled.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												It's games like this that really make me wish Steam has 3 recommendation buttons: thumbs up / thumbs down / apathetic shrug. Because LOS 2 is far from the great game the first one was, but also isn't totally crap - I'd say it's about 60/40 on the quality divide.If you played LOS 1 you'll recall it finished with a gob smacking reveal - that had me extremely curious as to how the developers would follow up on this audacious twist. As it turns out - not particularly well. It's a beat em up platformer just like the first, but in this case the camera is moveable - which makes a big, and unwelcome, difference as it is slightly too far out to see the action, and also gets obscured by the ridiculous amount of special effects that happen with EVERY attack.The game begins back in ye olde days with Dracula's castle being attacked by a giant robot that looks like a building. At first I was like WTF  is that?? because it looks utterly stupid - until I remembered the Titans from LOS 1: those majestic towering elemental creatures that were so impressive. Well, this is one of those - except it's been put through the moronometer, and come out with totally dumb design. Technically impressive for sure, but so NOT Castlevania!If you hated the liberties the first game took with the series design - you'll be frothing at the mouth over this one....and I'd probably best not mention it gets even worse when the game jumps back to the present day, because those bits will  likely cause your brain to explode in disgust. They annoyed me, and I wasn't bothered by LOS 1's changes. In the modern day bits you begin by traipsing through a pharmaceutical warehouse, beating up crates and plastic barrels - but not the enemies because you are too weedy after starving yourself of blood for hundreds of years. Yet there's a cutscene where Dracula gleefully murders a family of three - kid included - to regain some of his strength, and to show you how EVIL he has become...err, okay ...not really selling it so far (mainly due to Robert Carlylse's utterly♥♥♥♥♥♥performance), but whatevs!Anyway, because you've become a total wimp  the first enemies you face have an enforced stealth aspect, which is pretty basic - and by the way, said enemies are big dudes in demonic armour with a gun bigger than you are.......Wot tha fudge?Eventually you get through these dull encounters, and get sucked back into ye olde times - which thankfully are (a) much more enjoyable, and (b) less crap stylistically, though the first boss you face in this world isn't the greatest to look at. Duff them up, explore a bit more, and then...it's back to the crappy warehouse, traipse thru that some more, and it's back to ye olde world. The games a YOYO!!! Ye olde world =good, modern day=big bag'o'shitoBack in yon days of lore there's a bit with these creepy snake headed girls that's very....creepy, as they skitter about, and contort themselves in a fashion that really won't be doing their spine any favours. They're genuinely disturbing, yet at the same time it's such a pity the whole game seems incapable of maintaining the menace they exude. The boss battle that precedes this bit has an awfully written cutscene, that's very japanese (even though the devs are spanish...) With an overtly sexual demonic villainess who laughs like a demented walrus, and then says you make her wet....yeeeessss, ok then. The bizarrest thing about all this - the first game had Hideo Kojima involved and wasn't this bad, this time around he was nowhere near this game and it's even more Hideo Kojimaesque than Hideo Kojima. And, well, that's as far as I've got so far : that's an awful lot of crappy aspects for the first 3 or 4 hours of a game. There's still some enjoyment to be had with it, but it's a shadow of LOS's greatness and a horrendous treatment of Castlevania.On the plus side - Patrick Stewart is much less awful this time around, so there's that. So, here goes - time to push the 'meh' recommend button, oh wait - there isn't one.
