content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												As much as I would like to, I cannot recommend "Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2". OK, yes - fighting is perfectlty fine. Especially since devs dropped the fixed camera. But everything else? Not so much. It's like devs tought "We have a good fighting that we improved with working camera. Lets call it a day, just fit anything as the rest. Who cares anyway - it's the beating that matters". And  so we have booooooooring plot, told in Fast Forward mode (even faster than in previous part). With some sort of poor stealth sections instead of puzzles. And of course there are still platforming elements but just as in part 1 - you have to be deliberatly sabotaging yourself to fail them. And the visuals... Castle part is ok. Really. But the City?! Jesus, it's supposed to be somewhere around year 2000. So why dafuq everything that can tries to look like World War I thing?! The things that cannot are just plainand simple putting fantasy stuff in early XX's cetury seting, Which never looks good. I know, I know - we all want to be unique and original. But that doesn't mean we have to be ugly or do ugly things. And - last but not least - technicals. The game does not recognize controllers other than Xbox's. You are very limited at keybinding (for example, the game does not recognise mouse side buttons). And autosave feature is f***** up - which means that you will see info about "autoseve issues" which is a kind way of saying "Next time you start the game, we will ask you to do it from the begging" cause you cant save on youir own. So make sure you kep somwhere copies of your autosaves.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												I loved the hell out of the first Lords of Shadow, and I enjoyed this game as well. However, it's not without its share of problems.First and foremost, there's the setting. I didn't mind the fact that a significant portion of the game was set in the near future, but the open nature of the environments (both the castle and the city) seemed to sap the creative element from their design. Yes, it's cool that all of it links together, but that feeling of exploring strange new landscapes with all their weird quirks has been completely sacrificed. I get that it works with the plot, but I feel like the game would have benefited from having a level structure like the first.Speaking of plot, there's the second problem. The story in LoS2 doesn't stack up to the first game at all, opting to go with a campier plot more reminscent of other Castlevania games than the original Lords of Shadow. While this isn't inherently a bad thing (I love Castlevania as a series, cheese and all), there's a massive plot hole introduced at the beginning of the game that is never resolved. Dracula was defeated at the end of Mirror of Fate, but apparently rose up again at some point between that game and this one. This is entirely glossed over in the main narrative and only offhandedly mentioned in Alucard's lore entry. I might be expecting too much out of the story of a Castlevania game, but it bothers me nonetheless given the detail and work put into the first game.Then there's the stealth sections. Oh god, the stealth sections. For the most part it's not too bad; there is one enemy type that requires you to go around instead of confronting directly. These sections are mostly just mild hiccups in the pacing (which also isn't quite as good as the first game), but the final one is absolutely one of the worst segments I've had the displeasure of playing through. Not only is this segment immensly frustrating, but you battle the thing you were sneaking around immediately afterwards; no new weapon, no new powers, no upgrades whatsoever. You just fight it straight away, essentially rendering all the work you just did completely pointless.Fortunately, it's not all bad. The combat is a ton of fun, giving you three different weapons with distinct features and fighting styles. It also looks fantastic; though I disparaged the nature of the new environments earlier, I can't deny the level of detail put into the city and Dracula's castle. The creatures and characters all look great too, from the detailed facial animations of the humanoids to Satan's grotesque abominations. Voice acting is solid; the actors did a good job delivering the lukewarm script in a believable way.All in all, Lords of Shadow 2 is a solid action game with a few flaws. Go into it expecting more of a Devil May Cry experience than a Lords of Shadow 1 experience and I think you'll be able to derive more enjoyment from it that way.

Posted: December 14, 2014
												Allow me to add to the chorus that says "The Metacritic Score is a lie."This was a good game. Though it differs from the first. It is by that measure that I think its best compared.+Graphical Presentation+The first game had your character crossing an elaborate, Lord of the Rings like world with plenty of variety and set pieces. It was absolutely beautiful.None of that beauty comes close to be realized here. Instead, what you get is an atmosphere......THAT ACTUALLY FEELS LIKE CASTLEVANIA!There are many reviewers who will cry at the fact that the last game was prettier, but here, you are in a dark, moody castle with full control of your camera and dammit I just couldn't help but love how it actually felt like you were involved in a dark tale of vampires and demons, unlike the first. So between this and the first, its an apples to oranges comparision. In the end, the graphical presentation gives you that SoTN feel that the first game was missing (the sexy mountaintops of LoS1 be darned).+Story (Spoiler Free)+The first game was about losing faith. The second game is about redemption. Obviously. What else is new? What's important here is characterization and voice acting delivery. To which it does an absolutely fantastic job of delivering. Though, in my view, its story is not as heavy as the first, given that every single chapter in LoS1 had Captain Picarde himself explaining what the heck is going on in detail. We really could've used that narration to explain some of the strange stuff having in this castle-city. Like what the heck is a castle doing here in the first place? That was a head-trip, but hey, its Dracula; his castle be constantly respawning I guess.So here's what I recommend you do before jumping in here: 1) Play the first game first (or read its cliff-notes). 2) Play Mirror of Fate (or read its cliff-notes) . They frequently make references to the first game and the hand-held tie-in so if you skip these steps then expect a confusing plot. Given that I didn't skip these steps, I found LoS2 to make for a pretty good story. Certainly has more heart than most games these days. It's like a DMC that you can take seriously.+Gameplay+Here is the one place where I can say without a doubt that it delivers better than the first game. You see, LoS2 is easier than the first, for all the RIGHT reasons.The first had some Nintendo-hard bulls*** issues holding it back that have been fixed. For one, you have more options given the three weapons to choose from. The lame Light and Dark Magic system is replaced by an Ice Weapon and Fire Weapon.  In the first game, you only switched to Light to heal on occasion and that was it, as you were constantly struggling to fill up the focus meter to fuel your heals. Dark magic was never used. It was nothing more than an unimportant DPS buff. Here, the replacements to the old magic honestly feels different enough for you to want to mix it up, what with the fire ability being able to break enemy shields and blocking (in addition to doing more DPS), and the ice sword having some mean crowd control abilities (in addition to healing you). Filling up the focus meter is much faster and easier so you can continue to fuel these things without fear, and with the camera in your control, you just won't feel as frustrated as before.The side items and powers are must more useful as well, and a power you get later on adds a whole new dimension to to your defensive options. Overall, I'd say LoS1 comes no where CLOSE to being a steller action game in the gameplay department. It was servicable and that was it. Here, we actually have a system that's as fun as God of War.  YOU FEEL LIKE YOU'RE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ DRACULA, AND NO ONE CAN F*** WITH YOU! You ARE the final boss of over 30 games, and nothing can stop you, only slow you down.Hell yeah. About the only thing relatively weak are the stealth sections, which make sense only at the start of the game...how is it that you're a threat to Satan, but these red guys can blow your♥♥♥♥♥away doing 9999 damage per shot? I need Captain Picarde to explain. Fortunately, such sections are mercifully short and easy.There are also fewer puzzles than the first game. But who cares?+Overall+Overall I give this game a 7.9/10. Its not the greatest thing since Bayonetta but taken as a whole, the Lord of Shadows series offers the best story in the action game genre today...taken as a whole.  View Lord of Shadows 1 and 2 as one really long epic and you're pretty much doing it right. When the dust clears, you'll likely give this game a worthy playthrough on New Game + and have fun with it as well.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												If you expect this game to be of the same caliber as the sublime Lords of Shadow, prepare for bitterest disappointment.  While the fighting is responsive and the PC optimization is excellent, too much of the game is a mess.The levels, in layout and aesthetic, are by and large atrocious; the magnificent fantasy forests and brooding, vine-choked ruins of the first game have been exchanged for tedious near-future cityscape where 90-degree angles dominate (nice attempt at camouflage with those pretty textures, Mercury Steam, but they can only go so far).   There are a few brief, beautiful segments that take place within Dracula's "inner castle," but these are over too soon and serve to highlight the dull ugliness of the metropolis, which is confusing, repetitive and filled to the boxy margins with generic, endlessly respawning T-Virus monsters.  Yes, you spend most of the game battling urbanites transformed into Biohazard C-stringers by a Satanic biological agent, and they are a dull lot indeed.  The worst gameplay sections of all are the stealth bits.  In these, Dracula, who is supposed to be the baddest damn thing in the world, Dracula, who demolishes building-sized gorgons, Dracula, who ultimately succeeds in deep sixing Satan himself, must hide from cyborg guards with plasma rifles who are able to one-shot him on sight!  Aside from making absolutely no sense in terms of the game world, these bitter bits of Metal Gear lite are distinctly unfun.  Hell, you don't even get to kill one of the damn things!  The bad guys should have just sent an army of these cyborg guys after Dracula, thus ensuring the Devil's terrestrial reign forever.The storytelling in Lords of Shadow 2, like everything else in it, seems patchy and incomplete.  In concept, it was a great idea (you'll see this if you stick it through to the end), but the execution is completely slapdash, leaving even some of the most important plot points, particularly the seemingly transdimensional status of Dracula's castle, unexplained.  Most of the time, you'll be unsure of why you are doing what you are doing.Despite all, I recommend this -- but only for the price of ten or fewer U.S. dollars, and only if the shockingly fun DLC, Revelations, is included.  Surprised?  Well, as I said, the story isn't bad, it's just badly told for the most part; if you are fan of the first Lords of Shadow, you'll want to the experience the unexpectedly cool ending of LOS2.  Also, most of the boss fights are pretty damned great, particularly the epic final battle!    Lords of Shadow 2 is a poor Lords of Shadow game and kind of a bad Castlevania game, but it's not really a bad game, just a mediocre one with a few redeeming bright spots.  By all means, give it a whirl when it's on sale.

Posted: September 23, 2014
												This new Castlevania series just isn't for everyone.Personally I loved it.  The first game ended on an interesting note and the LoS2 picks up right at that point.A game controller is recommended.Many people didn't like the stealth segments, but they're really brief and play out more like simple puzzles with minimal punishment for mistakes.Pros: Great PC Port: Rendering / Performance and Framerate were fantastic.  No bugs encountered. The Intro (First 15 minutes) were outstanding. Excellent boss fights, one of which has become one of my favorites in the Castlevania series. Crisp, Responsive Combat system.  Nice animations. Great Soundtrack The Intro and Middle-section of the game are excellent along with the "Revelations DLC"Cons:*spoilers* All 3 weapons do share the same special moves upgrades which does make them a bit less unique. If you don't like the Xbox 360 Controller you may need a modification in order to use your preferred controller. The Ending was both abrupt and lacking but apparently Konami asked Mercury Steam to keep the ending open so that they could continue the series[/list]

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is the latest in the Castlevania franchise. This title is a hack and slash action oriented game that is not for the faint of heart. Those who dislike blood and gore are likely to turn away from this game, however those who like blood guts and gore can go nuts. Fans of Castlevania will appreciate this game to a point, however those new to the series may find things a little confusing.For starters, the control system in the game is very fluid for the most part. Abilities can be used at will depending on the situation at hand. Swapping between the 3 weapons you get in the game is very smooth, switching from one to the other and back again at the touch of a button while keeping a combo going. The combat in general is smooth, however there are minor things that can be very disheartening for newer players. Unblockable attacks can be overlooked given the amount of things going on in a heated battle at times. For example, fights with a lot of dirt, rubble, blood and enemies flying everywhere can sometimes (not always) block your view from unblockable attacks meaning you are going to get hit. And in a life or death situation this is very annoying.The difficulty of the game varies between 4 difficulties, 3 of which are available from the outset. The 4th difficulty is unlocked by beating the game once. A veteran of games from series like Devil May Cry will not find the initial "hard mode" all that difficult. While it can be a challenge at times managing the players health and resources on hard, it isn't deathly hard. For newer players the easy and normal difficulties can provide their own challenge, but all in all things are very much dumbed down for ease of play.Graphically, this game is incredible. The HD textures make everything within the environments stand out. From the tiniest pebble on the ground to the largest building in the distance, the developers have not skimped on anything. The whole game looks amazing from start to finish. The addition of several hundred pieces of concept art makes the whole look of things even better. The animations for every enemy, and every npc are very fuild, very good at depicting a certain realism about things.The music in this game is also once again incredible with a few minor exceptions. Certain cutscenes have music that just doesn't fit at all. No emotion is felt from the music, no meaning. However that is just a few places. For the most part the music, and sounds in general are very well placed, very well composed and very well done overall. Voice acting is quite good, at times it's a bit questionable however again for the most part it fits, and is very well done by the actors including Robert Carlyle and Patrick Stewart.Now. The major gripe I have with this game is the lack of direction throughout a lot of the games "open world" sections. Your minimap shows you the general direction on where to go, but a lot of the time you can spend a fair amount of time searching for the way to go. This could be a ledge to grapple, or a wall to walk around. For the most part things are easy to spot, but there were several times where I had to look around the area, after backtracking and re-entering the room just to find where to go next.To conclude, I would give this game 8/10. It is a good solid game, well built and with a lot of nice features and well crafted gameplay. If you like hack and slash adventure games then this is a definite pick-up. 15 hours of solid gameplay minimum, well over 20 with NG+ and challenges, as well as the concept art collection. Those who know the Castlevania games of old may frown upon its story, but give it a shot and you'll like it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												This review is written after having played almost three hours of gameplay with intent to play more. It's also important to note that this is written from the point of view of someone who has not played any of the Castlevania's before Lord of Shadow (The first one.)Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 thrusts you into the role of Gabriel Belmont (otherwise known as Dracula) who is disturbed from his centuries of rest to once again battle Satan. The game stands well on it's own and I feel like someone who hasn't played the first game can still pick up this one and not be confused as to what is going on. However, I also feel like if someone were to have played the first one they will enjoy the story a lot more than if they didn't. (This is easily remedied by reading a wikipedia summary or watching the cutscenes of the first game on youtube.)The gameplay is reminiscent of Devil May Cry, Ninja Gaiden and other stylish action fighters. You do combos against multiple enemies and emphasis is placed on avoiding attacks to survive. Even the normal mode feels difficult because there is just so much going on and it's easy to lose track of enemies that end up behind you. However, the combos you can upgrade into feel almost pointless when you can just mash your single target attack, dodge and come out victorious. However, it also does some things good by giving your weapons meaning. The Void Blade restores health through attacks and the Chaos claws deal extra damage to enemies. Dodging attacks is essential because in order to use these weapons you need to build up a combo meter which allows "blood orbs" to appear which gives power to the weapons.Where Castlevania: LoS2 sets itself apart from Devil May Cry and Ninja Gaiden is in the platforming sections. With Devil May cry you time a bunch of jumps and with Ninja Gaiden you run across rooftops. With Castlevania it manages to execute a good platforming experience reminiscent of games like Prince of Persia. You'll scale up walls while under siege by enemies, time perfect jumps and use your abilities to reach hidden spots to power up Dracula.I also think it's worthwhile to note that if you dislike Quick Time Events(QTE), there is an option to disable QTE's in the game menu. This is a huge step forward as a lot of gamers moan and gripe about having to "Press X to not die" and I hope to see this option more in the future in other games.Overall, if you liked Ninja Gaiden or Devil May Cry you'll find a similarly enjoyable experience in Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Muito Bom!!!!- Excelentes graficos, principalmente se seu computador aguenta rodar tudo no max com o pacote de texturas em HD- Sistema simples e fácil de combos com evolução intuitiva de habilidades e magias- Ambientação simplesmente arrasadora, principalmente nas partes antigas. As partes modernas ficaram boas mas Clastlevania é um jogo que precisa te levar ao passado com suas construçoes em pedra e com uma ambientação escura e sinistra- Ele é longo, de uma forma positiva e diferente do primeiro, não é como se o jogo te enrrolasse para durar mais, mais ele tem fôlego para te prender realmente por muito tempo. Segundo alguns reviews que li pode chegar a 15h horas se você for rápido e 20h procurando todos os itens escondidos, ou seja, vale o seu dinheiro - A arte do jogo é linda com tantos detalhes que da ate pra se pegar olhando para o cenario sem se mexer, só admirar. - História mediana, mas na longa vida da saga já houveram bem piores - Se você jogou o primeiro e gostou, não se desapontará com essa bela continuação. Se você gosta de jogos de ação a la GOW você vai gostar. - Dois contras: Dificuldade fácil demais mesmo em níveis dificeis e inimigos menos carismaticos do que o jogo anterior

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												Castlevania LoS 2, takes everything that was in the first game, and makes it better. The light magic has been changed to cool sword (*heh pun), and shadow magic is replaced with fiery claws. The graphics are better and this time and you can control the camera. The combat system is also much better in this game than in LoS 1. Storytelling in LoS 2 is between mediocre and good, and I actually liked few of the "Forced references" there was in the game... WHAT IS A MAN?*  The only complaint I have about this game is the final boss, which was kinda boring and too easy even on hard difficulty. It was a cool final boss though. come on, it is Dracula VS Alucard... How cool is that?  <-OOPS, spoilers.The final boss in the first LoS is still better (but not as cool) though, as it had some interesting aspects to the fight.I'm currently on my second playthrough, this time on new even harder difficulty. I hope the final boss this time will be more interesting.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												I simply... can't stop playing this game. Near finishing it up, I've got to say Mercury really did an awesome job with LoS2. When they meant the game was going to be "open world", they weren't kidding; no map stage selection screen to revisit stages or whatever, you gotta backtrack either on foot, or through warps (map rooms) which, I admit it can be a bit tedious at times but, I don't mind (especially when you get to grind on enemies along the way). The story is great and we get to see a more human side of Dracula in comparison to the previous iterations before the reboot of the series. The contents to collect and search throughout the game is pretty vast (void/chaos/life crystals, kleidos nails, soldier/memorial scrolls, and other sub-weapon expansions). The skills and skill mastering system is also pretty deep (SO MANY MOVES YO! :V ). But enough about me gushing over this game! :D ENOUGH TALK, HAVE AT IT... and discover for yourself. :D

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												Lords of Shadow had wonderful graphics, great combat, spectacular boss fights, clever and interesting puzzles, brilliant art design with lush worlds and fun enemies, a heart felt story and a fine performance by Patrick Stewart.This? Has a fine (but small) performance by Patrick Stewart.Graphics? I think the first game looked better and I played that on 360. No support for resolutions above 1080p btw.Puzzles? Flip a switch, sometimes twice or turn into a rat and sneak by. I mean you're Dracula right? You can turn into a dragon and scorch the earth, Satan himself is afraid to leave the pits of hell to fight you...but you gotta sneak by these Golgath guards.Art design? Hope you like brown! And sewers! And empty bulidings! What is this, 2007?Enemies? Mechs and guys with guns. Because that's what you want in a Castlevania game, right?!Not to mention a terrible targeting system, sloppy platforming and some all around poor design including having to wander around for 5-10 minutes prior to the final mission.I played through all 20 hours of Ride to Hell Retribution and had more fun than this. There were 4 times towards the end of that game I considered quitting and not finishing it, this was at 4 times 7 hours in. Then it got worse. I somehow managed to finish it anyway.Game producer Enric Álvarez said of Edge's 4/10 review "one must be blind or stupid to give a 4/10 mark to a game with this quality" and he is correct. How this got anything above a 2/10 I'll never know.I do highly reccomend the original Lords of Shadow and Mirror of Fate but I'm quite sure this unseated Assassin's Creed III as worst game sequel.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Somehow this game is even LESS like Castlevania than Lords of Shadow 1.It's like Mercury Stream's objective was to cram in as many aspects from OTHER successful games as possible, hoping that by emulating them that they'd make a blockbuster. This game took a lot of chances by drastically distancing themselves from the traditional Castlevania formula and judging by the abysmal metacritic score, things didn't pan out for this game as the devs had hoped. Dracula endures stealth segments like metal gear solid and at times transforms into a rat to covertly delve into enemy ground, very much like the morph ball from Metroid Prime. Also instead of a level select book like in the prequel we now have a psuedo open world to explore, like SotN. Beating up enemies is a 1:1 conversion from the previous game and the rockclimbing simulation aspect was reigned in just slightly.I have a few gripes about this game. Though the overhead map in the corner ensured I'd not be lost for very long, I still managed to get stuck in several rooms scratching my head hoplessly trying to figure out what to do or pick up to continue. Eventually I'd stumble upon whichever asanine detail of the room I had missed in my multiple examinations.This game's biggest shortcoming is the plot. The writers had an outline of what they wanted to have the main character do and feel, and while they try to explain his motivation the game just feels full of holes.This game is like a delicious recipie with some fresh ingredients, but the chef forgot to stir the pot as it was cooking so now the meal separated. Rather than blend together into one satisfying experience we have competing facets of gameplay (flavors) that seem to detract from one another. I heard mercury stream had a lot of problems. Maybe if the people running the company paid their employees and stopped enforcing their asanine and uninspired ideas over the people who had experience making games then this game would have been better recieved. As it is only TWO people on my ~200 friend list have bought your game and BOTH dropped it more than halfway through. Despite all this game's shortcomings it has plenty to offer and overall I enjoyed playing it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												I loved "Lords of Shadow" and the intermediary sequel, "Mirror of Fate", but I heard a lot of bad news about this game before it came out on Steam. There was a letter from someone in the development team that talked about how the production was disjointed, some bad reviews, etc. There was no way I was going to pass on it though.The player returns again to the role of Gabriel Belmont, who is now Dracula. Following a tutorial level that takes place in his castle, the game is divided between two major environments, both of which are "free to explore". The first is the city of Castlevania in the 2040s or 2050s (mostly modern, but with some nice cyberpunk and gothic touches), while the other is Dracula's castle of antiquity (which has been destroyed in the modern day, but still exists as an extradimensional realm; I don't believe it is in Dracula's mind).Unlike the fixed camera angles of "Lords of Shadow", this game features a true 3rd person over-the-shoulder camera. It is well executed, and allows the player to really drink in the beautiful visuals that drip ambience. I personally preferred the castle to the modern levels, though.Combat still consists of basic attacks, combos, dodging, special weapons, and special powers. I have to admit that most of the fights were a bit dry for me. Most enemies require a single special tactic to defeat, and I frequently found myself looking for ways to bypass them (and there aren't enough ways in the game to do so). The designs are interesting, but fighting even common enemies frequently took as long as a boss fight; that was annoying.The boss battles are a lot of fun, mixing again a good amount of combat, quick-time elements, cinematics, and great music. Unfortunately the game suffers from boring boss battle environments; like the first game, it's usually just a sort of open arena (though the music, in my opinion, imparts the sense of swinging around to avoid attacks and other epic thoughts.)The voice acting and story are still excellent. Robert Carlyle and Patrick Stewart really have to carry most of it, and they do great jobs. The game takes some time to defeat, though all the events occur in a single night (this is undoubtedly longer for Gabriel/Dracula, since half of the game involves him traveling to his other-dimensional castle).The music in this game is AMAZING. It's probably my favorite video game score, and possibly my favorite of both video games and movies. To say that composer Óscar Araujo accomplished something amazing would be an understatement.Despite so many similarities, this game didn't feel the same as the first "Lords of Shadow", so I can't say this one is either better or worse. There are some weak points in the gameplay (such as some enemies that Dracula is NEVER able to defeat in combat, regardless of how powerful you become), but this is balanced by some truly amazing scenes as well (the train battle comes to mind).In some way it is more "Castlevania" than the first game, and less so in other ways.Ultimately, I would recommend highly it to Castlevania fans as well as fantasy action fans. It's a shame that this game will be the last in the series (to my understanding). Mercury Steam and the designers did a great job of creating a Castlevania series that represents Western concepts and artistic values over the Japanese anime style that the original games devolved into.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												According to Steam I've sunk 16.8 hours into this game from beginning to end, and two of that was on the last boss, because jeez, what a pain!If you were a fan of Lords Of Shadow 1 then the next entry should definitely satisfy your jonesing for another foray as Gabriel Belmont.  The story is decent, it's not an amazing articulate and in depth thriller, but it is serviceable for the game that it is, and honestly, as far as Castlevania games go, it is probably the best story.  (People really seem to love the 'plots' of Castlevania games without understanding that the story is generally pretty weak.)Gameplay-wise, big improvement over LoS1.  The camera isn't locked, the environments are open for fighting and the "background" doesn't obstruct the combat the way it did in LoS1.The platforming is guided, there aren't a lot of fall down and die challenges, if you can make a leap, you'll make a leap, and there's a lot less guesswork than there was in the first one since the camera now sits behind Gabriel not a mile away from him while you judge a gap.The pace does get disrupted in several moments with these bizarre stealth pieces that, as you approach the end of the game, will have you wondering how it is you still aren't powerful enough to sneak around enemies you should be able to kill.  If you've been playing about 45 minutes of combat, then expect to spend the next 45 dealing with sneaking.  There are a couple of scenes that will definitely test the frustration durability of your controller as well.The game allows backtracking, but it isn't as crucial as it was in LoS1.  I remember in LoS1 NEEDING to go back and get some more upgrades because combat was such a pain.  In this I tended to find enough health upgrades, power upgrades etc. along the way if I kept my eyes open for side passes, that I did not backtrack at all.I didn't backtrack because it is a giant pain in the♥♥♥♥♥  The environments are HUGE, there is a quick travel system but it goes to like 4 waypoints in massive areas in the city or in the castle, so it doesn't exactly put you right where you want to be.  I thought about it said "nope" and never backtracked, aside from hitting up a shop.You may also get locked into certain fights and you can't back out of them to go back and farm health potions, so you're screwed.  Let's just say I spent so long fighting the last boss starting with a shred of health and zero void sword power that I had to learn how to fight and counter him effectively.  I'm probably pretty much unbeatable now thanks to my own lack of preparation going in to the end game.Despite some of the flaws, fun game.So...Get this if:You love the atmosphere / plot of the Castlevania games and aren't so linear in your thinking that "ZOMGZ ITS NOT CASTLEVANIA IF ITS NOT 2D!"  Or if you were ever a fan of the Legacy of Kain games, because there hasn't been a better "bad♥♥♥♥♥vampire platformer" since the last ones of those were made.Avoid it if: You need complicated platforming, not the hand holding kind, or if you're the kind of person who will put a game down if the pace of it gets disrupted.  Because this game definitely upsets its own pace several times during a playthrough, and then it just sits on your computer never getting played.When in doubt:Steam sale!

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I have been a fan of the Castlevania Saga since its very early days on the nintendo consoles. Seeing the first LoS on my gaming rig made me salivate and I was not disappointed. Awesome storyline, great voice acting and a perfect mixture of puzzles and action bathing in a dark graphical and musical atmosphere.Now here comes LoS2 and I was ready to sharpen my holy swiss army cross against a legion of blood suckers again... which... you don't get to do per se. Now, don't get me wrong, I wasn't upset about the choice of having to play as Dracula. I wasn't bothered by the rather mind boggling flashbacks and choices for his resurrection. What DID make me quite mad, was the lack of consistency of the story compared to the prior game. Plot holes scattered all over, questions about some enemies which remain unanswered (you know, those mechanical ones...). Quite honestly, by trying to give you more freedom by opening up the "world" and let you travel back and forth to reach secrets you could not get before acquiring specific powers, the developers actually have damaged the game rather than improving it. I found myself running around like a vampire on the beach at noon all over the place to end up at random places for not much more than a couple of XP. Rather disappointing.But frankly, the game gets better the more you play it and old Fangs gets his powers back to kick to serious booty. Puzzles, action, frantic action, lots of blood and body parts flying around. Seriously entertaining. And the end is satisfying.Overall, it's a notch down compared to LoS, but not a complete disaster. Much could have been done to make it more engaging and gripping if the story had been more consistent. But aside from that, I'd say that I would recommend this game nonetheless, especially on sale. It's good. Not jaw dropping awesome but solid.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												This review is written after having played almost three hours of gameplay with intent to play more. It's also important to note that this is written from the point of view of someone who has not played any of the Castlevania's before Lord of Shadow (The first one.)Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 thrusts you into the role of Gabriel Belmont (otherwise known as Dracula) who is disturbed from his centuries of rest to once again battle Satan. The game stands well on it's own and I feel like someone who hasn't played the first game can still pick up this one and not be confused as to what is going on. However, I also feel like if someone were to have played the first one they will enjoy the story a lot more than if they didn't. (This is easily remedied by reading a wikipedia summary or watching the cutscenes of the first game on youtube.)The gameplay is reminiscent of Devil May Cry, Ninja Gaiden and other stylish action fighters. You do combos against multiple enemies and emphasis is placed on avoiding attacks to survive. Even the normal mode feels difficult because there is just so much going on and it's easy to lose track of enemies that end up behind you. However, the combos you can upgrade into feel almost pointless when you can just mash your single target attack, dodge and come out victorious. However, it also does some things good by giving your weapons meaning. The Void Blade restores health through attacks and the Chaos claws deal extra damage to enemies. Dodging attacks is essential because in order to use these weapons you need to build up a combo meter which allows "blood orbs" to appear which gives power to the weapons.Where Castlevania: LoS2 sets itself apart from Devil May Cry and Ninja Gaiden is in the platforming sections. With Devil May cry you time a bunch of jumps and with Ninja Gaiden you run across rooftops. With Castlevania it manages to execute a good platforming experience reminiscent of games like Prince of Persia. You'll scale up walls while under siege by enemies, time perfect jumps and use your abilities to reach hidden spots to power up Dracula.I also think it's worthwhile to note that if you dislike Quick Time Events(QTE), there is an option to disable QTE's in the game menu. This is a huge step forward as a lot of gamers moan and gripe about having to "Press X to not die" and I hope to see this option more in the future in other games.Overall, if you liked Ninja Gaiden or Devil May Cry you'll find a similarly enjoyable experience in Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												After a little more than 15 hours of a rather painful experience, I've finally managed to plough through the boredom, frustration and dismay, feeling a great and lasting sadness when the credits finally rolled over, putting an end the whole agony.A calamitous art direction:  Bland and repetitive backdrops (sewers, laboratory, castle, then more sewers), poor choice of a de-saturated almost monochromatic color palette (everything seems to be just another variation of grey), botched facial 3D renders (the characters' faces look like plastic with absolutely no emotional range, Dracula's face is particularly bad and almost laughable), uninspired character design (Nergal is just some random bald dude and Satan looks like a gym bro on steroids).Incoherent game design:  Ridiculous mandatory and aggravating stealth (the 'Agreus' sequence is already famous all across internet, and that's not even talking about Dracula being forced to transform into a rat to avoid security guards that are stronger than Satan), exploration ruined by a archaic game structure and sub-par plat-forming (the wolf game mechanic breaks the rhythm and the climbing is either unclear or too easy with the pointers).Mediocre sound design:  The only thing worth listening to is Dracula's theme at the title screen and a couple of action themes during the prologue, the rest being forgettable (compared to the first Lords of Shadow, this is a major let down), and the voice actors seem to be reading their lines more than they are giving it any kind of emotional depth (Robert Carlyle, Patrick Stewart and Richard Madden, shame on you ! You guys were so much better in previous games !).A decent plot, completely destroyed by the worst appalling ending I've ever witnessed in a triple A game.  The story is actually interesting if you've completed both the first Lords of Shadow and Mirror of Fate (otherwise, don't even bother), but the grand finale and the game's ending is so embarrassingly insulting, it's actually a league of its own. Combat mechanics are half-way decent, since it's basically a dumbed-down version of the first game (the game is much easier, thanks to a larger Synchronized Block window and an overpowered evade move, which knocks down and interrupts enemies), but let's not delude ourselves any longer and call this game what it is: shameful.Objectively, it's not the worst piece of gaming♥♥♥♥♥♥this century, but unfortunately the first Lords of Shadow which was published 3 years before this sequel, is just way better in every possible way (yes, even the fixed camera which actually provided some cinematic flair).  As a fan of the first Lords of Shadow and having always argued about Mirror of Fate's qualities (still waiting for it on Steam), Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 has been such a disappointment it has made me depressed, disgusted and hateful.  And I don't play video games to be depressed, disgusted and hateful.  You have been warned.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												I'm only 3 hours into the game, but so far I have enjoyed it.  Feels very God-of-War like, which isn't necessarily a bad thing.  Combat is fun although there's not much here that hasn't been done before.  Combat skill trees are present.  Exploration is fun as well despite not being truly open world, it's still fun to find hidden secrets.  They bring back staple items like the hourglass that can slow enemies' movements, etc.  That along with destructible things like candlesticks that hide experience points or other goodies keeps it feeling like Castlevania.  Not sure about the modern setting, but most of the environments don't reflect a modern look anyway, it still looks like dilapidated castles, etc. for the most part.The graphics are not fantastic, particularly in the distance some of the meshes have very jagged outlines, even with settings maxed.  The lighting/shadows in cut scenes can also be pretty distracting.  Much has been made about the stealth aspect of the game, but I didn't find it overwhelmingly unpleasant, although it did make me itch to get back into the combat and exploration where the game shines.  Ultimately I'm glad I bought the game

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												What a botched sequel this truly is. I loved Lords of Shadow. It had some issues, but was incredibly enjoyable, from the variety of settings to the classic monsters Gabriel did battle with. I'd read that this one was very slow to get going, but that once it did, it was solid. That disappointed me in and of itself, but it also made me wait for a sale to buy it. Finally a good one came along, and I bought the game, looking forward to get back into the world and see what had become of Gabriel since we'd last met. Because I'd read the reviews already, I was willing to sludge through the awful stealth sections where you have to turn into a rat to accomplish a variety of goals. And yes, they were terrible. But what was also very annoying was a constant sense of "where do I go" and "what am I supposed to do now?" A lot of time was spent backtracking or wandering all over the map looking for the next goal. There were areas that I couldn't get to simply because I wasn't SUPPOSED to get to them yet, even though I could see things I wanted just beyond simple things like rocks that Dracula should've easily been able to leap over and obtain. Not this Dracula. So that took me right out of the immersion. But OK, I can overlook it if the game itself is good. It's just the opposite of the first LoS to me. That one was excellent with a few flaws. This one is generally bad with a few bright spots, none of which make up for the game as a whole. The voice acting, aside from Dracula, is absolutely terrible, especially the "extras" you fight who constantly shout out the same lines over and over. The monsters in this one are poorly designed as well, and even the humans look bizarre. Garbriel's head often seems way too small for his giant body, for instance. Some of the fights were OK, but the vast majority just came down to relentless button mashing mixed with evasion. You can learn all the "cool moves" you want, but you really don't need them. Just mash that X and Y, and you'll get through most of the fights. Boss battles are typical of the problem with so many of these types of games today: big, giant, lumbering beasts or creatures that you have to climb or hit a glowing portion on, blah, blah, blah. Nothing exciting, nothing very interesting. The only thing that kept me going in this was really wanting to see a resolution to Dracula's story. Quite frankly, I wanted to see him become Gabriel again. But about 3/4 of the way in, I realized that, despite what some of the reviews said, this game was not getting much better. I was revisiting the same places over and over again, and who wants to walk Dracula around science labs in a game like this? Drab, boring science labs is where you spend much of the game, not the gothic settings of the first. SPOILER:Anyway, I was getting so frustrated wtih the game that I decided to spoil the ending for myself. I wanted to see if it was worth playing through to the end for a solid payoff. Well ... for me, it's not. Not even close. There was no resolution whatsoever. Silly me. How could I not get that they were just going to leave everything open-ended for yet another one of these things. The plot has become idiotic, downright stupid. I felt dumber for having played as much as I did. But at least I got it on sale. A true shame what they did to this franchise after such a great predecessor. Do not recommend this game at all.

content:
Posted: January 14
												Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is with distance one of the best Action RPG's ever made!Short: The Story is excellent and it contains Love, Hate, Vengeance and Sadness, also is well told and full of Surprises.The Gameplay and Combatsystem is fluid.Graphically this game is maybe not up-to-date, but it looks really good and every level in this game is wonderfully designed and affectionately made.Over time you get many upgrades which grants you more Ability's and skill's.More detailed:Story: The story tells of a former member of the Brotherhood of Light, named Gabriel Belmont.Many years after the Brotherhood of Light started to Hunt and Fight against Dracula alias Gabriel Belmont [Play part 1 to know why Gabriel is Dracula] a old "Friend" of Gabriel looked for him [you will wonder who it is if you know part 1] to ask for help defeating Satan again to save the World, because he wants revenge and destroy the world. Gabriels "Friend" make him an offer which he almost can't refuse.Also a Character which is akin with Gabriel, has an important role in this game. Even there is a second one who is akin with Gabriel, but find out by yourself =)So his Journey begins again ...Gameplay/Combat: The Gameplay and Combatsystem is a little bit slower as in part 1 but still really smooth and the controls are even really good and comprehensible. Over time you can learn more and more Ability's and Skill's which you can use by using the right button combination and timing. I played it with the Xbox360 Pad and it works perfect in all cases.Barely you have smaller stealth parts in this game which can take some time and sometimes you must transform yourself into a rat ;) also to find secrets.Enemys: like in part 1 there are many different Enemys. Every Foe has his unique style and his own behavior and/or abilitys and skills, which makes every Battle with an unknown enemy different from each other until you know them all. Some of the Bosses are little bit harder as like the Bosses in part 1, but good beatable.Soundtrack: The Soundtrack fits perfect to the game! It was made from a Orchesta.Graphic: The graphic is outdated but this gameengine looks Awesome!Environment: You have different surroundings in part 2. Sometimes you are in the Presence and sometimes you are in the Past which is technically important for the Story. Like in the first part, every detail is well designed and looks really good.Riddles: This game has many Riddles which must be solved to get further. Some are Easy, some Average and some Riddles are really Hard for the first time,Over and all this Game is totally worth the Money! You will not make a wrong decision if you buy this game. Also you will need to spend 13 - 21 hours approximately to beat the game the first time.Have a nice Day ^.^

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												A game i waited over 3 years for, expecting a final epic battle against satan and his army in hell but what we got was a bunch of running around a city with crappy stealth sections and just a lack of varied enemies, with almost nothing related to the castlevania universe. Should mention that the tutorials are horrific in this game and leaves a bad first impression right there but other than those things, its a pretty decent game with good combat and somewhat fun exploring(when you go back in time ofc, to avoid those horrible city sections.) and the boss fights are quiet nice, most of them are really well designed and badass but also not too difficult. At its current price i find it hard to recommend this game, at least if you are a fan of the first Lords of Shadow game but when it drops down to 20-15€ then it would be worth the price and worth giving a shot. Quick round up the good thing and bad things of the game.Pros: +Really good looking graphics and runs really smooth with not a single framedrop+Medieval era is awesome and looks fantastic+Combat is great and fun+The Orchestral music in the medieval areas and most boss fights are fantasticCons:-The Orchestral music during the city sections are really bad-Very few different kinds of enemies-Story is mediocre-Stealth is boring-So is the whole city-Characters this time around are not as interesting or memorable as the first game.EDIT: Now that the DLC is out but cant be reviewed seperatley, i will just combine it with this.The revelations DLC is a fantastic piece of content but still feels like it was cut from the main game just too make some extra cash. So you play as Alucard this time to retrieve Draculas weapons for whats coming next for him when he  wakes up. Sounds simple and a bit boring but it was much better than i expected.The big thing about this is NO STEALTH or CITIES, it only takes place in the castle and it looks amazing and has some nice puzzles and exploring the castle is fun.Now how is it controlling Alucard? I find it awesome, he has a good variation of combat skills and his abillities are cool but they have no purpose in combat. Instead of having a different weapon like Dracula for his light and dark magic, he has a sword with light and dark magic which might sound a bit lame but its not, works really well and its not too hard to learn the combat skills.Overall this is one of the best DLC's i have ever finished and definetly worth the money and makes the games story feel much more complete, its just a shame that this wasnt a part of the main game from the beginning.Would easily recommend the main game and dlc if found for 30-50% off, unless you own the main game, then you should throw ur money in steam right now and buy the dlc.

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												It pains me to do this, but I can’t recommend this game. It’s an example of how not to do sequels to good games. The first LoS game was a good reboot of the Castlevania setting with an ending that was baiting for a sequel, so I was anticipating this game, hoping for something better or at least more of the same. What I got was mostly the worst parts of LoS1 made even more annoying.[Spoiler alert for LoS1 and LoS2]The story and the way it is developing is boring and goes to unbelievable lengths to be stupid. The whole premise “You are Dracula” is being thrown away almost immediately and replaced with a redemption story that defies almost any reason, considering the setting and the narrative. The game starts you with a DmC tier edgy vampire lord and then repeatedly shows him as some pathetic weirdo, who was visions of his son he never actually saw in his young form. The gameplay humiliates the character of Dracula even more with annoying stealth sequences that make you hide from some demonic space marines – these sections of gameplay have zero freedom of approach and challenge – you just have to make progress the way it was intended or you will face ridiculous fail states or invisible walls.And oh boy, this desire to limit the player can be traced through the entire game when you are stuck with forced tutorials, platforming that makes little sense considering the level geometry (you can’t get to a secret you see hidden behind a 1,5m tall cinder block with wide gaps by its side, because you have to circle around it and use the Mist Form skill after a decent chunk of story progression)The level design being “open world” doesn’t help at all – it’s just badly designed locations, taped together in an attempt to create a fake metroidvania feeling. It actually brings frustration instead of interesting exploration because there are no ways of traversing the world that are fun. You would think that being Dracula could mean that you can fast travel by turning into bats or something like that, but no – you are stuck with tedious running and platforming with fake loading screens behind switches for doors and elevators.The things that made this experience actually bearable and occasionally fun were the visuals and the combat system.  The visuals and the designs of sceneries and enemies were pretty cool and the combat system had an interesting leveling gimmick that motivates you to use different moves as often as possible (if you want to level up your weapons faster).By the way, the Alucard DLC shares the same problems of the base game – it’s more of the base game if you want it.This game is not the worst game ever, but it’s a disappointment and you can almost always find a better action game to play and waste 15-20 hours on.

												This game is not worth your time. The graphics and combat system are still fine - they're directly from the first game, after all. They also added a way to mark the next spots you're supposed to grab when you're climbing, so that's an improvement over CLOS1. But the whole rest is terrible. The storytelling is artrocious right from the 10 minute opening cutscene. The modern day scenario is completely lacking in any charm whatsoever. They were definitely trying to be more like Darksiders with their "open world". However, the game throws you from one thing into the next way to much. The game feels disjointed. It sends you around between worlds like nobody's business and breaks up the flow of missions constantly. It's simply uninspired and disappointing. I stopped caring after 9 hours.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												I would highly recommend that you play LoS1 before playing this - the premise of the game spoils the 'secret ending' of the first game, but the game does recap the story if you just want to jump in here.Combat is much tighter than the first game - not only do you control three distinct weapons (a long-range whip, a mid-range healing sword, and close-range guard-breaking gauntlets), but the Mastery system encourages you to play around with and get comfortable with all of the moves in your repertoire instead of just mashing the simplest combo.Visually the game is intense - this is about as good as it gets from the PS3/360 generation, and the PC version has special HD textures.As far as the story, I was personally hoping for something a little less safe considering the gut-punch ending of the first game.  I have heard that Konami changed the original ending to the one we have here, so we'll see what the DLC offers.All in all I think that I may have enjoyed the first game more than this one, but this had moments, especially in the first half of the game, where I felt as if it was exactly what I had wanted out of the sequel.  The latter half also has great segments, such as the Toy Maker, but the last quarter of the game the narrative begins to get a little loose and things just happen because end the game already.  Which is a shame, but it doesn't necessarily ruin it.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												It is finally time to review Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2. A game I have been anticipating since I beat the first one. Mercury Steam did a good job rebooting Castlevania for me in a different perspective, however, that is sadly not the case with its direct sequel. Four excruciatingly long years I have endured to find that my expectations were too high for what could have happened to this series, and I will gladly explain why.I was wrong about my assumption again after finishing the DLC, since it added peripheral information to the reasoning behind some characters' choices, but it did not add anything more than what the player already knows which is ironic given its title "Revelations" and even more ironic comparing it to the first Lords of Shadow's DLC, which revealed quite a lot about the story. To be precise, I was generally dissatisfied with Lords of Shadow 2 in its story and was hoping the gameplay would make up for its mishaps.Full review found on: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/04/castlevania-lords-of-shadow-2.html

content:

												Castlevania: Lords of Shadow was the first Castlevania game I played. I haven't looked through the artbook yet, but I can just tell it will be amazing like before.If I had to give this a score out of 10, I would only have to say an 8.3/10 for now, as my views will change (hopefully for the better).

												Well it's a lot like God of War gameplay. The story so far is alright. You play as a weakened Dracula who has to get his powers/abilities back. The combat is strange because it's harder to fight regular mobs than it is to fight bosses. It has light puzzle solving. Parts of the game you have to sneak past guards because you're not strong enough to kill them. Which is complete bull crap because you're fighting Satan's acolytes who are super powerful demons. content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												I was sceptical of the critic reviews for the final instalment in LOS, but I did not loose faith in MercurySteam and they pulled through with flying colors! Being an avid Castlevania fan since the snes days, I was more than surprised at mercurysteams reminagination of the franchize. This game is very well polished and manages to top it's predecessor in almost every way. The graphics are beutiful and almost photorealistic, the diferences in graphics between the PC and PS3 version are very noticable. The combat is more refined since the first game and makes for a very enjoyable experience every step of the way(considering it take 15-20hrs to complete) and the storyline keeps you wanting to keep playing till the very end. I have to dispell some alligations by "reviewers" who mentioned the story is confusing compared to the first game. The games story is linear and easy to follow so long as you've played mirror of fate (although the game does a pretty dam good job of filling you in on the details at the begining, in fact you probably don't need to play the game although I recomend it).My only complaint with the game are the stealth sections.I found them to be a nucance but in no way were they hard of frustrating, actually they were well executed and easy to acomplish. I only dislike them because they felt out of place within the games combat and fun platforming.There are barley any stealth sections in the game anyways, maby taking up less than 10% of the game so it's not an issue worth crying over. This game was a day one buy for me and I was surprised to see I did not have any software issues with the game like crashes or freezing etc ( I have bad experiences with AC4 black flag and battlefield 4). On a gtx760 and FX6300 I can run this at a full 60fps. One thing I would like to mention is how half of the critic reviews said this was a God of War knockoff. God of war did not invent the Hack-and-Slash genre and LOS2 shouldn't be classified as such. If we are going into deep water here, mineaswell call God of War a knockoff of Devil May Cry.Going back to the game though, I fondly look at this as a fun hack-and-slash game with  an amazing story! This game is a true testament at the hard work mercurysteam has put on their take of castlevania. All in all I would give the PC ver. an 8.5/10. If you were a fan of the first lords of shadow like me, this game will not dissapoint!

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												GAME REVIEW TIME:Okay, so, I'm sure you all know, or at least some of you know, how passionate I am about Darksiders 2.That game, was a brilliant masterpiece of a creation. I must'v played through it at least 5 times.Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 COMPLETELY matched up with it. I WOULD say it beat it, but I hold Darksiders 2 near and dear to my heart, I couldn't betray it like that.Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is a GREAT Action/adventure game, with tons of different enemies, with different attack patterns, it forces you to adapt to your situation really quick, and I think that's what we need more in games.I'm going to be comparing CLOS2 (castlevania: lords of shadow 2) To Darksiders 2, since it has a small bit of similarities. The problem with Darksiders 2, was that they threw the same enemy at you constantly, and it made the game a bit boring, not to mention memorizing all their attack patterns, and making the game a breeze. Not much of a challenge, in hindsight.CASTLEVANIA THREW THAT OUT THE ♥♥♥♥ING WINDOW.MOTHER ♥♥♥♥ING♥♥♥♥♥♥TONS OF DIFFERENT ENEMIES LEFT AND RIGHT EVERYWHEREEverywhere you went there was a different enemy, and it really brings out that sense of impending doom thing they have going for it.Like, 'oh i'll just go over here and grab tha-wait... no... no i won't. it's scary over there'Granted, if you're skilled enough, you can defeat the enemies no problem, and grab whatever the hell you want, but that's not the point. The point I'm trying to make is, you never know what's going to be behind that corner, so it really makes you stop and think about your situation. Do I have enough health in case a huge ♥♥♥♥♥ shows up? Do I have enough healing items in case I get ♥♥♥♥ed over? THAT'S what makes the game fun, exciting, and fresh. It just throws new♥♥♥♥♥♥at you, it keeps it FRESH.And the weapons you get, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ Your main weapon is called the "shadow whip" and it's basically, a whip that Dracula (main character) can summon whenever he wants, as it's made out of his own blood. The lore about the weapon says that people who get hit by it says it feels like "A thousand fangs piercing every inch of your body." Also, it hardens on impact... That's why it's able to hit people, and not just splooge all over the place.Your secondary, or heavy weapon, is called the "chaos claws" These deal... MASSIVE amounts of damage, but they can't be used for long, as they require a chaos charge. you get a Chaos charge by absorbing blood orbs from enemies.Your third weapon is called the "Void Sword" This is the same as the Chaos claws, except it doesn't hit as hard, AND with every blow you land, you get health back. So, basically, if you've played Darksiders 2, it's basically health steal.And the Graphics... The Graphics, and the lighting technique are AMAZING. Everywhere you go is beautiful scenery, be it the modern city or Dracula's castle. The Characters models are amazing, as well. The art they chose for Dracula, and alucard, and all the other people you come in contact with is BRILLIANT.And the best god damn part of this whole game? YOU DON'T EVEN NEED TO KNOW THE STORY! CLOS2 is technically part of the story that Castlevania was portraying in their earlier days of 2d sidescroller, but it doesn't match up with it. It's almost a different timeline.You know what? ♥♥♥♥ it. Castlevania beat Darksiders 2 in my list of all time favourites.You had a good run Darksiders 2...Seriously though, go buy this game. It's ♥♥♥♥ing great.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												I loved the prequel to this game so much, I had the best time on that game, it was beautiful, I felt strong and I had motivation to keep on truckin'. I was so hyped for Lords of Shadow 2.The game began, the tutorial scene was spectacular. I felt like I was unstoppable as I tore through armies of men with great ease.Suddenly I was in the future and I had no powers at all. I thought to myself "I'm ok with this, it's just an intro scene to tell me the story" and I was right, I gained some of my powers back and I was placed into the world, the world which was simply a modern day looking city... that ruined some of the Lords of Shadow feels, I was used to beautiful natural landscapes with ancient ruins dotted around, the modern world is not something I want to see in a fantasy series, it's boring because I see it every day.I decided to push on and I came up to the first "enemy". The first enemy of the game you cannot kill, you have to hide from it. I am Dracula, the Prince of Darkness... and this GRUNT enemy is undefeatable by me, yeah that doesnt make me feel cool. You have to use stealth which is just turning into a rat and running past him, THIS IS A CASTLEVANIA GAME. I proceeded and there were two more of these undefeatable enemies, it took what felt like forever to get into real combat and ... it was Ok.The combat feels smoother that the last game but for some reason I ended up getting hit a lot more, I dont know if this was my fault or a lack of enemies telegraphing attacks, I really dont know. The first boss was cool to begin with but it was quite repetitive and way too simple, way more simple than the tutorial boss which actually hit me quite a few times.I continued through the game a bit longer, but after an hour or so after fighting mutants and military mech suit things, I gave up. My character had no motivation so I had no motivation, there were too many gaps between combat where i just had to♥♥♥♥♥♥around for a good while to make my way through an area. The scenery of the game was unattractive in my opinion with everything being either black, white or grey and all of the feelings of the original Lords of Shadow were gone. I was truly truly disappointed when I played this game and I wish that it didn't exist.tl;dr THIS GAME IS CRAP3/10

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS:To be honest, I really enjoyed this game during.  I think the combat was well put together.  The story we really well done, IMO.  This is a tricky review though.  As I said, during the game it was fun.  On beating the game though, I did feel disappointed.  But let me break down some of the elements.Stealth:  I feel the hate for these sections is misplaced.  The fact is, they are such a tiny part of the game, they might as well not even be there.  They can all be completed in no more than 10 minutes.  I also feel the whole transforming into the rat swarm was not neccesary at all.  Enemies:  Most enemies are very good.  They vary up their attacks, they dodge your attacks, and large groups of them can prove problematic.  Out of all the times I died, it was mostly to these situation.  At points you are under seige from large groups of small enemies, and then sometimes you are facing two or three very large hard to kill enemies.As it should follow - Combat:  The combat I feel was excellent in this game.  It was as good as the combat in the first game, hands down.  They added this power up element which basically incentivizes changing attacks and weapons.  The dodge was much more responsive feeling in this game than the last game.  Accordingly, the timing for the charge moves of enemies is very much varied.  So there is no absolute time to block.  They also made it harder to syncronize block in this game.  It felt like you have less frames to hit the button in.  I noticed that some enemies hardly ever normal attack and almost always charge.  Those enemies ended up being the easiest though as their attacks tended to not be varied.  The World:  This is where the game has some failings.  It placed you in many small corridors and very few vistas.  In the first game you had lots of open and interesting areas to fight and puzzle your way through.  In this one lots of times it felt lackluster because of this failing.  The castle, as other reviews have stated, is awesome.  But it just feels like the castle is mostly optional.  You find Wolf portals between the worlds, but I found little reason to back to the castle and explore.Environmental puzzles:  Almost non-existent.  It's a shame, iit was fun to try and get past timing puzzles and spike traps in the first game.  This game had none of that.  No timing puzzles, no spike traps, it just felt like you were walking forward a lot in this game with little to hinder your way... well little except finding a switch which was usually located in the same room.  I just didn't see the point of pulling a lever to open a door that was five feet away.Extracurriculars: There was plenty of things in this game to collect.  But the back tracking isn't fun to me.  In the first game, the stage based design was awesome for this.  Go back, find the scrolls, collect the gem or the weapon upgrade, maybe do a the stage challenge while you are at it.  I loved the challenges in the first game, they were fun to try and complete.  This game didn't really have that.  They had some sort of challenges that I unlocked throughout the game, and the game managed to tell me about them about 700 times throughout the course of the game.  The funny part was, going through the pages of the Journal and menus... where the hell are they located?  I never figured it out, but I wan't inclined to backtrack and figure it out. Pros that don't need explanation:Music was awesomeVoice acting was awesomeStory was, for the most part, very goodCons (many of these are personal cons and as such I know aren't objective or shared by many people):Free Camera - I loved how the first one was with the locked camera.  The devs always put it in a good spot to show off the awesome world.  I feel that stepping away from that was a mistake.  The camera was downright annoying in some battles, and in other battles it didn't do a good job.  Open World:  As explained, I didn't enjoy this aspect.  I am a firm believer that not every game is automatically made better by an open world.  This one was definitely not.  Believe it or not, the world actually felt much smaller than the stage based world from the first game.  I think a good open world is truly awesome, but this unfortunately was not.  Also, in making it an open world that helped to deny my want to go back and find collectibles.Overall Opinion:  I think this is a worthy game on a sale.  If you played and liked the combat from the first game, you are probably gonna love the combat in this one.  I also felt that the dev failed to deliver on a conclusion to the trilogy.  The ending was not a conclusion, but an outright attempt to further the series into yet another game, which disappoints me.  I am anxious to see what they do with DLC however.  There are rumors of an Alucard DLC, which I would be interested in playing.   If they did some sort of DLC that let you play as the other Belmont you meet in the game, that would also be fun.  If I had to give it a score, I would probably give it a 6/10.  This is not an objective review, I have explained what I personally did not like about it.Edit:  At the time of writing my Steam timer shows 25 hours in game.. but I alt/tabbed out of the game to do something, realized I had to leave for work, and then left it on while I was at work by accident.  I really only put 15 hours or so into the game, so that was a disppointment.  The first one I put 29 actual hours into.Edit2:  I did a "No" recommend.  But if you get it on sale and want to see how the story plays out, it's  a yes.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												One of my favorite action-adventure games; but be careful, this game has a different tone than the first Lords of Shadow and also, it has big plot holes and some gameplay flaws.The combat is very similar to the first Lords of Shadow, but improved.The puzzles are easier but most of them are more related to the game than the puzzles of the first Lords of Shadow ( now many puzzles involves using the abilities of Dracula instead of moving pieces in a board).This game also have camera control with the right stick instead of the predefined camera of the first game.Another noticeable change is that now there are exploration in the game, it's really a 3D Metroidvania game, where you unlock new areas while getting new powers.About the tone, LoS 2 has an atmosphere much darker than the first one, basically you explore two worlds:  one is very similar to the first game(but darker), and the other one at the beginning may look like an arkham city less appealing, but most of the game it's more like the first Darksiders atmosphere.The story also remind me Darksiders and a little bit of Hellboy.The bad parts: there are some stealth sections that feels out of place and there are not very fun, the first hour of two of the game(after the prolog) are not very good, Dracula doesn't look like a vampire(but you can buy a skin :) ), and the game has some annoying on-screen suggestions (fortunately, they can be deactivated in the menu).Even when these shortcomings most of the game is great.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												A few notes about this review: I'm yet to play the prequel to this game as of the time this review was written, and as such, will not be comparing this title to Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 1.Gameplay:The game is very reminiscent of open-world  hack and slash classics such as Devil May Cry and Bayonetta. The mechanics are well varied and properly executed, and at its' very beginning, launches the player into action. The boss fights are bloody, epic, and memorable. Little was spared in terms of length and difficulty when encountering various bosses, who are well varied and endowed. Prepare to die a few times in your quest to make progress.Note that duie to the nature of the story (see section below) , repetitive gameplay is necessitated for one to unlock Dracula's potential abilities as the story progresses. This is executed in a repetitive manner, and as such, incurs a considerable challenge at the early stages of the game. However, as an indirect consequence, later sections are very rewarding as your new abilities are fully utilized in making progress. Prepare for a challenge. The stealth system and mechanics used are not ideal and are out of balance. A being such as dracula shouldn't be reduced to a powerless imp in the stealth sections, which can be confusing and often convoluted. Graphics:Excellent, judging bu its' requirements and visuals. They are well balanced and properly executed. Details are clear and vivid, and so are the vast, open world environments. Character forms are well refined and so are their spectral abilities. Story line: All in all, dependin gon your background, its' taste may differ to you. I've read previous reviews from people who played the games' prequel and most were not pleased.in my opinion, I found the fusion of both the present and the past (through the use of the Wolf Medallion) a bit unique in that you can switch to either timeline and progress at your own rate. In a manner, this further enhances the open world experience. As a drawback, this can make the game very repetitive since the environments are consrained to one transitional area, a chemical company. This also incurs a drawback to the overall quality of Dracula's retelling as a legendary vampire who must be trapped to a moden themed factory for extended periods of gameplay time as a requirement to progressing in the game. This repetitive nature may not bode well for all players. Overall rating:The production quality is superb, and so is the gameplay. Comes highly recommended.My personal rating is 7.5/10.

Posted: July 4, 2015
												Solid, smooth fighting mechanic is not sufficient in my opinion to carry the whole wieght of this game. I'll start with the good elements of the game, then follow up with what went wrong with it:Pros:-Smooth fighting style and movement-All three weapons are unique and special in thier own way with robust upgrading tree for each.-Atmospheric scenes and amazing Castle design are enough to leave you at awe at some moments.-Some great and well designed boss fights scattered throughout the game.-Collectables scattered throughout the game encourage you to explore many areas and backtrack.Cons:-Absolutly shallow and unnecessary "stealth" mechanic slapped on multiple parts of the game.-The city doesn't leave a memorable moment. Its colorless and many times make you feel like you want to run through it as quick as possible.-Particle effects of attacking/blocking leave you blind to where the enemies hits will come from midcombat.-Blocking is ineffective when you are swarmed my multiple enemies. leaving you vulnerable to consecutive hits after your first block.-Many boss fights feel scripted, with no way for you to beat bosses unless you do it the way the game wants you to.-The story is such a drag, with characters coming and going with no backstories to them.
