content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												A massive overhaul of the combat system without forgetting tricks learned, optional quicktime system, across the board admission that they made mistakes with the first game, and a demonstration that they can learn from them. The only problem this game has is the menu interface, which doesn't allow multiple saves or easy access to an actual title menu. But it doesn't hurt the actual content of the game.Graphics: 9/10. Only deducted points is for some weird-looking hair and particle animation touching on the uncanny valley, but it's otherwise a gorgeous, nigh perfectly beautiful game.Sound: 10/10. The score is wonderfully emotional and puts you in the middle of each moment. You'll find yourself humming along with the rat theme, and gratified during the main theme's return in key moments.Gameplay: 9/10. It's not castlevania anymore, but I'm not complaining. The tricks they picked up from Devil May Cry combine well with other improvements, and mesh in the Symphony-esque metroidvania world. No more is the whip the only useful weapon, no more is spamming R1 the easiest way to end fights. No more are quicktime events required, but neither are they abandoned, for those who enjoy them. And they skip function works beautifully, at no point during even cutscenes do they feel forced, nor does the lack of them feel depriving. A good status quo. But it looses a point for not having a heart system, or a means to deal with stealth sections as a combat option. Sorry, series fidelity is one thing I'm big on, and Castlevania isn't a stealth game, neither is it Devil May Cry. That said, the stealth segments are still very well designed, just a littlle immersion breaking when you're playing as the Prince of Darkness, whom the devil and death both fear.Replay: 9/10: Postgame, Newgame+, and some really enjoyable once-through sequences, with a train sequence early on being a standout, and a few of the boss build-ups having that effect as well, make for a game that you won't feel a need to give up for awhile, and will always be willling to dig out in a year for another run. No complaints, only point deducted is thanks to Dark Souls moving the goalposts (and Dark Souls II doing it again,) for replay value in recent years by evolving the new game+ formula, and there should have been an attempt to learn from their methods. Great games learn from each other. This applies to all games developed after a previous game. You don't need to change your self-entity, but cool tricks should not be ignored.Story: 10/10 Yes. On par with the first, with a slightly more Castlevania-y feel, despite your role as the series villian. No more pacing problems. Just awesome. There is emotion, forshadowing, character depth all done wonderfully. If I can make a complaint, it is only that some character arcs require a knowledge of the much-less-enjoyable first game to fully appreciate, but watching a youtube cutscene compilation will fulfil your need.Overall: 94/100. If you're into the genre, if you're into the series, heck, if you're into just good storytelling in general, give this game a shot. If you're scared, wait for a steam sale. It's optimized wonderfully, so hardware shouldn't be a big problem.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												This game is really good. If you liked the first one, like I did, I highly recommend it. The combat depth from the first is still there, and no amount of button mashing will save your life. And the combat is quite chalenging. The map exploration is a Metroid-Vania, but in a 3D enviroment, look like Darksiders. The game rewards exploration, since there are a lot of collectibles and upgrades, and you can easily miss then if you don't explore, and a quick travel trough castle map rooms are a enourmous help, altough the quick travel system could be better. Story is awesome, what could you ask? It is Dracula, The prince of Darkness kicking Satan in the nuts - that's a good one on my book. The presentation is spot on, you totaly look like a badass vampire and fight like one, and both city and castle parts are impressive. The developers reproduce the horror ambience from other Castlevania games perfectly, and even when you are in modern times, it really looks like a Castlevania. The only complaint I have is that they could use more of the open air parts of the modern day city, since it looks so awesome, but you'll be on the inside of buildings most of the time. I'm a big fan of the series, and this is a worthy sequence of a great game. I'm still working on beating it, and the boss fights are really good.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												What can I say other than I will not be recommending this to my friends...Pros:It looks nice (very few graphical glitches only seems to happen on higher settings)The story can grip you sometimes with a 'what next!' moment. (very rare)Get to see my man alucard thats always a plus. (wish he had more face time)It was cheap when I got it that was the plus if you can not get it on sale dont bother.I felt compeled to finish it I suppose I will count this as a positive but would be hard for non Castlevania fans to have that drive imo...Cons:Horrid voice actors (seen more life in a mortuary could have been chanting 'I LIKE APPLE PIE' would have made more sense than what they said 65% of the time and would fit with the facial expressions 85% more)Overly drawn out tutorial (does it really take like 5 minutes of pounding heads to say oh beat them down then eat them alive)Crazy player hitbox size compared to enemies. (A ground based attack hitting you in a double jump)Really stiff platforming that feels like it belongs in a slycooper game. (felt like tomb raider on the ps1 well... better animations)Constant screen flashing and out of no where flashbacks that confuses the player (Never knew where I would pop up).Foot holds I have a fear of rock climbing now due to the gross overuse of climbing sections.Other:Nudity and strange ugly creatures (if you like dead body boobs this might be for you otherwise #NoPe)Would be nice if it had only one or two quarks I did not like but it has 6 game breaking flaws!That is just off the top of my head not counting those annoying reaper things that if they are not airborn will own you trying this on a moving terrain with a fixed camera beyond annoying.In closing I feel this is a game with a huge identity crisis it has a hard time deciding what it wants to be does it want to be a stealth action game, a brawling beatem up, a god of war clone, or even a platformer. Also Wtf Man! Drac spent so much time as a rat was beginning to think even he has an identiy crisis. (I get the plot memory loss thing but the second he knew he was the prince of darkness he should have had a little dignity)

												Lords of Shadow 2 is a decent action adventure game with outstanding graphics. Unlike the first installment this title felt more like Darksiders. Don't get me wrong, while the Darksiders franchise is great, One can only wish that the developers didn't just copy and paste some aspects of other titles. The story arc was great until towards the end of the game where everything just seemed rushed and the ending anti-climactic. The stealth feature in the game was very repetitive and annoying at times but a decent attempt at something different. All in all I Give this game a thumbs up, even with my complaints I still really enjoyed this game!

												About 4 hours in so far and I am enjoying this game very much.  It is much faster paced than the first one and is doing a nice job (story wise) of wrapping in the existing lore from other games (espeically Symphony of the Night) while adding it's own twist.  The environments, monsters, look & feel are all superb.  Fantastic lighting, graphics, mechanics - the game feels good to play.  Some pacing issues and 'duh, i know that' moments.  If you enjoyed the first one at all (which I did for the fantastic environments/monsters ... less the mechanics) then this is an upgrade and a solid sequel that definitely feels more like a castlevania game ... even with some very new changes to the formula.  So far: no wall chicken.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												While it's not perfect, Lords of Shadow 2 is still an extremely fun game.If you liked the classic Simon's Quest back in it's age, you'll probably enjoy this as well. You can't just go in blind for the story, but if you've followed the other LoS games, it makes sense. Gameplay got an overall improvement from LoS 1, and the hub-structure feels great.Some of the stealth sections can feel a little heavy handed, but they're over fast enough with just basic levels of situational awareness. Also, some of the monster packs can feel awkward at times due to running out of weapon-magic at bad times.Overall, it's still a solid game. It feels like a Castlevania, it plays like a Castlevania, and it's plotted like a Castlevania. Not sure what all the over-negative games-media reviews were hating on, part of me thinks they didn't "get" Simon's Quest when it was out on the NES originally, and have held a petty grudge since. It's not a 10, but it's not a 5 by any stretch of the imagination. IMO, 7.8/10, solid combat systems, a healthy-sized world with plenty to explore/find/collect, but with some rough stealth sections, and one character feeling fairly wasted in their introduction/departure.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Addictive!If you liked the first game, expect improved mechanics and a better developed battle system which encourages you to learn your combos instead of constantly using the same button. Leveling your weapons up is a much better experience now and you will actually feel the difference as Dracula's power returns.As for graphics, the game is beautiful - though not as inspired as the first episode. Light is improved, textures are improved, creativity not so much. Bear with the game for the first 2 hours and it won't let you down. Playing through modern cities with the almighty vampire might sound like a nice idea but the lack of better designs and the feeling of repetition as the scenery looks the same for a while will make you ask why the developers chose this path instead of focusing on the much nicer gothic    landscapes Castlevania really shines on.Storywise, even though the actors are awesome and doing their best, they haven't got much to work with. Still, this is only true if you compare it with the first LoS. Yes, there's a story, yes, it's kind of mediocre... Well, the majority of games I've been playing haven't been above mediocre so I guess it's fine.Other than that, lots of places to explore and collectibles all over the place will give you replayability over the already lenghty main course. So, yeah. Good. Really good and recommended at full price. 7/10

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is an entertaining, 12+ hour long action game with a few issues holding it back from greatness. It's a shlocky, hamfisted and (in my mind) enjoyable story focused on Dracula and his bloody escapades around his palace in two different timelines. While not wholly divergent enough from the play-book of the first Lords of Shadow to call it a Metroidvania, Lords of Shadow 2 (LoS2) makes an admirable attempt at creating a fully explorable world which requires backtracking to old nooks with new moves in your arsenal to claim some doodad for your growing inventory of glowing crystal assistance-thingies. It's all very obvious and not particularly exciting, but it does reward you for your time and attentiveness. You won't really need those 'hidden' rewards unless you're playing on the upper difficulty echelons. The combat is instantly recognizeable if you've played the first game. This year's model does come with improvements, weapon switching on the fly similar to DmC: Devil May Cry replaces the blue glow/red glow for essentially the same status effect, but with new combos to learn. There's also a fully adjustable camera, which is a pleasant new necessity (given the level design). Like the first Lords of Shadow, LoS2 has a deeper combat system than you might give it credit for at first appearance, it'll grow on you, but it doesn't go as far as some contemporaries and on all but the highest difficulties you won't struggle in battle.LoS2 has a few obvious issues. While there's some goofy and entertaining narrative chunks to push you forward early on, there's also some sluggish tutorialization. The two timelines are enjoyable, but the past clearly has the art design edge- with the present not really distinguishing itself nearly as much. You'll probably greet flashlights with a weary sigh as the signal in another easy, brainless stealth section that, conceptually, is used to break up the monotany of entertaining flashy combat and brisk level design. Yeah, great idea.At the end of the day, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is a likeable sequel. It's self-aware, in many aspects, with fantastic options like 'Turn off QTEs' which I highly recommend, as well as boasting satisfying boss encounters. It unfortunately struggles with branching out and exploring new gameplay elements. The pacing could be tighter... But, that said, I had a lot of fun with it. There are some great sequences, great moments that play off of the crazy Castlevania Dracula power trip which make it easy to recommend to fans of the first game. When it's firing on all cylinders, it captures the essence of what so many people liked about the first. It hits a lot more than it misses and is worth your time and money if you happened to enjoy the first. It runs great, looks great and is fun to play. While it didn't surpass my expectations, it met them.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Forget the general critics from "God of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; and "Symphony of the Night" fans (the majority of them just played SOTN and dont really knows about Castlevania games at all) this is a deep very well made fan service.Rule of the tumb: if you liked the 1st Castlevania: Lords of Shadow this game is a "Instabuy"***Edited at 09/13/14 to review the DLC Revelations.***PROS:- Improved combat and movement mechanics making this even more solid;- Awesome graphics and immersive scenarios (combine several aspects of Vampire lore with Castlevania's elements);- Free movement camera;- Lots of extra content including: 400 pages of design artwork (seems much but it is easy to have those collected during the game - I've completed mine in the 1st run), Challenges and Lore- Fantastic follow up history;- About 14~17 hours long (if you're a completionist and like achievements you would mostly at least double that time);- On LOS1 the platforming wasn't really great and you finished get killed by bad jumping several times. That was corrected!CONS:- Although stealth isn't that bad as people say (in reality just a puzzle) it is so easy that doesn't adds any value to the gameplay at all;- In 17 hours -my 1st run- I didnt spend no more than 30 minutes with ALL puzzles (including stealth) which means that the puzzles are super easy. The LOS1 puzzles were waaaaay more fun;- Voice acting, for Gabriel Belmont, should be better. During LOS1 it was "Fair" for a Brotherhood templar but it is not enough for Dracula;DLC Revelations:The level of disappointment provided by this one is only compared to Oblivion Horse Armor.Add 2 hours of gamplay with an incredible weak plot.Do a favor to yourself and skip this one.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Absolutely loved this game. Now, most people will say the story sucked...and they're right. The story wasn't all it was supposed to be. Very shoddy work on the story, I won't lie. But you know as well as I do they aren't done with it. There will be more story released just like there was with the first one. Which, i'm ok with. With all the backtracking and whatnot I did it took me 23 hours to complete. That's a good length in my book with what story they went with. I mean, who wanted more of what they were doing? And the graphics are truely amazing. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. The screenshots alone prove this game is pretty as hell. (heh) And a lot of people are complaining that the scenery is bland and boring. It's modern age style london. It's not that exciting. What did you expect from modern times? I mean, come on now. The segments in the castle are amazing and remind me of the backdrops of the first one, though not quite as epic looking.All in all it's an improvment on the first. The camera problems are gone, the combat has been tweeked, and you get to play as Dracula. That in and of itself is way too awesome. WAY TOO AWESOME! It was a great game that I reccomend for fans. People joining in on the series now may find it difficult at times to maintain interest in the story. But the gameplay will probably keep you around. I give this game an easy 9/10. Only losing a point because of the story. I had high expectations and they were met. ^_^

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Unlike its predecessors, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 in overall did not move me as much I was expecting it. Gameplay wise, it's gone back to the dungeon crawling genre which could be great for some of the gamers out there. The abilities are quite similar to what we experienced in Castlevania: Lords of Shadow however with different type of weapons and upgrades. There is a larger selection of secondary items that can help, but in my personal experience, they were rarely used. Some events were quite interesting but I must agree with most people that the stealth feature should have been scrapped and put focus on the platforming and puzzles.As you might have guessed, the storyline begins with Dracula or formerly Gabriel Belmont fight the Brotherhood of Light then ends with Alucard appearing. You then jump through time into a modern technological world, and start with the ridiculous stealth feature à la Metal Gear Solid. So, your objectives are basically to fight various bosses and repossess old powers which Dracula has lost through time. Pretty much like any dungeon crawling game. Unfortunately, there is little content about the storyline which was pretty disappointing. Characters, including Dracula and Alucard were uninteresting, emotionless. The exception is when Dracula returns to his castle throughout the playthrough. I finished this game without any emotion and with lots of questionning. Do I recommend this game? I will for the people who like Castlevania, the old dungeon crawling genre. But, you must expect some disappointment if you want to know the rest of the story. Cheers.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												I have to admit I was a little late to the game when it came to the first game. For those that don't know, the first Lords of Shadow - and by extension this game as well - is a reboot of the franchise as opposed to a continuation of the original canon.That being said, I have been greatly anticipating this sequel since finally playing and beating LoS and man was it ever worth all that waiting and anticipation! LoS 2 has you playing as the Prince of Darkness, Dracula (Gabriel Belmont in this universe) himself which really needs no explanation in regards to it's freaking cool factor.Patrick Stuart reprises his role as Zobek (aka Death) and Robert Carlyle is back (and better than ever!) as Gabriel/Dracula, which alone are two good reasons why this game rocks! Also, Richard Madden as Alucard was a pretty splendid choice in my opinion. The sound and music - and the other voice work too - is all quite excellent as well.I have been absolutely loving the gameplay so far, especially the combat which I feel has recieved a nice overhaul. There is still enough of the old system there that it should feel familiar and comfortable, but they also improved nicely upon some of the smaller snags I felt the first game suffered from. AI is a bit more agressive and (only slightly) less predictable this time, which is a bit refreshing. Also, for all intents and purposes - at least as far as gameplay is concerned - Gabriel and Dracula are two entirely different characters, despite actually being the same person.Gone is the Combat Cross, Gabriel's signature weapon from LoS; instead Dracula most commonly wields the Shadow Whip which is a manifestation of his own blood that he can summon and control. Instead of Gabriel's Light and Shadow Magic, you now have the life-leeching Void Sword and the armor-piercing Chaos Claws which each offer their own form and style in combat. You can also feed on stunned opponents to recover your health in a pinch. Oh and instead of the consumables Gabriel used to carry around, Dracula wields powerful vampire abilities and other dark magics - Shadow Daggers, Void Projections, Bat Swarms and more; instead of being consumable they all have their own cool-down timers and thus behave more like spells would.The game is much bigger and better all around for the most part, though there a few minor things that I personally find annoying. For instance exploration is way more 'hand holdy' than it was in LoS... to the point that ledges you can grapple and climb now glow faintly and are surrounded by a small swarm of bats, objects you can bash with your throwing daggers are outlined by a glowing red ring of what appears to be blood, and the addition of an actual function (hold LT) while platforming that outlines possible moves 2-3 steps ahead of where you're currently climbing/hanging. Not really a deal breaker, per say, but definitely takes a lot of the fun out of it. In LoS I actually missed quite a few collectibles due to not being able to find them or simply not being able to reach them once I did locate them - this in turn drove me to explore further and look all the harder for what I may have missed; the possibility for this level of challenge is all but impossible in LoS 2 it would seem.I won't give away too much of the plot, for two reasons: one I have yet to beat the game and two it would just be a damn shame to spoil something so good. That being said the basic premise is this: a thousand years (and a 3DS game) have passed since the events of LoS, Dracula has been defeated and weakened - by his own blood no less - and thus left vulnerable to an attack from Satan, whom Gabriels seriously♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off the last time they met. Zobek makes a timely arrival to warn his 'old friend' of course and offers him both a way to regain his powers - to defeat Satan - and a way to free him from his curse - death at the hands of Zobek, who has supposedly located the Combat Cross. Thus the battle begins between the Prince of Darkness and the agents of Satan.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												What can I say other than I will not be recommending this to my friends...Pros:It looks nice (very few graphical glitches only seems to happen on higher settings)The story can grip you sometimes with a 'what next!' moment. (very rare)Get to see my man alucard thats always a plus. (wish he had more face time)It was cheap when I got it that was the plus if you can not get it on sale dont bother.I felt compeled to finish it I suppose I will count this as a positive but would be hard for non Castlevania fans to have that drive imo...Cons:Horrid voice actors (seen more life in a mortuary could have been chanting 'I LIKE APPLE PIE' would have made more sense than what they said 65% of the time and would fit with the facial expressions 85% more)Overly drawn out tutorial (does it really take like 5 minutes of pounding heads to say oh beat them down then eat them alive)Crazy player hitbox size compared to enemies. (A ground based attack hitting you in a double jump)Really stiff platforming that feels like it belongs in a slycooper game. (felt like tomb raider on the ps1 well... better animations)Constant screen flashing and out of no where flashbacks that confuses the player (Never knew where I would pop up).Foot holds I have a fear of rock climbing now due to the gross overuse of climbing sections.Other:Nudity and strange ugly creatures (if you like dead body boobs this might be for you otherwise #NoPe)Would be nice if it had only one or two quarks I did not like but it has 6 game breaking flaws!That is just off the top of my head not counting those annoying reaper things that if they are not airborn will own you trying this on a moving terrain with a fixed camera beyond annoying.In closing I feel this is a game with a huge identity crisis it has a hard time deciding what it wants to be does it want to be a stealth action game, a brawling beatem up, a god of war clone, or even a platformer. Also Wtf Man! Drac spent so much time as a rat was beginning to think even he has an identiy crisis. (I get the plot memory loss thing but the second he knew he was the prince of darkness he should have had a little dignity)

												A great conclusion of the Castlevania saga on PC, 8/10! It is much more open world than the 1st part, you basically explore 2 big realms you can switch between, instead of small secluded missions like in part1. Although many skills are the same as before, it plays quite differently because of that, and also seems to be a bit easier. In the end, the boss fight were not as impressive as in game 1, so I like both games equally. Nice number of achievements to unlock, good graphics and some bad♥♥♥♥♥skills make this game highly recommended for action fans. Some of the new stealth parts can be a bit frustrating, but it is again fun to explore and hunt down all live, void and chaos extras to become super powerful! The DLC actually has some clever new skills for the new protagonist, and they are used for some much more difficult timed puzzles, so the really add to the gameplay.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Well, this was quite a waste of potential. Dracula vs Satan in the fantastic/futuristic modern day setting among the apocalypse - sounds exciting. Plays boring.First LoS was a really boring game, but at least the story was coherit, the art style was beautiful and it, while borrowed, truly *tried*. It felt like it was trying to be a good an exciting game. Usually it wasn't. But it's the thought that counts.Mirror of Fate was surprisingly fantastic, falling slightly flat from what people expect from the 2D Castlevania, but a fun mix of classic games in the series with gameplay elements of LoS.LoS 2 tries to improve. It looks better technologically, tries to rebalance some things in a good way, makes camera mostly good, removes the linear level progress in favor of the open world and makes soundtrack especially nice. And then adds forced stealth sections. And boring bland looking levels. And "secrets" which usually feel like pointless stuff. And incoherit storytelling without any conflict you can feel (but it's there, honest!).This feels like Blood Omen 2 recreated in LoS universe. Except Blood Omen 2 was still a pretty okay game with some excitement and Kain, while this game just... is. LoS 1 was boring, this game just exists. It's just there. And you can play it. But you really shouldn't.P.S. Playing as Alucard in the DLC is fun, but that's about all there is to the DLC. It tells nothing new at all, despite the title.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												Sequel to the first Lords of Shadow game, this second installment is very good. It has amazing graphics and soundtrack as the first one. The gameplay is very good too, with some differences with the first game.You play once again as Gabriel Belmont, but this time you're known as Dracula.The story is good, it keeps you hooked to see what's next. However the ending of the game pales in comparison to the ending of the first Lords of Shadow. I was expecting a closed, more epic ending for Gabriel Belmont.This game has had a lot of criticism because of it's stealth sections. I think they're not bad once you get used to them. However, one think I didn't like is that the Golgoth guards are the strongest characters of all for no reason. And the Agreus garden could be a little less stressing or frustrating in my opinion.The game is very well optimised and runs perfectly.I would rate this game an 8/10. It's very good, but I still think that the first Lords of Shadow game is a little better than the sequel.

												***SPOILER*** No no no... as someone who absolutely loved lords of shadow this game is pretty bad. The futuristic London setting is bland and uninspired, the skill progression feels almost non-existent, the stealth parts are terrible. Example of how completely stupid the stealth parts actually are. They literally consist of turning into a rat, taking over a body, or using bat form to walk right past someone. On top of that the whole these enemies are too powerful for you is complete ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t I mean ♥♥♥♥! you destroy satan and all of his acolytes yet you literally get one shot by some random minions where the ♥♥♥♥ is the logic? The half open world is stupid I don't feel like I'm on an epic journey like I was in lords of shadow one, instead I feel like im running to 3 different wings of the lamest city. This is what killed this game for me and the ending(BIG SPOILER). The entire game Dracula had a goal in which he would help kill satan and then recieve what he has wanted for one thousand years which is death. The ♥♥♥♥ing ending to this stupid game is him looking into the mirror of fate crushing it and saying fate will tell what happens from here and he walks away and the game ♥♥♥♥ing ends. The only redeeming quality of this game is when you are in Dracula's castle, the outstanding sound track, and the boss fights. I don't recommend this game for anyone looking for a good story/ending to lords of shadow.Edit: To all those reviews saying stop comparing it to lords of shadow 1. How the ♥♥♥♥ Can people not compare a direct sequel that claimed to be improving apon the bad things in lords of shadow one and concluding the epic journey of the lords of shadow franchise.

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												  Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 should be the shining example of how not to do a sequel. The first Lords of Shadow game was a successful reimagining of the Belmont clan's eternal war against Dracula, with a solid combat system and gothic story that ended on a cliffhanger that easily teed up a continuation that would just have to stay the course to be enjoyable. Instead, MecurySteam seems to have dug deep to unearth the worst parts of the original, then added a pile of steaming♥♥♥♥♥♥on top of it.   I've never played a game that was so hellbent on taking control away from the player as this one. You start out in Gabriel's throne room, fighting back an invading army of armored foes. Every few steps you take, the game pauses to display tutorial text detailing moves you have available. It's a standard introduction to the controls, I thought, that's fine... Then I arrived at a section that required platforming, which was excellent in the prequel. Here, swarms of bats appear on handholds, and you just jump bat point to bat point, with no rhyme or reason to how high/far Gabriel can jump; often where you're jumping is completely off screen or doesn't make logical sense, you just jam jump to follow an arbitrary bat path. The movement in general just feels very stiff, linear, and unreliable. The camera is much too close to the character when “exploring”, and trying to jump a two foot gap could mean death in one instance, but you're deftly performing acrobatic leaps when the game wants you to...   Lords of Shadow 2 is more movie than game. After about the two hour mark of barely controlling the character, watching intolerably long cutscenes, taking two steps forward then triggering another obnoxiously long cutscene, I tried to grin and bear it, holding out hope that the game was setting the scene and would go off the narrow rails later. I was wrong. The reliance on movies to fill out the play time is persistent for the entire game. A few minutes of control, fighting a few small, easy demons... ten minute cutscene. Fight a boss for five minutes... ten minute cutscene. And the story is miserable; part emo, Dracula wants to kill himself, and part cartoon/anime cringe-y, Dragonball Z trash, every story beat somehow manages to be stupider and less cool than the last.   On the off chance you aren't watching a cutscene, you're presented with a poorly designed, fake open world to explore. It's only “open” in the sense that you can theoretically move among the levels at will without loading into them, but good luck with that. The environments are these super tight, twisting, confusing to navigate messes that's don't connect logically, and you're often forced to hit switches and wait for load-hiding mini-cutscenes to play out before you advance. It didn't take long before I completely abandoned any desire to look for optional power ups or secrets and just wanted to rush through the main path as quickly as possible. And even that can be a nightmare...   And then you'll hit the stealth sections. Oh, boy. They are really bad. Putting aside the idiotic narrative leaps where Gabriel can rip the heart out of a skyscraper-sized demon in one scene but will cower and automatically fail if a Strogg spots and shoots him the next, it's just a horrible, tacked on mini-game that you're forced to endure six times too many. Like the rest of the game, these horrible tests of patience expect you to play like a robot, using what powers they want you to use when they want you to use them. Experimentation is discouraged; there were a few instances where I thought I was pretty clever and found shortcuts around the unnecessarily long path they laid out, only to run into invisible walls or nonsensical fail states. You can transform into a swarm of rats if you activate set “dark spots” (because apparently Dracula is shy) which seems neat, but you're forced to watch more canned animation play out every time you do this, and you're often tasked with following a glowing skull bread crumb trail through narrow, linear vents, which is about as much fun as it sounds.   The one thing Lords of Shadow 2 has going for it is the visuals. I guess throwing player agency to the wind has it's perks, because the artists had the time to make a beautiful game. The demon and boss design in particular is excellent and creative. From fighting a Guillermo del Toro looking, tentacle-headed scientist to battling Satan riding a flying Cthulhu worm, the unique monsters and reimagined classic foes are pure, inspired eye candy. This ends the positive things I have to say about the game...   The “Ultimate Edition” includes all of the DLC, including a mode called Revelations that I think lets you play as Alucard in a new set of single player missions. I can't say for sure, because I didn't play it. I honestly couldn't wait for this game to be over so I could delete it off of my hard drive and be done with it. That might not be much of a review, but Lords of Shadow 2 isn't much of a game.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												I can't even explain how pumped I was for this game. I watched all the trailers over 30 times at least and got kinda obsessed over it, but then release day came. I started playing and it was a great game! Smooth combat which improves a lot over LoS 1. There are many moves for all weapon types and with each mastery level, the weapon's effectiveness improves. The enviroments are stunning (plus with the free camera, you can enjoy them more), and with the HD texture pack only available on PC, the games was absolutely amazing and showed what PC's can do that consoles can not. I enjoyed the game quite a lot infact, but the story did seem dumbed down, especially the ending (won't spoil it for you and besides, it's my opinion on the ending). The modern day city was refereshing, but got a bit boring after going through the same area's multiple times during many missions. The stealth mission's are not exactly as good was Splinter Cell, but they are alright in their own way. Characters in this one seemed a bit bland as well, even Alucard and Gabriel. The only part I enjoyed in terms of characters was the Carmilla part, other than that, the story was pretty dull in most areas. After all, Dave Cox did say that we were going to get an epic, emotional ending as well. I'll just list pro's and con's on my view:Pro's:Great combat system! Way better than that of LoS 1.Beautiful enviroments (just a bit repetitive).Great QTE's for boss fights.Soundtrack is absolutely one of the best I have ever heard in a video game!The free-camera.Pretty cool boss fights.Con's:The story was pretty bland compared to the first one.Characters seemed to not be that interesting either (Except Alucard, Gabriel, Zobek, Marie, Carmilla and maybe Victor) Mainly the acolytes and Satan (Dave also stated we'd see how Satan progressed as a character. Didn't really see that at all).Some enviroments are boring when you keep having to go through them all the time.Not too many enemy types actually. I came across about 10-15.Stealth isn't the best either.The difficulty has been lowered down in this game as well compared to LoS 1.Final Verdict for me:Personally, I'd give it a 7 maybe 8/10. The ending wasn't all the good in my opinion, others may disagree. I think the game was pretty over-hyped, but most games are these days to be honest. I would definitely recommend buying this game, but don't expect as much a story as LoS 1. Combat was lovely though as well as the climbing buildings, wires and lamposts etc. I only ever got to use the dragon form once though (found it rare to find fragments of the medallion). Overall, if you loved the first one and MoF, get it! If you found LoS 1 and MoF a bit boring and bland, this game may not be for you then. I personally enjoyed 80% of it, but I feel that it will be another year or 6 months until I replay it.

												Just finished the entire game and I've to say, I quite enjoyed it. The story is definitely not something to be amazed at but it does have its moments. The gameplay is nice, your powers have multiple uses. Combat is amazing and the difficulty level is just about right. I played it in normal. The game is also visually very impression, however, Dracula's hair is kinda♥♥♥♥♥♥looking, that was my only problem with the graphics honestly.My only real complaints with this game is that there's♥♥♥♥♥♥tons of QTEs in the game, you even have QTEs while opening doors! However, QTEs can be disabled in the options menu. Also, Keyboard mapping is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, the game doesn't tell you that to change the book's pages you need to use Insert and Delete. I had to randomly press all my keyboard buttons to figure that one out because it's not even written in the configuration menu. If you're playing with QTEs "on", the game will not tell you which button to press in the keyboard but will rather tell you which button to press on the gamepad, so you're always looking at the options menu in order to figure out which buttons to press. (For easy access to the keyboard layout, press F1 while in-game.)Cons: QTEs everywhereGame is not keyboard and mouse friendlyPros:Great Graphics.Okay-ish storyline, the game does have it's high moments but it's rare.Good hack and slash combat with proper difficulty settings.The game definitely does not hold your hand but you can adjust it that way.There are demons with boobs!

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Debilitatingly disappointing. I can't stand this crap pile of code. The story is excruciatingly slow. The dialogue is awkward and is comprised mostly of overly-exaggerated acting.The graphics are sub-par. Even on the highest settings on a newer high-end Samsung plasma TV and a gaming PC equipped with SLI'd GTX 780 Ti's, I am reminded more of a PS3 game than a PC game. After much experimentation with the graphic settings, I have come to the conclusion that they used motion blur to cover up the shortcomings and inadequacies of their game engine. Motion blur has clearly been implemented to bridge and smooth the gaps between stuttering frames rather than to create a more realistic sense of motion. (Turn off motion blur and you'll see what I mean.)The combat gameplay is utterly terrible. Gabriel is incredibly sluggish for being the badass that he's supposed to be. The camera angles are unmanageable and frequently interfere with the direction of your attack. Even the minor improvement after you disable the "Combat Assist Camera" setting, you are still left to struggle against some unidentified form of 'aim-assist' that frequently targets random objects to your sides and behind you rather than the bad guys - which is completely infuriating.On that note, let's talk about enemies. Enemies are as cheap as they come. Their attacks will always interrupt yours where, conversely, your attacks rarely ever interrupt theirs. To make matters worse, the enemies constantly rely mostly on their 'unblockable' attacks. They are so frequent that fighting multiple groups of monsters results in more dodging and - invariably - dying over and over again rather than a well-balanced challenge. The unblockables are either back-to-back or followed up by a second attack that changes oblique angles to follow Gabriel in more of a 'homing' fashion. All of this requires a lot more room to maneuver than is often provided.Forget blocking. It worked well in the first game but here, blocking is inconsistent in success.Worse still; as you progress through the game, you are faced with armored enemies whom you can not damage until you fist-pound the armor off of their bodies with the chaos claws. (This supposedly makes the armor "hot" until it either shatters...OR the AI decides that it's too hot to wear - at which point they strip it off.)Attacks don't just glance off of the armor. They bounce off. This makes targeting the lesser enemies around an armored enemy IMPOSSIBLE as your blows land squarely on the armored enemy rather than on any of the non-armored enemies. This makes fighting infuriating as you can't target the armored enemy without having to constantly avoid the attacks of the lesser enemies and vise versa. (Again, most of these attacks are unblockables.)It is also obvious that the developers generate challenge in the game using cheap methodology. The whip's reach is ridiculously short and enemies purposefully stay just outside of it's range. The sword and claws are nearly useless as they are limited on usability due to rapidly-drained energy meters which must be saved for various tasks. It's also irritating that ground attacks still catch you in-air - despite what basic relativity/logic would otherwise dictate.The bosses are ridiculous with typical lather/rinse/repeat tactics. Many of their attacks feel cheap and, at first, unavoidable. (Again, Gabriel is ridiculously sluggish.)Also... Why is a terrible creature such as Dracula spending so much time skulking in the dark as a rat? LAME.Then there are the little maze/stealth 'puzzle games' you play with various main story characters. (Carmella, Agreas (Pan's brother,) etc.) Here, you have to sneak through the areas unseen as the characters hunt you with intent to kill you on sight. These are incredibly irritating. This is NOT what Castlevania games are about. The controls are difficult enough but these control difficulties are highlighted during these maze/stealth puzzle games.All of this does little more than to make your character seem weak and not AT ALL like someone who once defeated the most powerful foes the world's history has ever known. This is unforgivable.It definitely wasn't long into the game to realize that it's an atrocity. Not only does it quickly prove you right, it actually makes you realize that you underestimated it's terrific level of crappiness. It's definitely the type of game that makes you wonder in fury if the studio has ever heard of "quality assurance." ("Did they even PLAY the damn game after making it!?")NOTE: Dying finds you having to re-watch all videos and re-gather all items you find unless you passed a save point - including shards that increase your stats. (WHY, Mercury Steam? WHY!?)Don't feel bad if you finally give up on playing this crappy game and resort to Googling the videos to finish Gabriel's story instead. Trust me. I should have. It's NOT worth the time it takes to play it.This game is GARBAGE

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Finally, a 3D Metroidvania that does the series justice. This game is packed so full of homage to classic CV its ridiculously cool. Gameplay is similar to the first game, but much tighter. 'Useless' moves were removed, now every move in your arsenal has a point and purpose. The new movesets for the Void Sword and the Chaos Claws are excellent and diverse, they have a distinct different 'feel' as opposed to simply being light and dark powers.A true Castlevania fan will appreciate how far the series has come in this conclusion to the LoS story. Don't listen to the butthurt Igavania fanboys who are seriously the cancer killing the series. There are merits to both 2D and 3D CV's and this game fully delivers the 3D CV real fans have been waiting for.Oh, and ignore the paid reviewers who are butthurt they didn't get a paycheck, or simply suck too hard at REAL games to actually get far enough to form a proper unbiased opinion. It shouldn't even need to be mentioned though, anyone with a fraction of a brain knows to ignore 'professional' reviewers nowadays.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												I'm not sure I'm playing the same game as review sites are, this is a great game for fans of the first one. There's plenty of opulent set pieces to go with the same emphasis on defensive, carefully paced combat, alongside newly added incentive to try and vary the attacks you use long term to upgrade the power of your weapons. There are a few samey corridor pieces and a few poorly executed "stealth" puzzles, but for the most part the game is whips and platforming. If you liked LoS1 and/or Mirror of Fate there are very few reasons you wouldn't like this. Protip: Golgoth guards will spot you when they are standing still, so creep up behind them only when they start moving.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Truly an upgrade to the first game, LoS2 brings a nice change of pace. The gameplay itself is solid, responsive and platforming isn't a chore like it was in the first game (fixed camera and 3D should never mix). The enemies are a nice change of pace, forgoing the traditional fodder spam in previous Castlevania games and the removal of the "Grab is the only attack that matters" is nice. Given the track record of 3D Castlevania games, this one is a leap in the right direction. The puzzles are a nice touch, not too difficult and quite creative.That being said, there are parts in the game that will cause you grief. Wandering around the city looking for an objective is tedious and frustrating, especially when the enemies continously respawn. The stealth mechanics are either stupidly easy or very cheap (I have developped a hatred for the fall season). And certain parts of the game will not give you an indication of what is required until you die (and a tip appears on the game over screen).All in all, the game is decent and will cater to fans similar games (God of War, Dante's Inferno, Devil May Cry, Bayonetta) and maybe Castlevania fans (if they are open to the 3D element). Unfortuately, the game's frustrating componants may deter players new to the genre. If the gameplay issues could be adressed, this game could truly be considered the stepping stone for 3D Castlevania games.

												Pay little attention to the Reviews out there giving this game 5's and 6's. I find it hard to understand the harsh reviews this game has gotten so far, i am about half-way thru the game and it just keeps getting better. here are my obdervations so farWhats Great:+ Game is Gorgeus! lives up to the amzing looks of the 2d castlevania's+ The Combat system is satisfying and a vast improvement over the previous LoS+ Boss fights are intresting everytime and i am loving the enemy designs+ Enviroments in the castle are stunning and detailed (many a time did i stop to gawk at statues)+ Fantastic soundtrack (I still miss the symphonic metal of the old games but this is still pretty good)+ Being the final chapter in the LOS series the story from all those games is paying off and cant wait to see how it unfolds+ Open world enviroment is back!, the first LoS was more of a level based game while this one tries to stick to its roots of open exploration via powers and items unlockedWhats not so Great:+ Stealth sequences (who put this in my castlevania game?)+ Modern time setting feels out of place and unexciting (I get sad everytime i leave the castle)+ Needs a more detailed overworld mapOverall i am excited to finish it and i hope this game does not go unnoticed due to mediocre reviews as many other steam users here seem to agree with me that this game is worth at least your time to try the demo. And if you enjoyed the first LoS there is no reason not to enjoy this one.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												This game gets a 6.5/10 - but the revelations DLC gets 8/10If you love vampires (the kind that don't sparkle) then there is really no way to exclude this from your collection, because  when it comes down to it, this is a high budget vampire action game. Whips, swords, claws, and excellent cinematography within the world. Its the first vampire game I've ever played where you truly feel like an immortal being, and time passes in an almost dreamlike way. I personally loved the the parts of the game (about half) spent inside Dracula's Castle, especially walking outside amongst the frozen ramparts with those beautiful gothic spires in the distance, fighting Knights and such. (The whole time not entirely sure whether this castle is an actual place, or it was destroyed and you are simplying battling through your mind palace to reclaim lost memories) If thats the sort of thing that appeals to you, then this game is worth every penny.The other half of the game is set inside a futuristic post apocalyptic earth; it feels kind of like you're playing a dungeon in "The Secret World" - not badly done, just a strange break of character to fight flying riot police with machine guns after fighting knights in a castle.The reason I rate this game, especially the original, so low, is because the story and character progression feels like a PS2 game. It is extremely linear; there is very little in the way of character customization or side storylines. The other reason, and this is the main reason, is that the instructions are often very vague and have only one very specific trigger to complete an objective, so you often spend time puzzle solving something relatively mundane. I personally had to look up how to do a lot of things, and it was frustrating. There is also a lot of climbing in the first one for some reason. About 20% of the game feels like a Guild Wars 2 jumping puzzle or an Assassin's Creed exploration mission. Revelations adds a couple of mechanics to shorten this process, but it can still be annoying.End result is, the more you like vampires, the more you will like this game.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												A very fun game in the same vein as the original Lords of Shadow, but with the added bonus of the ability to turn off QTE events. Even then, the QTE events are nothing more than timing based. No random button crap that forces you to watch Zeus kill Kratos 60 times in a row like in the end of God of War 2. Good points of this game - Can turn off QTE'sFun CombatInteresting StoryLore of the Loregasm varietyBad points- Menu system is a bit wonky, as you can't access the main menu without loading into your saveTwo major stealth sections that are far more difficult than they need to beItems are a bit of a pain to find if you can't remember where they were when you come back for themAll in all I'd consider this a very good game, an 8 out of 10.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												Did you like LOS 1? Then you might like this game too.Now where to begin, the combat system for this game is still pretty good, that is if you enjoyed how it was in LOS 1. The art is even better and the visuals for the game itself are as it predecesor, flawless. The story is 7/10 compared to the original LOS game and the game is shorter than the original. The boss fights are a joke. LOS1 had some cool fights, so does this game, but in terms of difficulty it doesnt even compare. If you played "The Forgotten One" DLC for LOS1 and enjoyed that as I did, you will be massively disappointment with the amount of challenge these bosses in LOS 2 gives out. Pros+ Great Visuals+ Alright story+ Good combat system+ Light/Dark Power has been redone a bit, making it more fun+ More configurationCons- The game is short- Incredibly weak bosses- Low amount of puzzles - Game feels rushed - Probably the last LOS game we will ever seeOverall I'd recomment it, but only so you can see more of the "Belmont" storyline.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Let's just get one thing straight; Lords of Shadow was my personal GoTY. Whilst I will admit that it had its foibles, overall I enjoyed it more than any other game I played that year. After spending some time with LoS2 I can already say that this is more of the same, so if you liked the first game then you will like this and vice versa. The game looks simply amazing, there's no denying that.The gameplay is almost identical to LoS but with a few tweaks. You now have a free roaming camera; This makes sense, as whilst the game world is stil split into distinct areas, you have the freedom (of a kind) to move between them as you see fit, and having a free camera lets you search around levels for all of those secret hideaways and stashes. As I just mentioned, the game world this time round is a much more open one. There are a ton of secrets and upgrades to find. Some of the things that made some people dislike LoS return, though they aren't deal breakers (platforming is still ropey and sometimes you think (can) jump to ledges only to "bounce" off them and fall into some lava or a pit and have to restart your platforming. The game starts off slowly but then builds pace nicely. The combat is almost identical to LoS (no bad thing).There are however some annoying things; "cheap" shots by enemies that are way off screen, unlbockable and sometimes un-dodgeable attacks and the way enemies will keep you in their fight area if you try to run/climb your way out of a fight. Most annoying.Seeing as this game is around £40-£50 on consoles I would definitely recommend getting on PC. Grab yourself an Xbox controller, ram up the graphics settings, sit back and enjoy another lengthy epic adventure (with minor quibbles (and they ARE minor)) with Gabriel Belmont AKA Dracula.Considering how EPIC the finale of LoS was, I can't wait to see how this one (as the end of the LoS storyline) pans out.

number of helpful: 16 of 35 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												I loved the first Lords of Shadow and I'm a fan of Castlevania in general. But I can't recommend Lords of Shadow 2. Gone are the sweeping vistas and gorgous colorful scenery of the first LoS, now it's all drab grays of a gothic city and a gothic castle. Even Patrick Stewart can't say the rediculous lines he's given with any gravitas. Which was a problem in the first game but is even moreso in the sequel. Further, the stealth sequences are shoehorned in and are very clunky. Dracula can take down giant gorgon monsters, combat mechs, and blood golems, but he can't handle some jerk in a suit with a grenade launcher.The plot meanders about, spending alot of time introducing characters who'll never be seen outside of their introduction until it finally mercifully ends on an anticlimatic note. The combat is good, if somewhat shallow, but the platforming is floaty at best. On the whole, you should wait for the steam sale before getting this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												After I have Let's played Castlevania Lords of Shadow 2 on my channel, I can give you a clear and accurate review on to this game. While this is no review in video form, I still hope to give you as much information as you desire.The storyline in Castlevania Lords of Shadow 2 is both gripping and compells you to keep playing the game. It is fun to explore further and further. As the story becomes more clear, the more you wish to play.The gameplay of the game is rather smooth even though it could use some tweaking. This is nothing that will stop you from enjoying the game as it is though.The bossfights are always different. They are never the same. needless to say - they are fights - but unique in their own approach to storyline and gameplay.The relatively vast, open world offers you the possibility to venture through the world of Castlevania nearly freely. You can find upgrades, goodies, best challenges and be furthermore amused by books and scrolsl scattered throughout the game that give you both helpful info on upcoming encounters and on the story of the game.The level design can be -very- frustrating at times. But if you are willing to look past that and can accept the graphics as they are, which as a lovely footnote here - they are not bad at all, then I would say you have a good game on to your hands in which you can sink several hours without regretting your purchase.The only downside is the lack of support for keyboard and mouse. The keyboard and mouse controls have not been translated and you will find XBOX Controller instructions in the game. But once you have learned how to control Castlevania, then you should be able to master it just well.I give this game a 70 out of a hundred. This is a good score for the game itself. If the port had  been better, than the score would surely be higher.Thank you so much for reading. I hope this game review was helpful for you.If you feel like watching it for yourself before playing it, feel free to visit my channel at youtube.com/Shengame

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												5/10tl, dr version: A cash in on the franchise one more time.Awful story that has ruined the heart of Castlevania as a game franchise. Decent graphics and responsive gameplay, but heavily mired by a flawed combat system. Still perhaps worth getting if on sale for the mindless smash enemies combat. Great voice acting from the main actors, but less should have been put in to the voice acting and instead spent on developing a real story that respects the franchise mythology. Big thumbs up, the scourge of modern games, QTE's, can be disabled permanently.Long Version:StoryAwful to put it simply, it's a train wreck. Castevania is at its heart a conquer the castle and kill Dracula game, this "re-origin" story series has just wrecked that with taking away everything that is Castlevania in exchange for trying to dramatise the backstory of Dracula to make him a tragic hero; with an overwhelming judeo-christian mythology shoehorned in to dominate the mythological aspects whereas previously the series was only very loosely tied to any particular mythology. The whole story was just 'Ugh, it's the devil is the bad guy story, how original...push that religion on us even more'.We are meant to believe the city is built on the ruins of Castlevania (dont even get me started on that nuke effect taht was shown large enough it would have destroyed several ENTIRE EUROPEAN COUNTRIES), and the devils kids would use that spot to try bringing about their dad's return...ofcourse. Use the site your ancient enemy is at his most powerful as your base of operations.....yep, perfect sense. Major plot holes exist *spoiler* e.g. Zobek could have read Drac's mind to discover his deception unless he lost his memories, but Zobek couldnt realise that his lieutenant had been replaced by Alucard by, oh I dont know...reading his thoughts....yeah, sure. I call ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. The deal with Castlevania itself is never really clarified, is the castle real and split off from the modern era dimension, or just a figment of Drac's fragmented mind....Major problems arise with the story regardless of which it is.The story is jsut a cavalcade of bad ideas. GameplayTight controls that function decently for getting around and in combat. Probably the aspect of the game that is most positive. The grappling aspects are a disappointment, see that you can only use fixed grapple points to get around, instead of simply making anything that is like a ledge able to be hung from, and the game is loaded with invisible walls which is hugely disappointing for exploration. The game is heavily walled in and you will find that you are limited to very selective above street level areas, and street level, if you want to go explore over the rooftops of the city like some real badass vampire god, forget it, go buy a copy of Batman arkham city, a game which did city exploration properly.CombatThe combat is broken down into mobs using 3 types of attacks: range, melee blockable, and melee/range unblockable.You have 3 weapons, a whip, sword adn claws. All with varying utility, the whip is a mid range weapon that is usable for building up 'focus' which when you hit 100% then attacking enemies will cause them to drop little gems that can be absorbed for magic power for your sword or claws, this only works with the whip though so you will spend a lot of time using it. Void sword burns magic and leeches life on hit, while the claws also burn magic but deal high damage and destroying shields and armour. The shields and armour♥♥♥♥♥♥was a terrible implementation, mobs can stand there blocking forever if you dont destroy the shield or armour, forcing you to use the real core combat mechanic, "timed counters" where you hit L2 at the right time in their swing to block an attack and stun them for a second and smash away, this builds huge focus so you can get your claws powered up to break the shields, alternateively you can somersault over attacking monsters and smack them in the back, whatever works. Unfortunately unless you are good at it, you are ♥♥♥♥ed, having spent significant time playing dark souls it was♥♥♥♥♥♥easy to time compared to parries in DS, but often if you are using the void sword or claws the actual enemy attacks get obscured by the flashy animations of the glowing weapons that you dont see them, this is a♥♥♥♥♥♥implementation really forcing play where you dont really engage upclose with magic weapons you mainly use a couple of specific moves then go back to the whip.There is though a mechanic of "unblockable attacks", which is a huge flaw in the combat and you are forced to dodge, these attacks are indicated, but seems like lazy design, especially when you come to the bosses who their attacks are pretty much all unblockables or range attacks other than usually 1 blockable melee attack, this menas you can spend boss fights frustrated and magic starved as the range attacks keep you away, and the unblockables are chained so often the fight is 30 seconds of dodging and waiting to get one block and some melee attacks, absorb some magic and hit them a couple times for reasonable damage as the whip does ♥♥♥♥ all. In this way the game lends itself to securing really only a couple of the actual skills for the sword and claws to 'gg no re' your way through the game, namely: Whirlwind for the Void Sword, and Flame Claws for the Chaos Claws. Both expensive to use but when you see them in action it's pretty much a no brainer to use them. You may simply discover the other method which is boss cheese and basically forces you to pop relics such as ensnared demon then go crazy with the inifnite magic while timer counts down (spam those flame claw attacks, for real, ~300 damage per hit on everything), then when it runs out pop the dragon emblem and finish the boss off, takes about 30secs per boss fight, even on PoD difficulty and is almost zero effort (you may have to use the void sword to freeze bosses to spam them hard with the claws).Skipping combat and bypassing trash is often impossible, as pretty much every enemy has some sort of range attack intended to knock you off a hang point if you try to grapple away. Some monsters (the wraith type guys at the end msotly) have ridiculous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t attacks that you cannot do anythign to avoid and hit extremelyhard, as noted, the wraiths, tey have a lightning attack that will hit you from 50 metres away, is practically instant hit and dodging it not really possible as by the time you see it, it is hitting you, and there is no way to defend against it other than popping the sword or claws shield magic. As these creatures fight in packs of 4-6 generally, you can imagine, Drac at max HP has about 300 hp, and lightning hit's for 40 each time....6 of them will kill you in about 3 secs, faster than you can close the distance to get to them sometimes....Also, finally, the camera is terrible, even with "combat assisted", it is awful and seems like it tries to blind spot enemies, and the trash monster scripts seem they are intent on getting behind the camera when they can to hit you in the back. This because truly frstrating when their seems to be no 'free camera' even when assist is off and the camera constantly tries to centre in ways that make no sense and you often spend as much time trying to correct the camera so you can see wtf is happening as actually paying attention.DLCRevelations has good puzzles, but disappointingly cruel end boss fight due to endless unblockable attacks and mechanics that dont work with the camera (teleporting behind and unblockable charge).ConclusionIs the game worth buying? Not at full price, it seems like an effort to just milk some more money out of the Castlevania fans who are holding on to hope that each release will be the next Symphony of the Night. Something which the LoD series just hasnt been anything near, ultimately this game is completely forgettable.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												The game was alright overall, but it's a poor man's Arkham game. The story of the main game was interesting and the art style is fantastic, but the gameplay and combat system actually got quite annoying near the end, when trying to get all the collectables.Part of the problem is the level design which is a non-obvious corridor, where areas are separated by a multitude of sluice-gates, elevators, decontamination rooms, etc. It's constant delaying and unnecessary gratuituous animations which get boring rather quick. It takes a very long time to navigate between areas and respawning mobs often prevent you from leaving before you dealt with them, even though you have nothing else to gain from killing them. Once I got the final secret collectible, it took me something like 20 minutes to get to the area where you trigger the final boss encoounter.Unlike the Arkham games where collecting additional content is enjoyable and adds to the experience, the design of the levels actually takes enjoyment away. I would recommend doing a story driven run and avoiding backtracking for collectables and challenges.The music is OK on it's own, but doesn't fill inspired as much as the art style and often doesn't really fit the environemt or add much to the game.The PC port is pretty bad. You pretty much need a controller, as all the button prompts are laid out for a 360 pad. It's much worse than the first game which you could play with KB/Mouse perfectly fine. The game runs well and stable, but it's absolutely impossible to tab out. You need to trigger an automatic save, which often happens between areas, but isn't reliable, and quit the game.Lastly, something that bugged me personally. You frequently either fight or partner up with humnoid characters. They have about 3 phrases each on average and will keep shouting them non-stop. Gets seriously annoying.

												The first game set up the pins for a great sequel. Throw all of that in the garbage, and then set that garbage on fire. Voila!I saw things 1/3rd through the game that made me say "Huh, I need a double jump to get that." You get the double jump at the very end, and then if you want to go back, you have to traipse through a half hour worth of things you already did to get at that not-really-worth it secret. No thanks.

												I have some things to complain about:   1. It is mentioned in the requirements that it is suggested to use a gamepad, but it never mentions that it is impossible to play with the keyboard.  I have configured the control to "keyboard" multiple times, and it invariably reverts to gamepad while playing.  In occassions it is required to pres X, Y, A buttons, and the keys originally configured don't work. It has become frustrating.2. The game is a series of events that are default and the player finds himself only following simple instructions as: press this or that key, without any other consequence than to be able to proceed with the tight story.3. The camera shifts during combat makes it impossible sometimes to know what's happening.4. The combats are so cut by scenes and "must press or do" situations, that it is hard to really enjoy them.I think this could have been a great game if not for these details.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												2 hours in it is unclear wether I still am in the tutorial. I mean, what is this, AC3?The game is ridicously bloated with cutsecenes and the little gameplay you are offered are the sort where you run through linear corridors, scale some ledges and then fight some guys. Some times the camera will even pan in on something important for you, then give you "valuable" hint on how to overcome your struggles. should you happen to die or fail the game will kindly show you everything again. And again. And again.Also, the main character is not evil enough. OK, "ooOOooh" he kills some humans in need of blood, which is as expected from a vampire, but then, as part of the half-hour intro cutscene/"immersive" exposition gameplay he seems all sorry about it, as if he only drinks from the bad, or like he has any kind of sentiment. Gimme a break!Anyways, played it for two hours, felt like I was playing some empty♥♥♥♥♥ soulless game from the nineties and felt like I was wasting my life. Then in an attempt to feel relevant and to justify the squandering of my grains of sand, I wrote this review so you don't have to squander yours.Play something worthwhile,play dark souls.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												This is that type of game that doesn't even know what it's trying to be, in the first part you're fighting in what appears to be a hack'n slash type of third person game, kinda like Devil May Cry, or the modern Ninja Gaiden games, and then all of the sudden it's just you walking around in first person for no reason whatsoever, only to then appear in what seems like an open world, with stealth elements, if you played the demo, and expect something similar to what you got at that point then you're out of luck.The combat system is extremely repetitive, and clunky, the graphics are nice, but every time that i'm enjoying some of them there's either a cutscene that lasts more that ten minutes while saying nothing, or just straight out a quick time event, that you luckily can disable, and i recommend you do, in the options menu in the game.I just didn't enjoy it, i didn't enjoy any of it, i was expecting a hack'n slash game, and instead i got a game that goes up, and down, not knowing even what's supposed to be, only trying to appeal to the lowest common denominator of people that just play games for the sake of playing them, this is a game that's trying with each second appeal to an, any type of audience while never acknowledging it's own, shame.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												I am a fanatical Castlevania fan. I've played every single game to date! (including Simon's Quest) I have kept an open mind about all the different stories and enjoyed every single one. So believe the severity in my words when I say that I *FIRMLY* believe that this game ruined the entire Lords of Shadow series for me. Don't get me wrong! Mechanically speaking, this game is near flawless! (I say "near" because on the hardest difficulty I was alowed to play, I still didn't find it challenging.) The story, however, took my favorite iconic Castlevania characters and just... Ruined them. The first one had a GREAT concept. I liked it! Despite the fact that it really was very "God of War"-ish. The DS "between" game even expanded on the great story they built up towards. BUT THIS ONE TOOK THE GOOD IDEA AND JUST RUINED IT. I want to use much harsher words, but I find reviews that just spew profanity never really seem to hold any weight for anyone. So trust that I want to just use every harsh word in the book at this. Honestly, I wouldn't even recommend this game to anyone who ISN'T a fan of the previous games. The story writing and concept for this game just didn't work in this one.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												A marvel of writing, the part where there's two Maries and Gabriel has to choose between them broke my heart, engaging stealth sections that keep the heart beating as you scurry past the enemy praying they don't notice (This stealth system could give Metal Gear a run for it's money) and let us not forget some of the best city levels ever designed in a video game. I really felt like I was a demon in the night as I slew generic monsters over and over again, but since its satan's army its OK to not have creativity. It's not like the only parts of the game that were of any worth was the toymaker and the prologue. The one thing that will stick with me for the rest of my life was that great ending, I won't spoil it but you kill satan and walk into a church as some kind of christmas music plays. If I may be so bold as to quote a line from this masterpiece"Don't hit me, father!"That line alone should help you decide whether this game is for you which isn't even needed as this game is for everybody.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												The stealth parts are atrocious. Combat is not an option and your weapons are simply removed, the explanation being that you, count ♥♥♥♥ing Dracula, are too weak to fight some lame♥♥♥♥♥baldies wearing what has to be the ♥♥♥♥♥iest looking armor I've seen in my entire life. Boring, mind numbing, badly designed, uninspired, uninteresting, and - most importantly - painfully, PAINFULLY slow paced, these sections of the game are a slap in the face. They make staring at a wall for an hour sound like an up in excitement. Pacing is a general problem, as the game takes control away from the player for WAY too long to play an unnecessary animation or even just display some tutorial text. This makes even picking up gems slightly discomforting, showing the same animation every. single. time. Seriously guys that silly pain box thing got boring halfway through the first animation. The Story is all over the place too. One of two main reasons I tried paying attention and got the basic gist of it was because of  the supreme voice acting. The other was remembrance as well as fondness of the characters due to having played the first game. Something about Gabriel becoming Dracula then getting killed by his son and grandson that don't know they're related and one of them is also a vampire but oh wait they did'nt kill him for real and now he's in the present bla bla bla. At best it sounds like you missed some epic action and get to experience the♥♥♥♥♥♥aftermath.Combat is still amazing, unfortunately I've run into hardly any at all, save for the first section. It looks kinda pretty, some textures seem to be muddy though. This game is so frustratingly bad, it makes me wish the first game had been bad too, so that I wouldn't care. Steer clear, unless your hobbies consist only of staring at walls and you feel like you need something with less action for a change. Then these stealth parts are just for you!
