content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												If you really loved the first one, give this one a try, otherwise go away and don't look back. Here's the detail : The more I think about this game, the less I like it. At first I'd thought that it was a cool sequel, not "super great" but decent, and worth the try if you liked the first one. But in fact to be honest, it's not even half the game that was the first Lords of Shadow.They have removed the Shadow/Light weapon mecanique that forced you to switch during boss fights.Speeking of boss fight, they for most of them have the same paterne with only two phase repeated 3 or 4 time, Phase "Beat the crap out of the boss" and phase "run to avoid the♥♥♥♥♥♥trowed at your face" abd in the end they feel like they are just the first phase of somthing that should be in two or three phase, like what was the boss in the first game.Some of the bosses are "shadow of the colossusish" like in the first episode but it feel forced, like a mandatory thing that the devs have put in the game for no other reason than "it was in the first one". The final one in particular is realy lame in comparaison of the final one of the first episode.And then, there is the "steath" phase, who are juste tedious as hell !And the ending feel like it was ... amputated of a final boss fight.Ho and by the way, I've finished Lords of Shadow in 15h (and dont feel like spending more time in it) where I've spend 25 for the first one.

number of helpful: 21 of 61 people (34%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												The pitiable game design choices prevent the enjoyment of the art and scenario from shining through this intriguing tale of Dracula.Bad design choices? How about displaying the correct keys on the screen for the PC port, instead of still having the XBox controls on screen? Seriously. You can't even turn off the onscreen controller "hints," so I'm fighting a paladin, really into it; he launches an attack. . . I dodge it. . . screen freezes: "whow hey, did you know you can dodge this attack, by pressing the X key on your XBox 360 controller?" I'm already dodging the attack, anyway!! And the game pauses, while I'm in battle, to tell me how to dodge the attack--I've already dodged it anyway--and the instruction isn't even for the right controller!!! In 2014, a majour release title like this, should feature the correct controls when displaying instructions. There's no option to change what controls are displayed, or to just disable when the game displays controller instructions--there is an option you might think would do that: it doesn't. It is an insult to literally the entire gaming community, that a majour video game would not even take the time required to show the keyboard controls onscreen, for their PC release. What does it say about your game, when you do not put forth that level of effort when releasing it?Recommended, absolutely, if you are very interested in the story of Dracula. I am, and I like the game for it, but at least 60% of my enjoyment of that, is burnt away by the frustrating controls and other bad design choices.For example, not too far into the game, you fight through a boss encounter of three strong enemies, and then immediately after, you open a portal to the next area. As soon as I got there, I accidentally opened the same portal again going backwards to where I just came from. I figured it out quickly, however the game would not let me just turn around and continue playing in the realm I portalled to: instead I absolutely had to complete portalling back into the first realm that I started from, where, oh the boss is here again, and oh thanks we just autosaved, and also I now only have a little bit of health and no mana left because I literally just faught this boss 15 seconds ago!! This is a design choice for this game. You can't open the portal until the boss is dead, so I almost quit playing at this point, because I could only survive two hits before dying. This is not how you introduce a new part of your game! Just please don't do this in your game. Like, I even understood that I had accidentally opened a portal backwards, and the game would not let me cancel out of it; and then there's a forced boss encounter before I can open the portal again?  It's just really bad game design. It feels like no one actually sat down and played this game.In another area, you have to get through a high security door. I though "what I'll do is kill that scientist, then the enemy will send another scientist in through that door, and when he enters,  I can rush through the door." No! Because that door is really just an art feature over an invisible wall, and the only way through it is to specifically activate a cutscene. Arhg! You can see through the door when it opens; why would this one door, in the entire game, have an invisible wall behind it? And then you can't really tell: "was I trying to go through that door too early, too late? Did I get stuck on the edge of it maybe. . . ?" You review the hints you have, and it seems like you're doing the right thing. It's frustrating because you're really playing this game against the game designers, and not against any enemies of Dracula. The game encourages you to imagine yourself as Dracula, but if Dracula was really here, then he would just walk through that door.An enemy has an energy shield, which you have to pound away on to break it. If you cease attack, for literally less than one second, then the energy shield completely recharges. So it's difficult to tell if what you're doing is effective, because it's hard to stay on the enemy as they move around, and other enemies in the room try to attack you. Then, do you want to know what happens when you do break through the energy shield? If you do break through the energy shield, then the energy shield completely recharges, looking just like what happens when you stop attacking it. You actually have to break through the shield three times, but the game offers no signal that you're actually having an impact. If you break through the shield, it looks the same as if you failed to break through the shield. This is a bad design choice which I hope I don't have to explain further, but I will: it encourages the player to cease doing the right thing, maybe even leave the area, and try other things--which incidentally won't work. The game offers a difficulty setting, but so far as I can tell, the only difference is that you get more health pickups on easy. It doesn't, for example, make that shield recharge after 2 seconds, so you can break through it without being a super expert fighter. There is an interesting story of Dracula here, but it is wreathed in bad design. Confusion abounds. Fighting is challenging, but difficulty comes from trying to understand what the game expects. A game about Dracula, could be difficult by having strange boss encounters that make you pass unusual trials. You may even think that's what this game is. But I do not think the difficulty present in this game, was intentional. Having a game throw you back against a boss, immediately after you defeat it; without restoring your health, and autosaving at the start of the battle . .  This is not "difficulty" this is "bad design." It is worth playing to experience some of the story of Dracula, but it is not worth playing to see what a good game looks like.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Also. . . to one of the commenters: I didn't write about any crashes. And I'm not using a 360 controller, because I like using a mouse and keyboard: the game actually controlles quite well with a mouse and keyboard, except that all the information in game is for the 360 controller, and then you're like "ooh, what button was it to activate this blood spout?" Then you have to go searching through not one, but two sepearte controller help pages to try and find it, and just, ugh. . .why? Why is it like this???

Posted: October 30, 2016
												I can't believe this game has so many positive reviews. It's total crap. First, the game description forgot to mention one 'detail' - that it's practically unplayable if you don't have a gamepad. Yes, there is an option 'mouse and keyboard', but they did't even bother to change the directions in the game. So every time there's a hint or a new power, you have to stop the game, press F1, and check what are you supposed to press. Plus it's extremely awkard - get ready for A LOT of falling and dying, NOT because the game's difficult but because the controls are idiotic. The game is supposed to be action-adventure, but I'm not sure what the 'adventure' is supposed to be, here. It's all same cheap wannabe dramatic moments, like floor collapsing under your feet - it gets yawningly repetitive within few minutes. There's very little story and the Dracula is about as charismatic and interesting as a loaf of a week-old bread. I wouldn't give this more than 50% - on condition you have the gamepad and like repetitive action.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												So first of all I didn't play the Castlevania series before which means I don't know anything about the GBA/Nintendo etc games.I bought Darksiders -which was in a bundle- and I realy fell in love with the game. Afterwards I got Darksiders 2 and after I finished it aswell I started to search for games which are alike. Someone told me about Castlevania: Lords of Shadows.So I started with Castlevania:LoS (Ultimate Edition) and it was one of the best expiriences I've ever had. The atmosphere, the fights, the mechanics (light/darkness) and the insanelly good music made this game a 9/10 for me. When I finished the game and closed the client I got an announcement by Steam about Castlevania:LoS2 and I was soooooooooo happy.I immediatelly bought it and when it was released, I immediatelly started it.The 1st thing was the "Tutorial" which was epic as♥♥♥♥♥♥ One of the greatest things in my opinion is the new usage of Light and Darkness which is splitt in new weapons (Sword/Gauntlet). I really liked the character development and how much the characters in the game actually changed.I'll be honest. After I played for about 1 hour I was really disappointed about the game. It didn't feel like the 1st LoS and something was missing. I felt that the story was really flat and -maybe- it was the new location which I felt were not fitting the game. And I stopped playing it.After some time passed I started the game again and realized it was the worst mistake ever to stop playing it. #######################SPOILER###########################It's amazing! I love how the game changes all the time. The timetravel and the changes in the locations are amazing. The story of the 1st LoS and LoS2 combine themself very well and makes a lot of sense. The story of LoS2 feels very flat but after I reach a certain point in the game my opinion changed completely. It pretty much change the whole point of view.One of my favourite parts is still the music in this game which fits perfectly.About the gameplay it's really simple to explain. The people who played the 1st LoS won't find many differences. You can still  find containers to increase your life/light/darkness. The 1st difference lies within the skilltree. While you still purchase new combos with the points you gain, your skills level aswell if you use them and you can compile them in your weapon which makes the weapon stronger. This change is really good in my opinion because it was one of the flaws in LoS. The skilltree didn't seem to be important and you didn't really need to unlock the combos becuase you could beat the game with the stadart attack. Now there is at least a reason to use different attacks.A new feature I really appreciate are the challenges which are a small sidekick. You get different challenges where you need to kill enemies within a certain time of do other things.One of the facts that every LoS1 players will love is the camera which you can move completely freely.What else can I add. The bossfights are still really good and the finishing moves are still epic as♥♥♥♥♥♥ the enemys use undodgeable moves more often which makes the fights a bit harder while the overall gameplay didn't change that much from LoS1.I will say it this way: If you liked the 1st LoS and enjoyed it you will like the 1nd one aswell. Give it some time and don't drop it after an hour like me. Play it and see how well it develops.My rating: 8 /10

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												As an avid fan of the Castlevania series, I will say most of the 3D entries have been mostly mediocre.  Some had good ideas marred by poor controls (N64 games) while others had tedious gameplay with excellent music and atmosphere (Lament of Innocence and Curse of Darkness).Then 2010 rolled around and Lords of Shadow came out.  Another 3D Castlevania that I had zero expectations for but still an almost forced obligation to try...and it blew me away.  Amazing graphics, gripping story, phenomenal soundtrack, varied enemy encounters, huge boss fights, and a simple on the surface but surprisingly deep combat system in the vein of God of War (this doesn't have to be an insult, people) gave a shockingly well rounded package that earned the game some high sales and critical praise the series hadn't seen in a long time.  It had its faults, namely a camera that couldn't be controlled and a somewhat slow beginning, but the series seemed to be headed in a positive direction.A few years later we got Mirror of Fate, a sort of in-betweener entry to bind the stories of LOS1 and LOS2.  It also marked a return to the side-scrolling roots with flashes of SOTN style gameplay.  The story was interesting but markedly less central compared to LOS.  Still, the gameplay was mostly interesting, a little different, and again had a wonderful score.With the announcement of certain features like a seamless world and a controlled camera, LOS2 had a lot to live up to.  For the most part it delivers, though it definitely has its flaws.  Rather than continue on with the paragraphs at length, I'll make some easy to peruse pros and cons lists.PROS: -The story is still well told and interesting, voice actors all nail their roles (specifically Robert Carlyle and Jason Isaacs). -The soundtrack is still amazing. -Gameplay remains mostly unchanged, though there is less emphasis on puzzle solving. -Good length, around 15-20 hours depending on how much secret hunting you engage in. -Lots of neat references to classic entries. -Dracula's castle offers some cool, varied areas. -Weapon mastery/skill tree system rewards experimentation and discourages 'spamming.'CONS: -Seamless world exploration is hurt by an incredibly weak map system.  Opening the map in the menu only lets you see a very small portion of the area you are in, and you can't cycle between them.  There are also a scant number of teleportation rooms, making backtracking quite painful. -Difficulty seemed all over the place.  I found most bosses very easy and generally struggled more with the regular enemy encounters. -The modern city you explore has that Gothic Castlevania feel to it, but unfortunately most of the areas are hard to differentiate. -Ending is rather abrupt and anti-climactic.As for the now infamous 'stealth' sections, I can safely say they have been completely overblown in just about every review.  Yes, they are by no means a good part of the game.  However they are very simple and account for less than 45 minutes or so of game time.  Don't let that be what sways your heart on the game.Although it has a few questionable design choices, for the most part I can give a positive recommendation for LOS2.  Arguably one of the best facets of the series is that each game brings something different to the table.  LOS was about the closest we've gotten to a (fun) 3D classic Castlevania, Mirror of Fate was more along the lines of a 2D SOTN/Circle of the Moon type game, and LOS2 was an attempt to merge the two.  None of them are perfect, but the series hasn't been this interesting in over a decade.  I look forward to whatever Mercury Steam does next, and we will see what future Castlevanias have in store for us.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												So first of all I didn't play the Castlevania series before which means I don't know anything about the GBA/Nintendo etc games.I bought Darksiders -which was in a bundle- and I realy fell in love with the game. Afterwards I got Darksiders 2 and after I finished it aswell I started to search for games which are alike. Someone told me about Castlevania: Lords of Shadows.So I started with Castlevania:LoS (Ultimate Edition) and it was one of the best expiriences I've ever had. The atmosphere, the fights, the mechanics (light/darkness) and the insanelly good music made this game a 9/10 for me. When I finished the game and closed the client I got an announcement by Steam about Castlevania:LoS2 and I was soooooooooo happy.I immediatelly bought it and when it was released, I immediatelly started it.The 1st thing was the "Tutorial" which was epic as♥♥♥♥♥♥ One of the greatest things in my opinion is the new usage of Light and Darkness which is splitt in new weapons (Sword/Gauntlet). I really liked the character development and how much the characters in the game actually changed.I'll be honest. After I played for about 1 hour I was really disappointed about the game. It didn't feel like the 1st LoS and something was missing. I felt that the story was really flat and -maybe- it was the new location which I felt were not fitting the game. And I stopped playing it.After some time passed I started the game again and realized it was the worst mistake ever to stop playing it. #######################SPOILER###########################It's amazing! I love how the game changes all the time. The timetravel and the changes in the locations are amazing. The story of the 1st LoS and LoS2 combine themself very well and makes a lot of sense. The story of LoS2 feels very flat but after I reach a certain point in the game my opinion changed completely. It pretty much change the whole point of view.One of my favourite parts is still the music in this game which fits perfectly.About the gameplay it's really simple to explain. The people who played the 1st LoS won't find many differences. You can still  find containers to increase your life/light/darkness. The 1st difference lies within the skilltree. While you still purchase new combos with the points you gain, your skills level aswell if you use them and you can compile them in your weapon which makes the weapon stronger. This change is really good in my opinion because it was one of the flaws in LoS. The skilltree didn't seem to be important and you didn't really need to unlock the combos becuase you could beat the game with the stadart attack. Now there is at least a reason to use different attacks.A new feature I really appreciate are the challenges which are a small sidekick. You get different challenges where you need to kill enemies within a certain time of do other things.One of the facts that every LoS1 players will love is the camera which you can move completely freely.What else can I add. The bossfights are still really good and the finishing moves are still epic as♥♥♥♥♥♥ the enemys use undodgeable moves more often which makes the fights a bit harder while the overall gameplay didn't change that much from LoS1.I will say it this way: If you liked the 1st LoS and enjoyed it you will like the 1nd one aswell. Give it some time and don't drop it after an hour like me. Play it and see how well it develops.My rating: 8 /10

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Fantastic game!   It absolutely lived up to all of my expectations, including the DLC.  It ended, for the most part, exactly how I would have wanted.  It is sad that Mercury Steam will most likely never work with the Lords of Shadow series again, but the story is at least complete and was well done from start to finish.  What more could a fan of great story-telling ask for?It does have some problems here and there, but if you are interested in it due to being a Lords of Shadow fan then your money will be well spent, since you are most likely here for the series' most accomplished attribute, it's lovingly crafted tale.  Otherwise, I suggest doing some more research on it, or maybe even trying the first two games (Don't forget Mirror of Fate) to see if the story grabs you.Either way, my final opinion on this game is that it is a finely polished piece of software that has phenomenal storytelling and an extremely well implemented combat system.  It suffers slightly from some odd gameplay design choices here and there that might be a bit off-putting to some, but this game did not get the attention, nor respect, that it truly deserved.  Hopefully, Mercury Steam will craft something in the future that is not so much the "diamond in the rough" that this game, and it's predecessors, ended up being.  Maybe something with a bit more mainstream appeal, i suppose?  I hope only the best for their future after having finished the Lords of Shadow series and am tentatively awaiting news of their next project.

												if you like the first game, then you will like the second game. the story wasnt anything to write home about, but it wasnt bad either. the combat was very fluid and easy to get the hang of. that said i have two complaints about the game. first is the stealth part of the game, which was often trial and error while dying over and over again trying to figure out what the game wanted me to do. these stealth parts were usually where i took a break from the game as dying over and over again was frustrating because there are no hints beyond the first couple of stealth puzzles. often times the solution involved using an ability in a way that was never talked about (such as the mist power can go through enemies). my second complaint was getting lost in other puzzles for pretty much the same exact reason (such as the revelations dlc you can use the wolf power while interacting with switches). both of these cases were "oh i can do that?" which would have been fine if they were explained better. overall due to its kind of dragged out short story, the stealth puzzles, and lack of information about some abilites involved in puzzles i would give this game a 7 out of 10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												*Edit: When I first wrote the review, I was only almost done with the game, but now that I have seen it through to the end, I feel I have to amend a couple of my points, primarily with the story. The ending sucks. I won't spoil anything, but I must say it was quite a let down. Many unresolved questions and an unsatisfying end both in story and boss fight. It was easier than the first acolyte.Looking at this game from a completed perspective, even before my edit, I can say that this game had a lot of potential and good ideas, but from what I've read had a botched development. It shows because a lot of the game feels incomplete or like the developers rushed to finish what was left after some development troubles. It's really a shame and very disappointing.*I played the first Lords of Shadow and I enjoyed it. As for this one, I would say it's better in some areas and worse in others.COMBAT: Compared to the first, it feels like they really smoothed out the combat in terms of how you move around and perform moves. some difficulties become clearer when it comes to one mechanic though: the way some enemies block in this game. When some enemies are blocking, they stop your combo and deflect your attack and zero damage is done. This can get really annoying when there are multiple enemies and you are attacking one that is open, but the one right next to the first is blocking. it will stop your combo. This makes engagements with multiple blocking enemies really annoying unless you are really good with your chaos energy (it's like the shadow energy from the first game and it breaks through shield and armor). Multiple skeletons are the most annoying thing in this game... That said, thankfully those kinds of enemies don't show up terribly often, and combat can still be very fun now that it's smoothed out.STORY: Sadly, I would have to say the story in this game is inferior to the first overall. There is no longer an opening narration to each stage like their was in the first because of the way they made the map somewhat open world (I'll get into that further down). There are also seems to be less moments of significant plot progression throughout the game; a lot of times it feels as if you go a great distance just to get a small snippet of story. That said, one of the things that brought me back toward liking the game more were the story moments (they pick up more once you get a bit further) when you see the way Gabriel changes based on his interaction with the other characters. Some of them were very moving. Still, overall there just doesn't seem to be as much story as there was in the first game, and for Patrick Stewart in particular, it almost seems like a waste of his talent.VISUALS: For the most part, I'm going to say that this game's visuals are gorgeous. Very pretty and detailed environments. Not a lot of more vibrant environments like the first game, but they are still very detailed and pretty, especially when the game's graphics are turned up. However, i did say "for the most part" because some of the more industrial areas that you explore in the game, particularly the areas with a lot of pipes and wires going along the walls and cielings, are very dull and start to feel repetitive really quickly.MAP SYSTEM: I think they had a good idea when they started this game to give it a more open world feel, but ultimately the traveling around the map gets very tedious, especially when you are backtracking to find all the hidden upgrades, and again in the more industrial areas, it becomes easy to get lost and start traveling in circles when you are looking for certain areas.OVERALL I would say Lords of Shadow 2 is a decent game that you will enjoy for its beauty and decent combat system if you have the patience for the map and sometimes tedious battles with annoying enemies, but I would buy it when the price lowers. Also, if you have a choice, play the first Lords of Shadow before you play the second, it will make your experience with the second. The story will of course make more sense and be more enjoyable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Honestly, i was going through a lot of these reviews, expecially from fans of the first game, and i was surprised by how much negatives came here. So this review will be focused in comparing the two games (I played the first on X360) I will say that, only in my first 2 hours of gameplay, i felt comfortable to rely on the lore for my so expected ending of the story. And i need to point out that this is a great game, regardless of comparations with the first. Also, a lot of these reviews say negative stuff about the stealth moments, but i think it's good and important because you have to acompany the story, if Gabriel lost most of his power, how would he go against a creature of Satan? It's very important to the lore. And i cannot agree to you being a fan of the saga if you don't pay attention to the story. I feel like these moments show me that like in the first game, i had to become strong. Playing all the game with ultimate Dracula powers would be tiring, and most likely ruin the experience.As to graphics, my system is not the best, but what i've seen in my game and videos, it doesn't leave a lot to be wished.I really enjoyed the new mechanics of gameplay, especially Gabriel's (sorry, can't call him Dracula :////) new powers. this really feels like to play the first game, but much more complete than that. Something i dislike strongly is the new combat rythim, i can't get to use special attacks, because i'm 95% busy finding enough time to do so. Also, there are some times when you truly don't know what to do, and you have to perform some action too quickly. I found this very troublesome in some parts.And the camera, oh, the camera. That's something MUCH better than in the first game, when the camera was placed in map-specific locations, and also had the problem of having to stop to ajust your controls, since they were kept on camera changes (40% of camera changes). Now, it's something much more subtle, the camera is controlled by the player, and stays in a 2nd/3rd person view which receives some influence in a few map areas (but nothing that forces the camera on a spot or a too strong change. It feels better because now it gives me the immersion of exploring the world. And of course, this is better because now i feel rewarded for looking for a nice view and finding an amazing view. It's very balanced.I do recommend this game to everyone, best buy, worth all the money (altough i got it on a discount).Please feel free to add me or comment on my profile with any disagreements or suggestions to this review.I wished to give it 10/10, but the gameplay has a few artifacts in my point of view.8.5/10

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												This game had a lot of promise but ultimately felt like a parody of itself. This game was loaded with recycled content including characters that shouldn't have been there - and game mechanics that were random and only served to draw the game out. The load screens were my favorite where Gabriel/Dracula stared thoughtfully into some candlelight while his inner dialogue summed up the most immediate objective. Soft, introspective piano music would play in the background. Then you the accept button and a slashing sound was followed by Gabriel glaring suddenly into the camera... It was over-the-top.The return of his wife Marie was a surprise and a happy one but they failed to tie her presence in to the over-arching arch. The ending was like watch an okay movie where they awkwardly avoid bring closure for the sake of making sequels that you already know are going to be bad. Its a little sad given how well this reboot started.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												I'm going through my second playthrough now under Prince Of Darkness difficulty, and figured I'd write a bit of a review about the game itself.First off, I would have to agree with some people who have posted "not recommended" reviews on the game for a few reasons:  The primary being that the game itself feels entirely too short for it's own good.  In comparison to LoS1 where levels are abundant and the scenery constantly changing as you progress, LoS2 seems to rehash the same areas, in a similar fashion to that of Dragon Age 2.  You spend more time running through the same areas and just gives off a feeling of redundancy throughout the course of the game.  Sure, the areas are pretty huge, but when you need to run through the same areas repeatedly to progress it's more of an annoyance than anything.Groups of enemies seem to perfectly chain their "undodgeable" attacks to seemingly no end.  I'm up for a challenge, but when you're surrounded by a whole group of enemies it's extremtly annoying to constantly be chained from special to special.  Then again, I suppose that's how the NPCs feel so bit of karma I suppose.  The stealth sections truly are a bit annoying.  I understand that they're trying to incorporate a bit more than your run of the mill hack and slash, but there aren't multiple ways to approach them or to resolve them.  Not to mention that if you're spotted, you can pretty much expect to just restart from checkpoint; rarely is there a chance to regroup without taking massive damage.On to the good, as this overall is a recommendation for the game.  Overall, I have to say that I did quite enjoy the storyline, and being able to play as Alucard really gave me some flashbacks to some of the greatest games in the canon.  [Spoilers] The surprise appearance of another Belmont was quite good as well!  The combat system, while much has been leveraged from the first game I quite enjoyed, even if it was a bit repetitive.  There seems to be quite a large focus on countering in this game as opposed to its predecessor, which I don't mind personally.  The new abilities are quite interesting as well, and the upgrade/mastery system keeps you trying to use new attacks against the same enemies you encounter.All in all, I wouldn't agree with the Metascore rating as it does seem a bit low.  Sequels are always tough and when you have a title as solid as LoS1, it's hard to not play second fiddle.  Anyone who is a fan of the series I would think would like the game, and overall it's a good playthrough with the added Kleidos challenges.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												I liked the first and enjoyed this one even more, it's not anywhere as bad as reviews made it out to be but it's still pretty flawed. The combat is good but 80% of the moves you can buy you'll never use since the basic ones are good enough and there's no point in using anything else. The infamous stealth sections act as replacement for the puzzles from LOS1 (of which there are a grand total of 2 this time around) and are very short, few and far between - I don't really remember more than a handful during the entire 13 hour campaign - but at the same time add nothing to the game, they're just "there." If there's one thing I genuinely liked then it was the semi-open world which is very similar to the Batman Arkham series in that you head down a linear path but there's plenty of optional areas with collectibles/upgrades.The storyline is nothing special, and the ending itself is very underwhelming considering it was supposed to be the last installment in the franchise. During the last 2 hours the plot quickly rushes to the end as if developers ran out of time, having you repeat a very simple puzzle 3 times in between a series of cutscenes then fighting two final bosses in a row with nothing else in between. If they had cleaned up the combat system, gotten rid of the stealth sections, fixed the pacing issues at the end and put more thought into the storyline it could've been great, but in the end it's only slightly above average.

												A truly mixed bag. Great in some ways, horrible in others.PROS:-Good, fun combat-Great boss fights which are a lot of fun-Great graphics-Castle environments are fantasticCONS:-Terrible writing/story-Extremely 'samey' with LoS 1, right down to some of the exact same movesets with the whip. For a sequel that took 3 years to come out that's a little inexcusable.-Modern environments are bland. They're supposed to feel gothic-modern, almost like something out of V:tM, but instead they just feel like they were ripped right out of Darksiders.-Some stealth sections are bad. Others are fairly straight forward and just serve as puzzles.The medeival setting of the first game worked so well, they should have continued it in this game.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												I wouldn't necessarily consider this game to be an upgrade to the first one.  While it had it moments, which for the most part came from the storyline, I was disappointed by the open world concept that was completely hyped by marketing.  Of course if you love mazes, I say go for it!  The game play was another upgrade, as far as controlling Gabriel Belmont is concerned.  The different powers that you pick up during the game add a fun challenge to break up the hack-and-slash that the first game depended too much on.  I think, unfortunately, that the developers listened to too many people while they were in the creative process, and it caused a bit of a mess.  Overall, I still liked the game, though I would have just as impressed if it was simply a movie.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												When I first saw the reviews come out for this game I was a little worried, though I did really enjoy the first Lords of Shadow a few years back. Bought the game anyway and surprise, it's the reviewers being crap at games and reviewing again. LoS2 is, like LoS1, a game that takes the best parts of various action games like God of War and it works out great as a result. Dracula is a great choice for a protagonist and is made a much better character than his main Castlevania counterpart in both abilities and personality. The story isn't too weak either, it's there, it does the job so you can't complain either.A lot of complains were aimed towards the stealth sections in the game, sure this seems like an odd decision but it works, and despite what reviewers say, it's not as inhumanly hard or excessive as they say. There's probably 5 stealth sections overall, they're all incredibly brief and are there to act as a bit of variety to prevent fatigue from constant fighting smaller enemies. Although it is easy to see why reviewers proclaimed the stealth section involving Agreus as the scourge of gaming, it requires you to use multiple skills you have gained so far, but the game doesn't tell you. Thinking is too hard for reviewers after all.Overall, Lords of Shadow 2 is a solid game and definitely deserved a better reception than what it got.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												This was my first Castlevania game so I went in not really knowing what to expect. First of all, the combat's fun, not played many hack'n'slash games and this made me wonder why, it's incredibly satisfying pulling off that perfect combo right after a successful synchronized block. Only real criticism I have of the combat is that there's not much of an incentive to try the special moves. When a game's this simple to beat and the enemies aren't overly difficult, nothing really forces you to have to pull off the special attacks, and you find yourself halfway through wondering if you're really getting the full experience because of your lack of variation in how you play combat-wise. Can't really comment on the exploration, as I've really no idea what makes someone want to explore a game world, some open worlds make you want to explore - some don't. I have no idea if it's to do with art style or hidden secrets, but I definitely wanted to explore the castle and find every secret there was to find, found myself spending hours just exploring different areas. Graphics-wise, this game looks amazing - found myself pressing F12 way more than I probably should have been, and I've changed my desktop to different screenshots about 5 times since I bought this game. The gothic architecture of the castle really gives the developers a chance to pull off some of the most stunning scenes, last-gen ports have never looked so good. Although I've never played the first LoS, I kinda felt myself wondering how great this game would be if it had the same setting, medieval Europe. I really dreaded the modern day parts of the game, the city was boring - everything looked the same, spent most of it hoping I'd see another castle sequence soon. Voice acting was great, can't really go wrong with a cast like Richard Madden, Robert Carlyle and Patrick Stewart, although when voice actors so famous play roles you can't help but see them as the actor as opposed to the character, because you've heard their voice so many times before. Characterisation wasn't the best, I wanted to see a Dracula that didn't start tearing up everytime he was reminded of his past, and he didn't really develop much throughout the story. Not going to go too into depth about stealth, all I'm going to say is that it was terrible and I'm glad it wasn't more prominent in the game. Story-wise, this game's brilliant, sometimes when the combat became a bit too repetitive and I was stuck in the city knowing I wouldn't see another medieval-esque area for a while, I was just hoping another cutscene would occur. The whole father-son dynamic between Trevor and Gabriel was really well-written and enjoyable to listen to, and although I complained about him being too emotional, I really liked the parts that Gabriel's human side showed in the scenes with his family. Boss fights were one of my favourite parts of the game, it was different every time and it forced you to adapt to the situation as opposed to just hitting and dodging, only criticism is that the dialogue during the fights could be improved as I heard the same line over 50 times when fighting some bosses. Can't really think of any other elements of the game to comment on. Overall I'd say this game is definitely worth getting - not got much replayability but the first playthrough is worth the money. Despite its many drawbacks like stealth and poor setting - the art style, voice acting, combat and story do more than enough to make up for it.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Not without its faults, but still quite enjoyable.After playing the full game. I certainly do not feel it deseved such low critic scores. Are there some issues, of course. But on the whole, I still had fun with it, and that's what it all boils down to. If you want some handy bullet points on the matter:Pros:* Combat is very fluid, and there are a number of attacks and options at your disposal* The Boss battles are the real showstoppers in terms of granduer and excitement, and are the high points of the game, and each one of them is unique.* Platforming is also very fast and has definitely been streamlined from the original* The Castle setting is simply beautiful and really makes the player want to explore it* Game is super optimized and runs amazingly well on most machines. Played at 1080p with all settings maxed at a constant 60fps* The musical score is just so well put together and a treat to listen to, fitting the action on screen perfectlyCons:* The game starts off slow after the prologue, focusing a lot on the modern day section* The modern day section is sadly lacking in terms of creativity and imagination. Was expecting something more unique from a modern day Satanic laboratory (especially compared to Frankenstein's Lab or the Toymakers Workshop from the previous games) for instance. * Most time in the modern day is spent underground or in corridors, opposed to the more visually pleasing areas such as the Arts District.* The Stealth sections needed more variety to be interesting, or should have been limited to just a few segments. Though they still only take a few minutes to do. Too much of a big deal was made about one stealth segment in particular, only because people forgot about the handy Mist ability.* The ending is somewhat inconclusive and the final segment leading up to it lacks any real sense of build up.

Very entertaining and now I'm sure my wife would like to have some of my time back in the evenings.

												What can I say?  I loved the first game.  I felt they did a great job rebooting the series and breathing new life into it.  While I loved the old games story wise they sucked.  Even lament of innocence which was great and tried its best to explain the belmont & dracula feud still lacked a little bit.  Now Lord of Shadow did a great job of really giving that belmont dracula feud a purpose and reason.  This game picks up right from the first game and really starts to breath life into dracula and with great story telling elements and voice acting really connects the players to dracula and kinda makes us question is her really that bad.  Maybe he has a good reason for being♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥People will pick apart the game play and the stealth mode.  I didn't enjoy the stealth mode but I did enjoy the combat system and loved using his new powers.  I loved the leveling up of the weapons and skills.  The items you pick up on the way I felt were just wasted I never used anyone of them expect of the health potion.The environment was good.  I enjoyed my time in the Castle but didn't care for the modern world.The important question is should I buy this game?  I think so but not at the full price.  The reason why is because of the ending.  The game really built things up with scenes of Dracula kinda coming back into the light and forgiving himself and redeeming himself in his own eyes.  This was great and really connected me to him even more.  The ending just kinda flopped there like a fish out of water.  It didn't wrap anything up or raise any question of whats next like the last game.  It was disappointing.  The fight with satan wasn't as tough as it was in the first one.  I kept thinking to myself he got beat the last time hit the gym and came back buff, but his old cross fitter body was better.  They need to give this game a proper ending if this really is the final game.  If they don't then all of that great work to just end on a bad note.So final thought great story, but buy at half price due to the lack of a ending.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												The game received unjust hate from many reviewers, citing poor story, stealth mechanism and not being open world enough.Now, if you liked the first Lords of Shadow, there is no reason not to like this second instalment. If, on the other hand, you are a fan of the old series (e.g: Symphony of the Night) then you probably didn't liked the first game and you shouldn't bother with this one. The name "Castlevania" is the only common ground between the old series and the reboot.The story isn't memorable, but it is decent and it does its job. Also, the Castlevania series wasn't necessary about story. What you have in Lords of Shadows 1 and 2 is great pretext for an action game.The artistic direction is more dark now and this is understandable since Gabriel turned into the evil Dracula. I am not a fan of the modern setting and I prefer the castle sections which look terrific.The stealth part of the game does seem weird but it's not game breaking as it was stated by the critics. Blame it on a poor game design decision that doesn't quite blend in with the setting.The gameplay is solid and the nice feature, called mastery, encourages you to use all the moves from your arsenal. Successfully using a skill in combat increases its mastery. Once it reaches 100%, you can improve your weapon by transfering the mastery of the skill.A minimap has been added to help exploring and find secrets. The old life and magic gems are back in the form of pain boxes. You can still find more about the lore by reading the journals of the fallen soldiers of the Brotherhood.You can and will return to previously visited areas.This is done better than the previous game, where you had to return to the map overview and select a completed level. Here you simply transition between areas. It's not sandbox, but there is a sense of continuity.To sum it up, Lords of Shadow 2 is good action/combat game, with an excellent artistic direction, nice voice acting and a story that helps you move forward. It's not a classic but it never wanted to be one. Definitely this is not a terrible game as the game critics want you to believe for whatever reasons.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Having been pleasantly surprised by just how good the orginal lords of shadows was, it's fair to say that my expectations for its  sequel were fairly high and nearly four years  later, we have lords of shadow 2 and with it, two questions which roughly translate to: "Is this game a worthy sequel to the orginal" and "should I buy it? In answer to the first question, my answer would be, for the most part, yes it is. The reason why I say for the most part is because while I think that los2 is a genuinely good game, I feel that it falls just short of matching the greatness of the orginal. The main reason why I think this is, is because los2 is a game of two halves. On the one half you have the exploration of draculas castle, which to say the least is huge and the medieval gothic  architecture as well as the unique characters and enemies that inhabit the prince of darkness's home. For me, this is where the game truly shines as it is this part of the game that seems to embody both the aesthetics and quality of the first game. The other half of this game involves navigating through a modern day setting, which I'm afraid to say is where this game falters. The main reason for this is because while the modern envioments are competently enough designed from a gameplay perspective, they lack any kind of personality and uniqueness of their own to make them memorable or even particularly interesting enough to warrent further exploration beyond the main game. Indeed, aside from the boss battles that take place in these locations and the stealth sections (The latter of which I actually quite enjoyed, contrary to popular opinion!) I found most of my time spent in the modern setting to be fairly forgettable,  especially when compared to the parts that take place in Draculas castle, and ultimately hold the game back from being truly on par with the first game. In answer to the second question as to whether the game is worth buying, my answer would be that if you enjoyed the original los then I defiantly believe that this game is worth buying. If you've never played the original but like God Of War style hack and slah games then I would also recomend this title as being a worthy purchase. In short, I would say that if you liked the original los then the odds are that you'll probably like this game as well. In conclusion, If I had to give the first game a score out of ten, then I would probably give it an 8. With this game, I feel that a 7 would be more appropriate.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												While not quite what I'd wanted after the first game in the series (and Mirror of Fate,) this is a good place for a semi-closing chapter.  Without any spoilers, a lot has happened since Gabriel Belmont originally set out to kill the Lords of Shadow and Do Good Things.  And this is a worthy addition to that story.  But what we see here is literally centuries after everything that happens in the other two games, and that gap feels kinda weird.  I suppose it's all explained via flashbacks and things, but even still.Lords of Shadow 2 improves on anything the first game did that needed improving, while not messing with 95% of the things about that game that worked great already.  And it THANKFULLY brings back one continuous world that you can explore as you see fit.  Physically walking back to an area with a new power to get a thing you saw but couldn't reach makes sense; selecting an earlier chapter from a menu in the first game, and running into characters and even bosses that are already DEAD... not so much.That said, the tone of the two games is much different.  This one doesn't ride on Hope so much.  Some might like the darker story, but personally I thought that it was a little somber and depressing at times.  It was all well told, and Robert Carlyle and Patrick Stewart knocked their roles out of the park, but I think that the darker universe just kinda took a toll on things.  We'll be visiting different environments, but gone are the sunny paths, baked desert-scapes, and clear skied mountain fortresses of the first game.  Here you get plenty of variety, with stormy locales, night cityscapes, fiery caverns, frozen mountainsides... but you'll never be doing anything during the day.  That's understandable, as Story Reasons require you to get everything done in one night.  And hell, Castlevania games usually all happen indoors, in one night, IN Dracula's Castle, so I can't fault it too much for grim, darkness.Powers work better in this game than the first.  Alternate weapons/magic/sub-weapons, all that stuff is great.  In the first game, I found myself doing everything with the whip, and never bothering to use my daggers, fairies, or dark crystal.  I used Holy Water to deal with BS waves that got boring, but when I used sub weapons or items here, it was all strategic and useful.  Especially in the Kleidos Challenges.Kleidos Challenges are unlockable (and thankfully optional) challenges that put you in a circular area with various enemies.  And there are three objectives, different to each challenge.  You might get, say, don't break any shields, don't use the Void Sword, and don't recover health by any means during the fight.  There's always the same 4th objective: do all three in the same run.  I did more than half of these before I got annoyed, and then just stopped.  For the super-hardcore, this is your kind of thing.Collectables are EVERYWHERE!  Kinda literally.  I've found 3 or 4 things in the SAME ROOM, sometimes I needed different powers for each... and sometimes when you find the first collectable, it's actually only half-way down a secret path, and going just a little farther will find you a hand-hold to climb or sneak or do something to get to another.  I liked that, using one power-up as a distraction so you'll think you've got it and miss out on the next one.Speaking of those collectible powerups, the come from two major things: Pain Boxes and Piles of Sacrifice.  The Pain Box is a box with a mouth that cuts or stabs your wrist when you stick your hand in, but then you get a Health, Void, or Chaos shard to raise your HP or Void or Chaos magics!  The Pile of Sacrifice is a little statue of a dude with a big curved sword over his shoulder, and you slice your wrist on it, bleed a LOT into the bowl beneath it, and then the bowl gives you either a capacity upgrade for 5 of your 6 relics or a Kleidos Nail, to get them Kleidos Challenges unlocked.  Don't worry if hunting for all this sounds annoying: you can pick up or shop for Dodo Eggs, and using one will mark the nearest collectible on your map.  It was fun for me hunting these down, though I did Dodo around... 15 of the game's nearly 200, just because I was at the end and wanted to get everything before I hit the last area.Some people say that the bosses here aren't as good as the first game.  True, for the most part, but at the same time not true.  They're very different.  The first game's bosses were huge and awesome, but had some HIGHLY scripted ways to beat them, and most ended in a series of Quick Timing Events.  Here it's more a real fight, relying on your gameplay skills.  QTEs have been dialed back A LOT from the first game.  Lords of Shadow 1 must have something like 800% as many as this one does.So I'll conclude here saying that this is a solid game with a cool story, and voice acting from two guys who do very good work.  Definitely, without question worth a buy on sale, and honestly even worth a buy at normal price if you're into Castlevania stuff.  But as a caveat, you might want to get the first game and Mirror of Fate HD first, as this is one epic overarching story, and though they do a pretty good recap at the beginning here, you want to be attached to the characters and the world first.  It makes this much more powerful.Here's hoping they make the intended third and final game, and round everything out as incredibly as I hope.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												First things first, I LOVE the art design of the whole game, they're really masters when it comes to imaging how Dracula Castle would look like, sound its also very good, music its good, visually its ok too. Now for a Castlevania game it lacks a lot from other games, including handheld versions (GBA/NDS). Game lacks collectibles, gear to improve you status, weapons, etcGameplay its ok but having so many attack combos can be too overwhelming, most of the time you'll use only use 2 or 3 combos for the whip and sword, I barely used the shadow claws (except when required by the game). It might be my bad memory but I found myself checking too many times how to make that cool looking combo I just unlocked and not so much time using it cause you can beat the game without it. Controls are fine but a few times they can get very frustrating, camera its also a bit frustrating since there is no way to lock your attacks to an enemy and the game will try to "auto aim" your attacks to the closest enemy but always the one you don't mean to attack. Collectibles are a bit boring, scrolls that try to complete the story and tell you parts of it that are not currently happening in game. You (Dracula) feel like the less powerful Dracula from the saga and the stealth sections of the game make no sense for a Castlevania game. Overall its a good game, not so much a good Castlevania. Definitely an improvement over the first LoS. I'll only recommend it if you don't mind a short game with almost no replay value and very little exploration like in past Castlevania games and you are a "true" Castlevania Fan 7/10

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												If Steam's rating system was stars, I would give this one three of them. It has beautiful graphics, optimized perfectly for a PC (even when the commands displayed are always Xbox 360's ones and you have to get used to them if you're playing with a keyboard and mouse) as it works like a charm on a Pavilion DV6 one. Music is the best part of the product, as cinematics are too (running 99% of the times fully real time)... but all the mythological themes, magic, settings and others that make a Castlevania game a Castlevania game are far away gone to present a more contemporary, darker, story. Character development is way better than the first game, but storytelling is not as solid as it could be. Gameplay feels amazing all the time, but I recommend using a guide if you don't want to get lost and wander for hours sometimes. Feels rock solid, but if you're expecting a Castlevania game you might not like this one at all as it feels a lot more like a Devil May Cry game now. Buy wisely.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												To preface: I came into this game off the expectations of the first Lords of Shadow, which I found to be one of the most worthwhile plays of the generation, marred only by the disconnect between cut-scene plot and loading screen plot (the former I chose to ignore for the much greater depth and intrigue of the latter). The way the last game ended, the trailer involving the castle siege, the unique universe and artistic style the game takes place in; how could they go wrong?And at first, it seemed like they'd made another great game (just like the first, which also came out to muted-to-mediocre reception but would prove to be a stellar experience). Even beyond the introduction sequence, with the lackluster stealth, linearity and meagerness of the city, it stilled promised to be much more, at least to me.For as long as I could, I held onto the concept that, at worst, it could be a poorly executed great concept; it kept sliding further and further away from that great concept ideal, to be expected of something coming from such a high plateu with too much expectation; a fault of my own if anything.What was dreadful about this game, however, was not its inability to match the former game's great expectations: it was unbelievably poor direction the plot lurches towards the mid-to-end of the game. In almost complete contrast to Lords of Shadow, which started off slow, picked up speed and took off into orbit: this game started off in orbit, slowed down and instead of just falling to the ground, somehow fell into a wormhole that took it straight into the jaws of a black hole where it went full-on Event Horizon.Give this game a massive miss; play the first and imagine what could have been, don't make the mistake that I did and assume the reviews were just a repeat of the first on release, of fans of Castlevania of old and this game just didn't live up to their rose-tinted rememberance of easiers times, and those who refused to do anything but accuse it of being a God of War clone, when it was so much more.In short, this game represents a tragedy in what could have been, of which I am saddened to have been a part of.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												The game received unjust hate from many reviewers, citing poor story, stealth mechanism and not being open world enough.Now, if you liked the first Lords of Shadow, there is no reason not to like this second instalment. If, on the other hand, you are a fan of the old series (e.g: Symphony of the Night) then you probably didn't liked the first game and you shouldn't bother with this one. The name "Castlevania" is the only common ground between the old series and the reboot.The story isn't memorable, but it is decent and it does its job. Also, the Castlevania series wasn't necessary about story. What you have in Lords of Shadows 1 and 2 is great pretext for an action game.The artistic direction is more dark now and this is understandable since Gabriel turned into the evil Dracula. I am not a fan of the modern setting and I prefer the castle sections which look terrific.The stealth part of the game does seem weird but it's not game breaking as it was stated by the critics. Blame it on a poor game design decision that doesn't quite blend in with the setting.The gameplay is solid and the nice feature, called mastery, encourages you to use all the moves from your arsenal. Successfully using a skill in combat increases its mastery. Once it reaches 100%, you can improve your weapon by transfering the mastery of the skill.A minimap has been added to help exploring and find secrets. The old life and magic gems are back in the form of pain boxes. You can still find more about the lore by reading the journals of the fallen soldiers of the Brotherhood.You can and will return to previously visited areas.This is done better than the previous game, where you had to return to the map overview and select a completed level. Here you simply transition between areas. It's not sandbox, but there is a sense of continuity.To sum it up, Lords of Shadow 2 is good action/combat game, with an excellent artistic direction, nice voice acting and a story that helps you move forward. It's not a classic but it never wanted to be one. Definitely this is not a terrible game as the game critics want you to believe for whatever reasons.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												To be perfectly honest, if you want more Lords of Shadow, you're better off replaying the first game.I feel this one really missed the mark, and after reading about the internal struggles of the development team and their near-constant battle with their director, I can say I'm not really surprised.Lords of Shadow 2 is, in every way, inferior to its predecessor. Graphically, it fails to impress. Mechanically, it feels sloppy. The combat is frustrating and choppy and, while LoS1 had its fair share of controller-throwing platforming segments, LoS2 doesn't even justify its own such moments with an equal helping of fun, satisfying ones. I have only put a couple hours into the game so far, and already I'm mad at it. I cannot comment on the overall story yet, but the beginning feels rushed and strange, and I have to feel bad for Patrick Stewart being forced to deliver such a petty script as Zobek. The writing is childish and uninspired, and the semi-animated lore sequence explaining the Belmont lineage is utterly boring.But you know, I could forgive all of that if the game didn't so completely miss its own point. At no time during play did I ever FEEL like Dracula, who is supposed to be an absolute powerhouse, combining strength, speed, and magical abilities to devastate ranks upon ranks of foes. The most basic of enemies can take a monumental beating from any of your weapons, and can even attack straight through your combos to strike you. One minor strike from an enemy, however, will interrupt your combo and send you flying, which makes your stature feel pitiful, even if you aren't taking significant damage from those attacks. These problems are only magnified and exacerbated when, after the tutorial sequence, the story fast-forwards some centuries and resets all of Gabriel's powers, requiring you to slowly unlock them, one by one.Other games have successfully portrayed their protagonists as extremely powerful beings without robbing the game of its core challenge. A great case in point is Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine. Lords of Shadow 2, however, takes the legendary Dracula and nerfs him into the ground, and then poops all over him with bad gameplay mechanics.I'll say it again: if you want more LoS, play the first game again, because you'll enjoy it a whole lot more.

												A great Castlevania game and a great sequel to the first Lords of Shadow. Even outside of its own series, this game is worth a recommendation, as it can easily appeal to you if you've enjoyed games with similar gameplay like Devil May Cry or God of War.While some aspects like the stealth puzzles or the metroidvania-esque level design may be divisive, the game features a uniquely satisfying, visceral combat system with finely-tuned fights and excellent controls. The game's difficulty modes are well balanced with a good challenge waiting for you on the higher two settings. The presentation is fantastic—all the graphics, music, sound effects, and amazing gothic-styled vistas mesh together perfectly to create a haunting and memorable atmosphere. The length of the game is equally impressive for a game in this genre, easily clocking in at over 20 hours just to finish the story.

												At first, I was a bit miffed by the fact that this game becomes anachronistic (Brotherhood version of Liberty Prime], Gabriel in the future), but the story ties it together nicely and it fits together with the in-game lore. The game itself is played out across two worlds (the "mission" world and Gabriel's Castle). Both worlds are free-roam and you can backtrack as needed to explore or to get items previously missed.Pros:- Option in menu to turn off QTEs. This made the first game really annoying with the constant QTE prompts; now it's optional.- Great story.- Fantastic soundtrack.- Combat is more streamlined with upgrades. The mastery system forces you to change up your attacks so you get to use all the combat moves.Cons:- Lack of puzzles (I enjoyed the puzzles from the first game).- Lots of backtracking (re-exploring and getting items from areas already explored).- Modern setting sometimes feels un-Castlevania like.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is an awesome game and the classic example of what's wrong with Metacritic. A 58 out of 100 seems awfully low for a game that plays so well, that I'm baffled by the hatred it gets from critics. Or, perhaps, the way Metacritic aggregates review scores is the problem? A single negative review can make that score right there plummet and provide extreme misinformation on an otherwise great game!Lords of Shadow 2 does a few things quite well. First, it removes the stupid locked camera. Second, it has easy to learn combos that the game outright encourages you to use via the "mastery" system. Third, it has far more gothic scenery and themes that pay a deep homage to Castlevania in general. Fourth, the graphics are absolutely beautiful yet they run at 60 frames per second. Fifth, the bosses are incredible. Sixth, there's a ton of secrets and for the most part you are encouraged to explore at your leisure between objectives. Those are the six key aspects I can think of, besides the music, voiceacting, and controls being stellar as well. The story can be confusing, but it's the most tragic tale of Dracula I've ever seen in my life, and that is awesome in itself! Have you ever found yourself rooting for Dracula in all of the Castlevania games? Well, you WILL in this game!The most criticized aspect of this game is that it "doesnt know what it wants to be", on critic reviews. I'm sorry, but there is such a thing as "gameplay variety". Consistency is nice, but this game isn't trying to be 100% like God of War, and offers decent stealth segments which aren't awful. Some of these segments are even a little clever, but they could be better. In fact, the game IS consistent for the most part, offering lots of platforming, action, exploration, secrets, and grand vistas. So why is that the worst part of the game? Is it really too linear? Does it really change too often too fast with the gameplay? Is it not trying hard enough to be Metroidvania style? These questions don't matter. The classic Castlevania games were by far more linear than this game, except the often criticized Simon's Quest entry. There are things wrong with Lords of Shadow 2 as well, but does it really warrant a FIFTY EIGHT OUT OF ONE HUNDRED Metascore?!So, I highly reccomend this game. I like it much more than Lords of Shadow, in fact!

												8/10My only actual complaint was that the game was too short. I beat my first run on the second hardest difficulty (considered hardest until you beat it... semi-smart idea for a rerun) in about six hours, and that's with finding most of the collectables along the way. The combat is fun to play around with and the idea of upgrading your weapon is interesting but the makers kept it simple, which is alright.I'd recommend it to anyone once the price goes down or if it goes on sale. 6 hours runtime for 60$ is kind of disappointing, especially with a decently good story behind it.Until then!

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												First things first, I LOVE the art design of the whole game, they're really masters when it comes to imaging how Dracula Castle would look like, sound its also very good, music its good, visually its ok too. Now for a Castlevania game it lacks a lot from other games, including handheld versions (GBA/NDS). Game lacks collectibles, gear to improve you status, weapons, etcGameplay its ok but having so many attack combos can be too overwhelming, most of the time you'll use only use 2 or 3 combos for the whip and sword, I barely used the shadow claws (except when required by the game). It might be my bad memory but I found myself checking too many times how to make that cool looking combo I just unlocked and not so much time using it cause you can beat the game without it. Controls are fine but a few times they can get very frustrating, camera its also a bit frustrating since there is no way to lock your attacks to an enemy and the game will try to "auto aim" your attacks to the closest enemy but always the one you don't mean to attack. Collectibles are a bit boring, scrolls that try to complete the story and tell you parts of it that are not currently happening in game. You (Dracula) feel like the less powerful Dracula from the saga and the stealth sections of the game make no sense for a Castlevania game. Overall its a good game, not so much a good Castlevania. Definitely an improvement over the first LoS. I'll only recommend it if you don't mind a short game with almost no replay value and very little exploration like in past Castlevania games and you are a "true" Castlevania Fan 7/10

												This game is quite entertaining, despite not being like what I expected.The game itself plays pretty much like the first Lords of Shadow. Game mechanics, movement and art style is very much the same. Very well executed, and especially the scenery of the game is nothing short of stunning!The storyline, however, is a bit confusing to those who have not read up on what they are going into. The game is open-world, with some backtracking and exploration. Collectibles are hidden where you won't necessarily be able to get them first time around, which can be frustrating if you are not aware of what skills are necessery to get to them. Also, I had a hard time getting used to the fact that Dracula was running around in a modern world for a part of the game, and with the game happening one part in the modern day, and the other part in Draculas castle, the skips can be confusing.The game however is quite fun, the dialogue is quite great, really moving moments that often surprised me in how much they made me care about the characters. Would recommend if you are a Castlevania fan, with an open mind.

												Much, much better than the first one:-Optional QTEs-Movable camera-Rewards attack variety-Many more combat items and habilities-FAR better enemy interactions. The final boss is great too.Background music is great, really good, better than the first one. Combat music is rather meh, with some gems. content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												     Over all I found this to be a spectacular game and would absolutly reccomend it to any player who enjoys their games with good story and characters. As said the story is fairly interesting. You play as Dracula on a mission to destroy Satan in order to stop a demonic invasion and finally be able to rest in peace. The voice acting was absoluely fantastic and the characters were completly believable and not at all flat. There was nothing weak with the characters.The Graphics and animation are also superb and the player is presented with stunning visuals all around, especially with the scenery which presents a gorgeous display of gothic architecture and other surroundings which will leave the player feeling fully immersed. Combat was intersting in that you could not simply just plow through a horde, but actually have to take the time to defeat them. I was playing on easy and defeating casual enemies was even then not just a simple task. Every enemy took time to kill. Quite a few boss battles took place and every boss was also an interesting character, who took time to defeat. Though I didn't find too much of a strategy nessessary, they still took time to defeat and it was enjoyable. The game is quite long and I feel that there were some parts the developers should have left out and even some parts I found completly unnessessary. For instance, there is at least two occasions where you are practiacally playing hide and seek, which I didn't feel was really nessessary or even enjoyable. Aside from this I feel it is a very well developed game. While I do not feel is is a classic, it was undeniably an enjoyable expirence that I can highly reccomend to anyone looking for strong characters, good story, and outstanding visuals.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												As an avid fan of the Castlevania series, I will say most of the 3D entries have been mostly mediocre.  Some had good ideas marred by poor controls (N64 games) while others had tedious gameplay with excellent music and atmosphere (Lament of Innocence and Curse of Darkness).Then 2010 rolled around and Lords of Shadow came out.  Another 3D Castlevania that I had zero expectations for but still an almost forced obligation to try...and it blew me away.  Amazing graphics, gripping story, phenomenal soundtrack, varied enemy encounters, huge boss fights, and a simple on the surface but surprisingly deep combat system in the vein of God of War (this doesn't have to be an insult, people) gave a shockingly well rounded package that earned the game some high sales and critical praise the series hadn't seen in a long time.  It had its faults, namely a camera that couldn't be controlled and a somewhat slow beginning, but the series seemed to be headed in a positive direction.A few years later we got Mirror of Fate, a sort of in-betweener entry to bind the stories of LOS1 and LOS2.  It also marked a return to the side-scrolling roots with flashes of SOTN style gameplay.  The story was interesting but markedly less central compared to LOS.  Still, the gameplay was mostly interesting, a little different, and again had a wonderful score.With the announcement of certain features like a seamless world and a controlled camera, LOS2 had a lot to live up to.  For the most part it delivers, though it definitely has its flaws.  Rather than continue on with the paragraphs at length, I'll make some easy to peruse pros and cons lists.PROS: -The story is still well told and interesting, voice actors all nail their roles (specifically Robert Carlyle and Jason Isaacs). -The soundtrack is still amazing. -Gameplay remains mostly unchanged, though there is less emphasis on puzzle solving. -Good length, around 15-20 hours depending on how much secret hunting you engage in. -Lots of neat references to classic entries. -Dracula's castle offers some cool, varied areas. -Weapon mastery/skill tree system rewards experimentation and discourages 'spamming.'CONS: -Seamless world exploration is hurt by an incredibly weak map system.  Opening the map in the menu only lets you see a very small portion of the area you are in, and you can't cycle between them.  There are also a scant number of teleportation rooms, making backtracking quite painful. -Difficulty seemed all over the place.  I found most bosses very easy and generally struggled more with the regular enemy encounters. -The modern city you explore has that Gothic Castlevania feel to it, but unfortunately most of the areas are hard to differentiate. -Ending is rather abrupt and anti-climactic.As for the now infamous 'stealth' sections, I can safely say they have been completely overblown in just about every review.  Yes, they are by no means a good part of the game.  However they are very simple and account for less than 45 minutes or so of game time.  Don't let that be what sways your heart on the game.Although it has a few questionable design choices, for the most part I can give a positive recommendation for LOS2.  Arguably one of the best facets of the series is that each game brings something different to the table.  LOS was about the closest we've gotten to a (fun) 3D classic Castlevania, Mirror of Fate was more along the lines of a 2D SOTN/Circle of the Moon type game, and LOS2 was an attempt to merge the two.  None of them are perfect, but the series hasn't been this interesting in over a decade.  I look forward to whatever Mercury Steam does next, and we will see what future Castlevanias have in store for us.
