number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												I'm going through my second playthrough now under Prince Of Darkness difficulty, and figured I'd write a bit of a review about the game itself.First off, I would have to agree with some people who have posted "not recommended" reviews on the game for a few reasons:  The primary being that the game itself feels entirely too short for it's own good.  In comparison to LoS1 where levels are abundant and the scenery constantly changing as you progress, LoS2 seems to rehash the same areas, in a similar fashion to that of Dragon Age 2.  You spend more time running through the same areas and just gives off a feeling of redundancy throughout the course of the game.  Sure, the areas are pretty huge, but when you need to run through the same areas repeatedly to progress it's more of an annoyance than anything.Groups of enemies seem to perfectly chain their "undodgeable" attacks to seemingly no end.  I'm up for a challenge, but when you're surrounded by a whole group of enemies it's extremtly annoying to constantly be chained from special to special.  Then again, I suppose that's how the NPCs feel so bit of karma I suppose.  The stealth sections truly are a bit annoying.  I understand that they're trying to incorporate a bit more than your run of the mill hack and slash, but there aren't multiple ways to approach them or to resolve them.  Not to mention that if you're spotted, you can pretty much expect to just restart from checkpoint; rarely is there a chance to regroup without taking massive damage.On to the good, as this overall is a recommendation for the game.  Overall, I have to say that I did quite enjoy the storyline, and being able to play as Alucard really gave me some flashbacks to some of the greatest games in the canon.  [Spoilers] The surprise appearance of another Belmont was quite good as well!  The combat system, while much has been leveraged from the first game I quite enjoyed, even if it was a bit repetitive.  There seems to be quite a large focus on countering in this game as opposed to its predecessor, which I don't mind personally.  The new abilities are quite interesting as well, and the upgrade/mastery system keeps you trying to use new attacks against the same enemies you encounter.All in all, I wouldn't agree with the Metascore rating as it does seem a bit low.  Sequels are always tough and when you have a title as solid as LoS1, it's hard to not play second fiddle.  Anyone who is a fan of the series I would think would like the game, and overall it's a good playthrough with the added Kleidos challenges.

												if you like the first game, then you will like the second game. the story wasnt anything to write home about, but it wasnt bad either. the combat was very fluid and easy to get the hang of. that said i have two complaints about the game. first is the stealth part of the game, which was often trial and error while dying over and over again trying to figure out what the game wanted me to do. these stealth parts were usually where i took a break from the game as dying over and over again was frustrating because there are no hints beyond the first couple of stealth puzzles. often times the solution involved using an ability in a way that was never talked about (such as the mist power can go through enemies). my second complaint was getting lost in other puzzles for pretty much the same exact reason (such as the revelations dlc you can use the wolf power while interacting with switches). both of these cases were "oh i can do that?" which would have been fine if they were explained better. overall due to its kind of dragged out short story, the stealth puzzles, and lack of information about some abilites involved in puzzles i would give this game a 7 out of 10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												*Edit: When I first wrote the review, I was only almost done with the game, but now that I have seen it through to the end, I feel I have to amend a couple of my points, primarily with the story. The ending sucks. I won't spoil anything, but I must say it was quite a let down. Many unresolved questions and an unsatisfying end both in story and boss fight. It was easier than the first acolyte.Looking at this game from a completed perspective, even before my edit, I can say that this game had a lot of potential and good ideas, but from what I've read had a botched development. It shows because a lot of the game feels incomplete or like the developers rushed to finish what was left after some development troubles. It's really a shame and very disappointing.*I played the first Lords of Shadow and I enjoyed it. As for this one, I would say it's better in some areas and worse in others.COMBAT: Compared to the first, it feels like they really smoothed out the combat in terms of how you move around and perform moves. some difficulties become clearer when it comes to one mechanic though: the way some enemies block in this game. When some enemies are blocking, they stop your combo and deflect your attack and zero damage is done. This can get really annoying when there are multiple enemies and you are attacking one that is open, but the one right next to the first is blocking. it will stop your combo. This makes engagements with multiple blocking enemies really annoying unless you are really good with your chaos energy (it's like the shadow energy from the first game and it breaks through shield and armor). Multiple skeletons are the most annoying thing in this game... That said, thankfully those kinds of enemies don't show up terribly often, and combat can still be very fun now that it's smoothed out.STORY: Sadly, I would have to say the story in this game is inferior to the first overall. There is no longer an opening narration to each stage like their was in the first because of the way they made the map somewhat open world (I'll get into that further down). There are also seems to be less moments of significant plot progression throughout the game; a lot of times it feels as if you go a great distance just to get a small snippet of story. That said, one of the things that brought me back toward liking the game more were the story moments (they pick up more once you get a bit further) when you see the way Gabriel changes based on his interaction with the other characters. Some of them were very moving. Still, overall there just doesn't seem to be as much story as there was in the first game, and for Patrick Stewart in particular, it almost seems like a waste of his talent.VISUALS: For the most part, I'm going to say that this game's visuals are gorgeous. Very pretty and detailed environments. Not a lot of more vibrant environments like the first game, but they are still very detailed and pretty, especially when the game's graphics are turned up. However, i did say "for the most part" because some of the more industrial areas that you explore in the game, particularly the areas with a lot of pipes and wires going along the walls and cielings, are very dull and start to feel repetitive really quickly.MAP SYSTEM: I think they had a good idea when they started this game to give it a more open world feel, but ultimately the traveling around the map gets very tedious, especially when you are backtracking to find all the hidden upgrades, and again in the more industrial areas, it becomes easy to get lost and start traveling in circles when you are looking for certain areas.OVERALL I would say Lords of Shadow 2 is a decent game that you will enjoy for its beauty and decent combat system if you have the patience for the map and sometimes tedious battles with annoying enemies, but I would buy it when the price lowers. Also, if you have a choice, play the first Lords of Shadow before you play the second, it will make your experience with the second. The story will of course make more sense and be more enjoyable.

												Castlevania Lords of Shadow 2 is hard to judge in my opinon. I really looked forward to the progression of the story from Lords of Shawdow 1.  I felt a little disappointed with the story since the previous game and its DLC made it seem that much action was going happen. That being said I still enjoyed most of the game, specifically its fighting mechanics, bosses and challenges. Cons: (not trying to spoil so it will seem vague)1. The developers made some odd decisions with the overall features/design of the game, some levels had these sections that required special abilities to get through them which to broke the pace of the game. There were also too many climbing sections.2. You're Dracula, and while he is weak the developers could have taken a more creative route with the abilities.3. The direction of the Story could have been better, The plot development left for so much to be desired.Pros:1. FIghting Mechanics were awesome. The leveling of weapons and powers were balenced.2. Challenges were a great addition, they were fun and just right in difficulty.3. The new items and some of the abilities were interesting. I recommend the game if you completed Lords of Shadow 1, if you get it at a reasonable discount.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												An amazing sequel. Graphics are top notch (HD-Texture pack is free and a recommended install), gameplay is engaging and fun, controls are crisp and free from lag or any kind of delay. Combat is varied and there's a truckload of skills to unlock and use.Exploration feels less of a hassle as it did in the first game and you usually pick the various bits and bobs up as you progress through the story. There's a huge number of unlockables and power ups to find, it'll keep you busy for quite a while.The music is fantastic. Really immersive.Overall a lot of quality of life improvements have been made.The only thing that really annoyed me was that the further you progress in the game, the more the enemies seem to favour using unblockable Power Attacks and wear heavy armour requiring you to expend Chaos Magic to break their defenses. Some enemies hit a lot harder and quicker than I think they should. It can quickly ruin your day if you're not careful.All in all, this is a really solid game. A well deserved 9/10.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Awak­ened after cen­turies of sleep, Gabriel Bel­mont joins his for­mer men­tor in an attempt to reclaim his pow­ers and defeat Satan and his acolytes in this final chap­ter in the Lords of Shadow series.The game tran­si­tions between present time and medieval times, just before Dracula’s cas­tle was ruined. Dur­ing these tran­si­tions, Gabriel must not only fight Satan’s Acolytes, but he must also bat­tle his inner self in order to be able to regain his strength.Lords of Shadow 2, like its pre­de­ces­sor, is an action-adventure hack n’slash game, but unlike pre­vi­ous install­ments it has some inter­est­ing game­play inno­va­tions, such as var­i­ous puz­zle ele­ments and stealth-like sec­tions. The new addi­tions, espe­cially the stealth ele­ments, tend to hin­der the pro­gres­sion of the story though and being totally scripted does not seem to add any­thing spe­cial to the whole gam­ing expe­ri­ence. There are no alter­nate routes, there is only one way… Despite this fact how­ever, the pres­ence of var­i­ous col­lectibles and upgrades which can be found through­out the map of the game make explo­ration quite a reward­ing experience.Read the rest of my review here:  http://www.blowsomesteam.com/castlevania-lords-of-shadow-2/

												It was my intention to get this for the PS3 to match the first entry but an unexpected Trivia Challenge by Konami made that plan change. This is the first PC game I've ever played that highly recommended the use of a gamepad. Once in the game, I was sucked in. The level of detail in the environments and characters designs are just eye popping.  The controls are solid and easy to get used to, though I can't say for the keyboard controls since I never used them. The story was great but you need to pay attention to little details otherwise you may find yourself disappointed at the end. I'm just sad this is the last one of the series. I'd recommend this game to everyone, even old school Castlevania fans. It's a nice change of pace and an interesting take on this household name.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												If Steam's rating system was stars, I would give this one three of them. It has beautiful graphics, optimized perfectly for a PC (even when the commands displayed are always Xbox 360's ones and you have to get used to them if you're playing with a keyboard and mouse) as it works like a charm on a Pavilion DV6 one. Music is the best part of the product, as cinematics are too (running 99% of the times fully real time)... but all the mythological themes, magic, settings and others that make a Castlevania game a Castlevania game are far away gone to present a more contemporary, darker, story. Character development is way better than the first game, but storytelling is not as solid as it could be. Gameplay feels amazing all the time, but I recommend using a guide if you don't want to get lost and wander for hours sometimes. Feels rock solid, but if you're expecting a Castlevania game you might not like this one at all as it feels a lot more like a Devil May Cry game now. Buy wisely.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												First things first, I LOVE the art design of the whole game, they're really masters when it comes to imaging how Dracula Castle would look like, sound its also very good, music its good, visually its ok too. Now for a Castlevania game it lacks a lot from other games, including handheld versions (GBA/NDS). Game lacks collectibles, gear to improve you status, weapons, etcGameplay its ok but having so many attack combos can be too overwhelming, most of the time you'll use only use 2 or 3 combos for the whip and sword, I barely used the shadow claws (except when required by the game). It might be my bad memory but I found myself checking too many times how to make that cool looking combo I just unlocked and not so much time using it cause you can beat the game without it. Controls are fine but a few times they can get very frustrating, camera its also a bit frustrating since there is no way to lock your attacks to an enemy and the game will try to "auto aim" your attacks to the closest enemy but always the one you don't mean to attack. Collectibles are a bit boring, scrolls that try to complete the story and tell you parts of it that are not currently happening in game. You (Dracula) feel like the less powerful Dracula from the saga and the stealth sections of the game make no sense for a Castlevania game. Overall its a good game, not so much a good Castlevania. Definitely an improvement over the first LoS. I'll only recommend it if you don't mind a short game with almost no replay value and very little exploration like in past Castlevania games and you are a "true" Castlevania Fan 7/10

You defeat the last boss by almost killing your partner and then you`re free to do whatever cr@p you wanted but oh, the sun is rising so I guess its time for bed. In conclusion:YOU DEFEAT THE PRINCE OF DARKNESS, FREEING MANKIND FROM ALL EVIL AND YOU REWARD YOURSELF... with a nap.This ending was indeed a miserable pile of sh!t.Altought the story reaches its stupid ending, the game itself is very good. 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												This game is kind of a mixed bag with me, so I'll just list the pros and cons. Pros+GameplayThe gameplay is quite a bit improved from the first game; camera is no longer locked, climbing is easier, items are actually useful this time, and there's items dedicated to helping you uncover secrets. I'm also quite fond of the openness, allowing you to go back at virtually any time to explore, collect items, etc.+GraphicsVisually, the game is beautiful, and there's plenty of areas in the game that are simply stunning. Found myself taking in the view more than once.+CombatThe mastery system rewards using different skills to enhance your weapons' power. Each of Dracula's weapons have their own specific use, similar to the first game, but are more than just enchanting your whip with magic this time around, giving you entirely different movesets for each weapon. Also you get to drink your enemies' blood.+MusicThe music of the first game was good, but it lacked any sort of memorability. The music in Lords of Shadow 2 is much better, although you'll hear a lot of the same tracks over and over. Somewhat of a hit and miss here, but a majority of the music is good enough that this is more of a pro than a con.+PacingThere was a lot of nothing in between the major events of the first game; the pacing was just kinda crap, in all honesty. There always seems to be something going on in LoS 2, it's easier to feel like you're actually doing something rather than roaming through some ruins without much of a goal, which was a major problem throughout the first third of the first game.+Gabriel is More InterestingI was completely incapable of feeling any sort of sympathy for Gabriel in the first game. He was a cardboard cutout of a character devoid of most emotion. In this one, however, he's a little more interesting simply because he is fairly PO'ed. Also he's the dark lord, he has a reputation to live up to. Thankfully, he does.+EnvironmentAs previously mentioned in the Graphics, the game is beautiful. The environment is also essential for this as well; for the areas that they created, the world is detailed and interesting. Areas are distinguishable from other places, and the concept of building a city on the ruined foundations of Dracula's castle is, honestly, quite interesting. It creates a distinctive gothic-type city that still seems reminiscent of Dracula's castle pre-ruin when you have opportunities to overlook the city.+LoreWhile the story blows (more on that later), it does have some intriguing lore to find, some of which indicating that the people of Castlevania City are fully aware that monsters and magic are a thing. It's definitely a turn from the original Castlevania games and other games such as Vampire: The Masquerade- Bloodlines where hiding the supernatural from the world was of the utmost importance. In Lords of Shadow 2, I find it intriguing that they accept, and are even fascinated by, the fact that there used to be werewolves, vampires, and even the siege against Dracula are merely documented as history and treated as such. Their history is as natural to them as our own is to us. This is certainly something I'd love to see expanded on in future games- maybe not Lords of Shadow, but other franchises where the supernatural is merely embraced as a part of history rather than hidden from the world for safety.  Cons-It's Not CastlevaniaYou can add the title, give the characters the names, and everything else, but it still doesn't make it a Castlevania game. Let alone it's horridly out of place with half of the game taking place in a modern day city. To be perfectly honest, it feels more like Darksiders than Castlevania due to the themes throughout the game. The heart and spirit of the series is completely absent from Lords of Shadow, hence I only ever refer to it as Lords of Shadow.-StoryI find it ironic that they rebooted Castlevania with an intended focus on story, and then ended up dropping the ball. The first game had an okay, albeit not-very-original story with Satan having Necron Syndrome and popping up literally out of nowhere at the end. Mirror of Fate was an atrocity of a game and explained jack squat. Similar problems are in LoS 2- Gabriel often finds himself back in what appears to be either the past of his memories of his castle. Honestly have no idea because it's never explained at all. His memories/past/whatever-the-fudge-is-going-on also has zero relevance to what's going on, aside from getting back his powers because reasons. There's also some Resident Evil bullcrap going on where the citizens are mutated by some demonic virus; this is so out of place it hurts. Everything else is fairly easy to follow, and there's some interesting things that do happen throughout the game, but it's nothing to write home about. Story is honestly not a good reason to play this game, and if it's what you're looking for, turn the other way.Gabriel forgot how to Open DoorsFound a door? Guess what? You're going to have to pull a switch to open it. He's only a superhuman Prince of Darkness, godforbid he opens a metal door on his own. There's a lot of this crap that just slows the game down needlessly, especially since it takes forever for said doors to open. This game was made in 2014, this is rather inexcusable.-Enemies can be AnnoyingThere's a guard/perfect guard mechanic in the game, which is quite useful. Unfortunately, roughly 50% of the time, the enemies perform an unblockable attack, which renders guarding a lot less useful than you'd like it to be. Also there's plenty of times where I simply wanted to get somewhere and didn't want to fight. Going places often involve climbing. Guess what? Every freaking enemy in the game can use some kind of projectile to knock you down, often forcing you to fight enemies when you don't want to. This is often infuriating when you merely want to explore for upgrades and other hidden items.-Stealth SegmentsOkay, I get that he's weak and whatnot at the beginning, but this just seems so unnecessary. Especially since the stealth segment with Agreus is absolutely infuriating.-BugsEvery now and then, characters may "say something" without sound- basically the sound file for the line they're supposed to say doesn't play (no subtitles either, which is even more aggravating). I've had other instances where the objective was the last objective I just did, and wasn't up to date. Worst of all, I've had it crash on me for no reason once. Final VerdictWhile the story is laughable, the stealth is pointless, and bugs are afoot, the game is actually quite fun. I do not recommend it at full price; wait for a Steam sale to get it because $40 is a bit much for some of the frustrations of the game. Gameplay-wise, it's pretty good, despite the annoying gameplay oversights. Worth getting if you're interested in, or at least play the demo first to know if you'd like it.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												I'll give C:LoS2 a limited "thumbs-up," but based almost entirely only the outstanding visuals, audio, and effects. To be brief, the models, animations, textures, lighting effects are simply superb. I would often walk into new environments and just pan the camera around to take it all in. The craftsmanship of the content is what propelled me towards the end.However, my big concern with this game is that I was hoping for a different mix of ingredients. In most action/adventures games (God of War, Batman: Arkham series) there is a nice mixture of combat, exploration, puzzle solving, and traversal (climbing, swimming, grappling, etc.) What I wanted from Lord of Shadow 2 was 50% combat and 50% everything else. What I got was basically 15% combat with a TON of emphasis on uninspried puzzles, boring traversal, and some rather obvious exploraiton. There were many, many times in the game when I would walk down a hallway and wish I would be jumped by a bad guy just so I could use my weapons.In the end, I still played and enjoyed it. But I wished for a lot more combat and a lot less of everything else.

												A nice sequel to lords of shadow, though it feels very different.Combat has been refined from lords of shadow, instead of light and dark magic you have two new weapons that change things up in a nice way. No spoliers but the last boss was not all it was hyped up to be.Story is alright, you do get to jump between some castle levels and city levels. To be honest the city levels did feel very strange and while some of the structures and areas evoked a sense of older Castlevania themes...it just didn't really do it for me. I would rather have had eveyrthing in an older setting.I found the game enjoyable though, and would recommend a play through.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												While not quite what I'd wanted after the first game in the series (and Mirror of Fate,) this is a good place for a semi-closing chapter.  Without any spoilers, a lot has happened since Gabriel Belmont originally set out to kill the Lords of Shadow and Do Good Things.  And this is a worthy addition to that story.  But what we see here is literally centuries after everything that happens in the other two games, and that gap feels kinda weird.  I suppose it's all explained via flashbacks and things, but even still.Lords of Shadow 2 improves on anything the first game did that needed improving, while not messing with 95% of the things about that game that worked great already.  And it THANKFULLY brings back one continuous world that you can explore as you see fit.  Physically walking back to an area with a new power to get a thing you saw but couldn't reach makes sense; selecting an earlier chapter from a menu in the first game, and running into characters and even bosses that are already DEAD... not so much.That said, the tone of the two games is much different.  This one doesn't ride on Hope so much.  Some might like the darker story, but personally I thought that it was a little somber and depressing at times.  It was all well told, and Robert Carlyle and Patrick Stewart knocked their roles out of the park, but I think that the darker universe just kinda took a toll on things.  We'll be visiting different environments, but gone are the sunny paths, baked desert-scapes, and clear skied mountain fortresses of the first game.  Here you get plenty of variety, with stormy locales, night cityscapes, fiery caverns, frozen mountainsides... but you'll never be doing anything during the day.  That's understandable, as Story Reasons require you to get everything done in one night.  And hell, Castlevania games usually all happen indoors, in one night, IN Dracula's Castle, so I can't fault it too much for grim, darkness.Powers work better in this game than the first.  Alternate weapons/magic/sub-weapons, all that stuff is great.  In the first game, I found myself doing everything with the whip, and never bothering to use my daggers, fairies, or dark crystal.  I used Holy Water to deal with BS waves that got boring, but when I used sub weapons or items here, it was all strategic and useful.  Especially in the Kleidos Challenges.Kleidos Challenges are unlockable (and thankfully optional) challenges that put you in a circular area with various enemies.  And there are three objectives, different to each challenge.  You might get, say, don't break any shields, don't use the Void Sword, and don't recover health by any means during the fight.  There's always the same 4th objective: do all three in the same run.  I did more than half of these before I got annoyed, and then just stopped.  For the super-hardcore, this is your kind of thing.Collectables are EVERYWHERE!  Kinda literally.  I've found 3 or 4 things in the SAME ROOM, sometimes I needed different powers for each... and sometimes when you find the first collectable, it's actually only half-way down a secret path, and going just a little farther will find you a hand-hold to climb or sneak or do something to get to another.  I liked that, using one power-up as a distraction so you'll think you've got it and miss out on the next one.Speaking of those collectible powerups, the come from two major things: Pain Boxes and Piles of Sacrifice.  The Pain Box is a box with a mouth that cuts or stabs your wrist when you stick your hand in, but then you get a Health, Void, or Chaos shard to raise your HP or Void or Chaos magics!  The Pile of Sacrifice is a little statue of a dude with a big curved sword over his shoulder, and you slice your wrist on it, bleed a LOT into the bowl beneath it, and then the bowl gives you either a capacity upgrade for 5 of your 6 relics or a Kleidos Nail, to get them Kleidos Challenges unlocked.  Don't worry if hunting for all this sounds annoying: you can pick up or shop for Dodo Eggs, and using one will mark the nearest collectible on your map.  It was fun for me hunting these down, though I did Dodo around... 15 of the game's nearly 200, just because I was at the end and wanted to get everything before I hit the last area.Some people say that the bosses here aren't as good as the first game.  True, for the most part, but at the same time not true.  They're very different.  The first game's bosses were huge and awesome, but had some HIGHLY scripted ways to beat them, and most ended in a series of Quick Timing Events.  Here it's more a real fight, relying on your gameplay skills.  QTEs have been dialed back A LOT from the first game.  Lords of Shadow 1 must have something like 800% as many as this one does.So I'll conclude here saying that this is a solid game with a cool story, and voice acting from two guys who do very good work.  Definitely, without question worth a buy on sale, and honestly even worth a buy at normal price if you're into Castlevania stuff.  But as a caveat, you might want to get the first game and Mirror of Fate HD first, as this is one epic overarching story, and though they do a pretty good recap at the beginning here, you want to be attached to the characters and the world first.  It makes this much more powerful.Here's hoping they make the intended third and final game, and round everything out as incredibly as I hope.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												To preface: I came into this game off the expectations of the first Lords of Shadow, which I found to be one of the most worthwhile plays of the generation, marred only by the disconnect between cut-scene plot and loading screen plot (the former I chose to ignore for the much greater depth and intrigue of the latter). The way the last game ended, the trailer involving the castle siege, the unique universe and artistic style the game takes place in; how could they go wrong?And at first, it seemed like they'd made another great game (just like the first, which also came out to muted-to-mediocre reception but would prove to be a stellar experience). Even beyond the introduction sequence, with the lackluster stealth, linearity and meagerness of the city, it stilled promised to be much more, at least to me.For as long as I could, I held onto the concept that, at worst, it could be a poorly executed great concept; it kept sliding further and further away from that great concept ideal, to be expected of something coming from such a high plateu with too much expectation; a fault of my own if anything.What was dreadful about this game, however, was not its inability to match the former game's great expectations: it was unbelievably poor direction the plot lurches towards the mid-to-end of the game. In almost complete contrast to Lords of Shadow, which started off slow, picked up speed and took off into orbit: this game started off in orbit, slowed down and instead of just falling to the ground, somehow fell into a wormhole that took it straight into the jaws of a black hole where it went full-on Event Horizon.Give this game a massive miss; play the first and imagine what could have been, don't make the mistake that I did and assume the reviews were just a repeat of the first on release, of fans of Castlevania of old and this game just didn't live up to their rose-tinted rememberance of easiers times, and those who refused to do anything but accuse it of being a God of War clone, when it was so much more.In short, this game represents a tragedy in what could have been, of which I am saddened to have been a part of.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Having been pleasantly surprised by just how good the orginal lords of shadows was, it's fair to say that my expectations for its  sequel were fairly high and nearly four years  later, we have lords of shadow 2 and with it, two questions which roughly translate to: "Is this game a worthy sequel to the orginal" and "should I buy it? In answer to the first question, my answer would be, for the most part, yes it is. The reason why I say for the most part is because while I think that los2 is a genuinely good game, I feel that it falls just short of matching the greatness of the orginal. The main reason why I think this is, is because los2 is a game of two halves. On the one half you have the exploration of draculas castle, which to say the least is huge and the medieval gothic  architecture as well as the unique characters and enemies that inhabit the prince of darkness's home. For me, this is where the game truly shines as it is this part of the game that seems to embody both the aesthetics and quality of the first game. The other half of this game involves navigating through a modern day setting, which I'm afraid to say is where this game falters. The main reason for this is because while the modern envioments are competently enough designed from a gameplay perspective, they lack any kind of personality and uniqueness of their own to make them memorable or even particularly interesting enough to warrent further exploration beyond the main game. Indeed, aside from the boss battles that take place in these locations and the stealth sections (The latter of which I actually quite enjoyed, contrary to popular opinion!) I found most of my time spent in the modern setting to be fairly forgettable,  especially when compared to the parts that take place in Draculas castle, and ultimately hold the game back from being truly on par with the first game. In answer to the second question as to whether the game is worth buying, my answer would be that if you enjoyed the original los then I defiantly believe that this game is worth buying. If you've never played the original but like God Of War style hack and slah games then I would also recomend this title as being a worthy purchase. In short, I would say that if you liked the original los then the odds are that you'll probably like this game as well. In conclusion, If I had to give the first game a score out of ten, then I would probably give it an 8. With this game, I feel that a 7 would be more appropriate.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Castlevania: Lord of Shadows 2 is a sequel to the well recieved but amoung some circles oft trashed "Lord of Shadows." Which blended God of War/Devil May Cry style gameplay with the original Castlevania actiony dark fantasy romp through monster land. I won't give away the ending to that game as some jerks do in even mentioning this game, but you probably already know. If you have not played Lord of Shadows, playing it first is an absolute necessity, and it's also a superior game to this one in my opinion. That said, in my opinion, contrary to the many reviews that are probably due to people not getting paid enough to give the usual IGN "9.5/10 it's ok" kind of review, I found this game a great experience, for many many reasons, since I always like to leave the reader with a positive taste in their mouth if I reccomend this game, (which I do), Then I'll start with the things this game gets wrong once I briefly summarize what it's about.Lord of Shadows 2 has you playing as a newly awakened Dracula after a brief and extremely handholdy tutorial (which will be especially tedious if you played the tutorial), Where he defends his castle from the Forces of The Brotherhood of light. These events take place after Lord of Shadows, and Mirror of Fate (which still needs a port, get on it Konami) And you can read the rest of this in the game summary above on the steam page. The gameplay is a blend of the 3D actiony combat and beat em up that Devil May Cry and God of War pioneered and refined also seen in Lord of Shadows, it is similar enough to that game that it doesnt feel brand brand new, but still new enough to not feel rehashy. It also features platforming and Uncharted and God of War brand climbing sections. And some stealth sections. You explore Dracula's castle, both in the quasi-otherdimensional quasi-memory quasi-past, and the modern day city Castlevania which was built over the ruins of Dracula's castle and it's quite cool how they overlap.Now, lets get to the negative bits. The stealth in this game is awful and unnessecary, There was a way this could've been done, which would involve Dracula stalking his prey and feeding, but the mighty Prince of Darkness running away from rejects in red from Legacy of Kain: Blood Omen 2 on steroids as rats was just ugh. But this can be forgiven as it is mostly just puzzles. The worst one is a particularly aggravating section of stealth against a giant monster satyr that you fight immediately afterward, and is a *COMPLETE* Pushover. It's ridiculous how easy it is to beat this guy after you were cowering in fear in the most difficult stealth section of the game. Another thing that bothered me is how utterly uninspired and generic the soundtrack is. It's beautifully written and scored but it's utterly forgettable and generic. there is maybe one, possibly two pieces on the whole soundtrack I remember at all, and they were variations on something from the previous game. This is forgivable for most games, But not Castlevania a series which has always had an extremely memorable soundtrack.Another odd thing is how arbitrary the things you can climb on and things you cant seem to be, giving a linearity that's even more irritating, but It's a standard of the genre so it is not so bothersome. I dislike how few platforming sections there are, honest platforming and it lacks puzzles compared to the first one.And one last flaw I noticed, was how much I hate enemies that require a certain power to defeat, though thankfully those enemies are either rare or this can be gotten around by clever gameplay. In addition, nto enough moves interrupt enemies for long enough making it too easy to be overwhelmed in situations you shouldn't be, and there simply isnt a large enough variety of enemies compared to the first game.Now onto the positives. The Art Direction of this game and it's implementation is breathtakig, it's simply magnificent. And is definately the strongest points  of it. The animation is fantastic, the atmosphere is gorgeous and captures castlevania to a T, while reminding me of Devil May Cry, and Vampire: The Masquerade, this all creates a neo-gothic feel that perfectly suits this game. The Combat is very good, and very polished. A skilled player can defeat most enemies completely untouched while keeping an very strong level of  challenge. the only drawback of the combat is the lack of stunlocks hits on groups of enemies causes far too much interruption, but this can be argued adds to the challenge, and I am a bit inclined to agree. The game feel is a bit light, but otherwise the sound of the fighting. I particularly like how it is a better Devil May Cry than the latest DMC game, and still retains all of the castlevania feel. The Characters are all excellent, and the story is beautifully told, and has much pathos even if it's a touch predictable. All in all, it fits together in a really excellent way and creates an atmospheric, fun, rich experience, if a touch too short. It starts with a whimper and ends with a bang. Many great boss fights and difficult enemies, and no shortage of action.To sum up, Castlevania Lord of Shadows 2 deserves is an excellently designed and executed game with a haunting and engaging story, a rich atmosphere, a fairly deep and well done combat system and plenty of gameplay and is well worth the money. Visuals 9/10- Excellent art design and execution, well done animations, Rich, beautiful enviroments and atmosphere.Sound 7/10- forgettable if well done soundtrack holds back what otherwise is an excellently voiced experience with quality foley .Gameplay 7/10- Lack of enemy variety, with some flaws to an excellent combat system as well as lack of platforming, combined with not enough puzzles for my liking hold back slightly what is an extremely fun experience, the tedious stealth sections at times could've been an improvement were they better executed and designed but otherwise it is another black mark lowering it's scoreStory 9/10- Excellently written, solid concept and unique spin on the castlevania formula, it is at times quite predictable, but it is so well executed it makes up for it, it is truly heart-warming, wrenching and breaking at times. With truly unforgettable moments, there is better stories out there, but not all that manyOverall= Solid 8/10

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												When I first saw the reviews come out for this game I was a little worried, though I did really enjoy the first Lords of Shadow a few years back. Bought the game anyway and surprise, it's the reviewers being crap at games and reviewing again. LoS2 is, like LoS1, a game that takes the best parts of various action games like God of War and it works out great as a result. Dracula is a great choice for a protagonist and is made a much better character than his main Castlevania counterpart in both abilities and personality. The story isn't too weak either, it's there, it does the job so you can't complain either.A lot of complains were aimed towards the stealth sections in the game, sure this seems like an odd decision but it works, and despite what reviewers say, it's not as inhumanly hard or excessive as they say. There's probably 5 stealth sections overall, they're all incredibly brief and are there to act as a bit of variety to prevent fatigue from constant fighting smaller enemies. Although it is easy to see why reviewers proclaimed the stealth section involving Agreus as the scourge of gaming, it requires you to use multiple skills you have gained so far, but the game doesn't tell you. Thinking is too hard for reviewers after all.Overall, Lords of Shadow 2 is a solid game and definitely deserved a better reception than what it got.

												     Over all I found this to be a spectacular game and would absolutly reccomend it to any player who enjoys their games with good story and characters. As said the story is fairly interesting. You play as Dracula on a mission to destroy Satan in order to stop a demonic invasion and finally be able to rest in peace. The voice acting was absoluely fantastic and the characters were completly believable and not at all flat. There was nothing weak with the characters.The Graphics and animation are also superb and the player is presented with stunning visuals all around, especially with the scenery which presents a gorgeous display of gothic architecture and other surroundings which will leave the player feeling fully immersed. Combat was intersting in that you could not simply just plow through a horde, but actually have to take the time to defeat them. I was playing on easy and defeating casual enemies was even then not just a simple task. Every enemy took time to kill. Quite a few boss battles took place and every boss was also an interesting character, who took time to defeat. Though I didn't find too much of a strategy nessessary, they still took time to defeat and it was enjoyable. The game is quite long and I feel that there were some parts the developers should have left out and even some parts I found completly unnessessary. For instance, there is at least two occasions where you are practiacally playing hide and seek, which I didn't feel was really nessessary or even enjoyable. Aside from this I feel it is a very well developed game. While I do not feel is is a classic, it was undeniably an enjoyable expirence that I can highly reccomend to anyone looking for strong characters, good story, and outstanding visuals.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
Vampires, vampiresFirst of all, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is a vampire game, vampires are the main protagonists of the story, and not just some vampires, in this game you play as Dracula (THE Dracula), you basically play as the main boss in the game where hardly anything can harm you (except the guards, those things can obliterate you at any time).Generally this game gives you the taste of what it means to be Dracula. Transforming into pack rats, turning into mist, commanding bats, travelling between two eras in the world (visiting the Dracula's castle is probably best part of this game), and drinking blood, loads and loads of blood (which you will need to use all the devices in the castle).Stealth sectionsMany people hated these parts, especially considering that as an unstoppable vampire you have to hide before the aforementioned guards and you also have to take a cover in the front of some bosses despite the fact that you will normally fight them, later. I personally liked the stealth sections as they give a little variety to the gameplay. Plus being able to transform into rats, throwing swarm of bats or even possessing bodies of unsuspecting guards is the most cool thing you have ever experienced.The trainThis is one part of the game where I am going to give you one spoiler. The reason is simple, I needed help there, as well. There is one level where you stand on the train and you have to avoid various obstacles in the tunnel. After spending over 20 minutes in this level I decided to check the discussion and figure out what I am actually meant to do. So, after a couple of minutes of avoiding getting smashed to the face there is a short section without any need to jump side to top to avoid hits to the head. When that happens, simple jump to the side of the train and crawl into the window that is there (the same window you could have seen during the cutscene with the guard and the demon).Graphical overkillThe graphics of this game are simply epic. The Dracul's castle is probably one of the most stunning things you will ever see in your life, the whole experience of exploration is just breathtaking. If you don't believe me, just notice that this is my first review ever and I have decided to use it for this game.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Lords of Shadow 2 fills in the story around the time of (mostly after) the first Lords of Shadow game. LoS2 takes place in a combination of the modern world built on Dracula's castle and the past. While playing LoS2, I never really felt a sense of progression, I just felt like I was playing. It's not a particularly difficult game but it does have some stealth scenarios that can be annoying. The boss fights aren't particularly intuitive, just hack and slash and avoid getting hit. The modern environments weren't really my cup of tea but I thought it was fun that they used Dracula's castle as the foundation of an entire city. The past environments were nice and the graphics were done fairly well.I had no performance issues with the game (played with an i7-950 & GTX 780) and no technical issues; it worked very well for me. I played with a gamepad, as any sane person should do with such a game.Took me just over 16 hours to complete. I didn't collect all of the items and upgrades, but probably most of them. Reading the lore is probably the best part of the game.Can't really say I highly recommend this game unless you're a Castlevania fan. Don't hate it, but probably won't replay it.

												At first, I was a bit miffed by the fact that this game becomes anachronistic (Brotherhood version of Liberty Prime], Gabriel in the future), but the story ties it together nicely and it fits together with the in-game lore. The game itself is played out across two worlds (the "mission" world and Gabriel's Castle). Both worlds are free-roam and you can backtrack as needed to explore or to get items previously missed.Pros:- Option in menu to turn off QTEs. This made the first game really annoying with the constant QTE prompts; now it's optional.- Great story.- Fantastic soundtrack.- Combat is more streamlined with upgrades. The mastery system forces you to change up your attacks so you get to use all the combat moves.Cons:- Lack of puzzles (I enjoyed the puzzles from the first game).- Lots of backtracking (re-exploring and getting items from areas already explored).- Modern setting sometimes feels un-Castlevania like.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												Take this thumbs up with a grain of salr; this game isn't for everyone.  But I can easily say that this is my favorite 3D Castlevania game, and the best I've seen out of the series since Dawn of Sorrow.  It has the emotional poignance of Bloodlines/Circle of the Moon, the dizzying grandness of Symphony of the Night, tightened up combar from the first game, and unlike LoS1, Castlevania-appropriate (not to mention gorgeous) art and music...when you're in dracula's castle.  When you step outside you get to hear Patrick Stewart do cold reads of Johnny Test screenplays before you play a mission exhumed kicking and screaming from the bottom of Arkham City's cutting room floor.  I actually started to resent Alucard (?) in this game bc whenever he (? the wolf) showed up, it meant you were done in the Castle for a while.  If LoS was in the middle of the road between pleasing Castlevania fans and presenting new material, this is squarely in the ditch - sweet fanservice and incongruous and confusing new material are presented almost side-by-side.  If you still want to play it knowing that, then you'll love it, but you have to have a super high tolerance for weird and frustrating design choices (as high as a Sonic fan's).  It ain't easy bein' dracula.

												Overall a good game, as many have said the first Lords of Shadow seemed a bit better and well planned.  This was fun by all means but the story felt lacking.  I didn't find myself driven to seek out secrets as they were more tedious to go back and find than enjoyable as i felt the first game was.  Fighting is very fun, combos and new skills make it feel solid and tactical.  There was some parts that annoyed me greatly to keep no spoilers ill make this vague....you are tasked with sneaking around in a few spots if you fail you are one shot killed.....only to then (seconds later) fight the same enemy and dominate them....I know its a game but this forced  game play mechanic annoyed me greatly.  Also the city/castle are hard to navigate, I remembered seeing places I could come back to later on to get upgrades but getting to these locations a second time seemed much more difficult then needed and I found myself just pushing forward instead.  Finally the story does tie everything up but the ending battle and conclusion felt...."eh" to me.  All the other fights felt great, similar to the original game they had a nice massive scale to them with a nice evily twist given your charcater.  I picked this game up on sale after seeing iffy reviews about it at launch I held off for a few months and im glad i did.  This game to me is worth playing, its not bad by any means its just lacking in some areas but I would not have been happy if i dropped full price on it.  Bottom line, worth playing but dont expect to be blown away by it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Lords of Shadow 2 is ostensibly the last game in the Lords of Shadow trilogy created by MercurySteam, and possibly the final game in the Castlevania series, due to Konami moving on to more "profitable" ventures. On paper, this game has all the ingredients needed to send the series out with a bang; amazing graphics, expanded combat and upgrade system, larger and more explorable world, great score, and stellar voice cast. However, when taken together, it doesn't quite reach the heights of the first Lords of Shadow game. One of the biggest problems is the story, which is all over the place as the player jumps between the past and present, represented by the enormous castle where Dracula resides, and the modern-day, gothic city. While MercurySteam's attention to detail and graphical prowess shine in both sections of the game, the city just wasn't as compelling as the castle, and every time I had to go back to the city to complete an objective, I sighed. This point extends to the gameplay in the city as well, which boasts uninspired and frustrating enemies, and stealth sections. In truth, the enemies in the city weren't actually that bad; I just felt that the castle's enemies were much better designed, and fit the "Castlevania" theme. Despite these issues, the core gameplay and combat is solid, and for the most part, better than the first game. The player is also free to roam around both areas looking for upgrades and collectibles; gone is the chapter-by-chapter format. Even with the story jumping around, it is fairly interesting, and the cast does a good job of keeping the player involved. However, the biggest problem emerged during the last third of the game, where it seemed like interesting characters and plot developments were either dropped or rushed to conclusion, culminating in a disappointing final sequence and boss that paled in comparison to the epic scale and confrontations of the first game. Stretching out some story moments or expanding on all the concepts that the narrative introduced would have made the story feel much more put together and complete. And ultimately, it is this feeling of "what could have been" that drags this game down to being simply good, and not great. There are some cool moments, and I did enjoy the experience enough to recommend this game, but it could have been so much more. And that's just a shame.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is a good game.  In fact, I'd call it very good if it weren't for a few glaring flaws.  Critically, this game floundered since the media focused on what the game did wrong rather than what it did right.  This game has many extremely memorable moments.  The battle with medusa and the battle with the toy maker immediately come to mind.  However, for a short amount of time,  the game throws some bad stealth mechanics at you.  There isn't much to say about them, the stealth is barebones and feels very out of place in the story, outside of a single instance where it seemed logical.  Luckily, their presence is more like a puzzle in the game than an actual mechanic.  You won't spend much time stealthing around.Now, on to what this game got right:Combat is A+.  It's up there with the best action games imo: God of War, Devil May Cry, etc.  It's more comparable to DmC: Devil May Cry all the way down to the weapon swapping mechanic.  It feels smooth, responsive, and impactful.  The graphics are fantastic.  The art team did a wonderful job in this game and the engine devs did a great job focusing on the most important aspects of the engine for this game.  The modern city looks great and manages to feel victorian while also looking modern, and Dracula's castle is absolutely gorgeous.  The game also runs like a dream (originally played on a gtx 780 with plenty of power to spare).The story is...well it's nothing to brag about.  The premise is interesting, and the beginning isn't too bad, but some cringy dialogue and a painfullly bad ending ruin it.In the end, I recommend this game.  The good outweighs the bad by a long shot.  Critically speaking, it's a heavily underrated game.  It's hard to accurately express what makes the good parts feel so much better than the bad.If you are interested in this game, download the demo.  It's a good representation of what you'll do in this game 80%-90% of the time (minus the exploration).

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Someone just needs to give Gabriel a hug.This game is one of the most prominent in recent memory to completely break my heart. So much potential in setting, story telling and gameplay squandered. The finale of Lords of Shadow suggested the coming of a great tragic villain. All of the trailers leading up to LoS2 reinforced the drama, the pain, the rage of a man turned into a monster by love.  It was all there for Mercury Steam to knock out of the park. Instead the swung and missed. The sad part is, there is actually some incredible gameplay here. The combat is markedly improved over its predecessor. The addition of vampiric speed and strength to Dracula's style really empowers you. Sure you have probably read about the stealth sections that drag the game's momentum to a squealing halt, and this is true, although perhaps not as miserable as others have suggested. The free exploration of Dracula's castle really improves upon the linear formula of the previous game. So yes, there is much to like here.But oh god what did they do with the the boss fights (a highlight of LoS) and, more unforgiveably, the story. I wont spoil anything here but suffice it to say that the finale not only drops the ball on the conclusion to Gabriel's arc, but does it in spectacularly cringe worth fashion. The less said about the final stage and the ending the better.This game seriously broke my cold black heart.

												After hearing about the negative reviews that this game received from the game critics, I was a bit leery of firing it up. If you enjoyed the first Lords of Shadow game, I think you'll appreciate the improvements that this game offers.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												To be perfectly honest, if you want more Lords of Shadow, you're better off replaying the first game.I feel this one really missed the mark, and after reading about the internal struggles of the development team and their near-constant battle with their director, I can say I'm not really surprised.Lords of Shadow 2 is, in every way, inferior to its predecessor. Graphically, it fails to impress. Mechanically, it feels sloppy. The combat is frustrating and choppy and, while LoS1 had its fair share of controller-throwing platforming segments, LoS2 doesn't even justify its own such moments with an equal helping of fun, satisfying ones. I have only put a couple hours into the game so far, and already I'm mad at it. I cannot comment on the overall story yet, but the beginning feels rushed and strange, and I have to feel bad for Patrick Stewart being forced to deliver such a petty script as Zobek. The writing is childish and uninspired, and the semi-animated lore sequence explaining the Belmont lineage is utterly boring.But you know, I could forgive all of that if the game didn't so completely miss its own point. At no time during play did I ever FEEL like Dracula, who is supposed to be an absolute powerhouse, combining strength, speed, and magical abilities to devastate ranks upon ranks of foes. The most basic of enemies can take a monumental beating from any of your weapons, and can even attack straight through your combos to strike you. One minor strike from an enemy, however, will interrupt your combo and send you flying, which makes your stature feel pitiful, even if you aren't taking significant damage from those attacks. These problems are only magnified and exacerbated when, after the tutorial sequence, the story fast-forwards some centuries and resets all of Gabriel's powers, requiring you to slowly unlock them, one by one.Other games have successfully portrayed their protagonists as extremely powerful beings without robbing the game of its core challenge. A great case in point is Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine. Lords of Shadow 2, however, takes the legendary Dracula and nerfs him into the ground, and then poops all over him with bad gameplay mechanics.I'll say it again: if you want more LoS, play the first game again, because you'll enjoy it a whole lot more.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
Vampires, vampiresFirst of all, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is a vampire game, vampires are the main protagonists of the story, and not just some vampires, in this game you play as Dracula (THE Dracula), you basically play as the main boss in the game where hardly anything can harm you (except the guards, those things can obliterate you at any time).Generally this game gives you the taste of what it means to be Dracula. Transforming into pack rats, turning into mist, commanding bats, travelling between two eras in the world (visiting the Dracula's castle is probably best part of this game), and drinking blood, loads and loads of blood (which you will need to use all the devices in the castle).Stealth sectionsMany people hated these parts, especially considering that as an unstoppable vampire you have to hide before the aforementioned guards and you also have to take a cover in the front of some bosses despite the fact that you will normally fight them, later. I personally liked the stealth sections as they give a little variety to the gameplay. Plus being able to transform into rats, throwing swarm of bats or even possessing bodies of unsuspecting guards is the most cool thing you have ever experienced.The trainThis is one part of the game where I am going to give you one spoiler. The reason is simple, I needed help there, as well. There is one level where you stand on the train and you have to avoid various obstacles in the tunnel. After spending over 20 minutes in this level I decided to check the discussion and figure out what I am actually meant to do. So, after a couple of minutes of avoiding getting smashed to the face there is a short section without any need to jump side to top to avoid hits to the head. When that happens, simple jump to the side of the train and crawl into the window that is there (the same window you could have seen during the cutscene with the guard and the demon).Graphical overkillThe graphics of this game are simply epic. The Dracul's castle is probably one of the most stunning things you will ever see in your life, the whole experience of exploration is just breathtaking. If you don't believe me, just notice that this is my first review ever and I have decided to use it for this game.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												This is a great game. The most important thing in my book however, is that it's a great Castlevania game.Graphics are great. And with the included HD pack, i don't know what more could one want. The battles are impressive, with huge, imposing bosses, and well-detailed enemies. The sound department is one of the most important aspects of the game with some great actors in thevoice acting department. Robert Carlyle does a splendid work as Dracula. However the most important aspect of the game, and where it succeeds is where Lords of Shadow 1 failed. Lords of Shadow 1 was a very proper game, graphics, sound and gameplay, but it used the name Castlevania in vain. I hated it for that. This, has Castlevania, running through its black undead veins. Castlevania, is in the atmosphere. In the dark vampirik feel. Good Job Konami. Reminded me something of the Blood Omen Games, and that is a good, good thing. I know now, that Lord Dracula will return in Castlevania, and he may or may not be in a Lords of Shadow game, after this title i have stopped thinking that this will be a bad thing. Definately recommend, to old fans and new.

content:
Posted: January 16
												I've been playing Castlevania since the first NES version, and I must say that I am really impressed with this as the conclusion of Lords of Shadow 1 and Mirror of Fate. The graphics (mostly in the architecture) and music are fanstastic. The stealth parts didn't bother me as much as everyone else. I would say the biggest con in this game is that the enemies are all relatively the same strength and kind of boring. I think it would have been a little more fun to whip my way through barrages of weaker skeletons and zombies with stronger enemies dispersed strategically through each area. As it is now, pretty much every enemy takes quite a few whips and combos to defeat -- none of them are particularly challenging, but rather time consuming.Ultimately, I did enjoy this game and would definitely recommend this and the other 'newer' series to any Castlevania fan.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 14
												There are times where I both loved and hated Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2.  I really like the first Lords of Shadow, with the Gothic setting, the fresh character design, the story, and the many diverse/fun situations.  Lords of Shadow 2 is at its best when it puts the player in dynamic combat where you are Dracula, the Prince of Darkness, laying waste to whoever dares to stand against you.  However, the stealth sections felt both tedious and illogical  (why would the strongest vampire on the planet be afraid of some trash mobs, with big guns sure, and pushed to hide?  I mean Satan and Death itself are afraid of him...  I don't get it).  Pros:+ Great artistic direction.+ Dynamic combat.+ Great boss battles.+ You play as mothereffing DRACULA, the DRAGON!!+ I enjoyed both the Gothic & Sciebce Fiction settings. + Great voice acting.Cons:- Stealth sections.- The overall world map is tedious to navigate.- Could have benefited of more combo variety and powers (remember the animation HELLSING, that's a bad♥♥♥♥♥vampire).Verdict: B+

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												I recommend 100% the game, especially for those who have finished the first Lords of Shadow. The story of the first is better, but Lords of Shadow 2 has a great story too! Besides, it is much better to play as Dracula than as Gabriel. Not to mention that the end of Lords of Shadow 2 gives a wonderful satisfaction, superior to completing the first game.People criticized the stealth parts very much. I think because it breaks the Hack'n Slash rhythm of the game to a situation where you have to use the brain. And, let's face it, it's not as difficult to overcome these parts as the people are complaining about. I personally enjoyed even the stealth parties. I liked Kleidos, and I liked the open world with a relic to help you find the secrets that you can leave behind unintentionally, and I enjoyed playing with Alucard.Worth every penny. I would love to play as Drakul again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 2
												So as my third Castlevania game ever I found this game to be interesting. Obviously my first 2 are the other Lords of Shadow games on steam. Lords of Shadow 1 and Mirror of Fate. I have to start out saying this game at max settings with the texture pack on is beutiful. Atleast the environments are, the character models are about the same as in the first lords of shadow game. But the Marble floors and walls look amazing same with the castle. The gameplay is 99% the same as the first lords of shadow lots of X and Y if you are using a controller, it has full controller support so I dont see why you wouldnt be. There is 1 change which I found annoying. They switched the function of the right trigger and B button on an Xbox controller from the first game. In the first game right trigger was used to pick stuff up and now its B. This threw me off as it is bascially the only controll change. SPOILERS. I found this game to be more enjoyable than the first but I liked the story in the first one more. This story is confusing. So in the first one you were sent on a mighty quest to kill the three lords of Shadows, Werewolf, Vampire, and Grim Reaper man. This one you are gearing up to fight Satan in a modernish city. There are basically no puzzles in this one which were prevelent in the first one. They have been replaced instead with weird stealth sections. Which absolutly make no sense as you are Dracula who is going to destroy Satan but dies in 2 seconds these large mutant guards with basically rocket launchers in futuristic armor. Very annoying. There is also a sub plot with the castle which was destroyed at the start of the game. Then it sort of becomes its own dimension were stupid BS things happen. Like the blood of the castle is trying to keep him there and basically Mutates anything it touches. Also Zobek is a business man now. I am notgoing thru the entire story but its basically you awake its the future you are in modern city, there are people trying to sommin Satan, you beat them and other bosses , then fight Satan and an old god. With weird BS stuff happening in your Castle dimensional realm. I think the castle became the new Shadow plane maybe? Idk it isnt really explained. 8/10 is what I give it.

												Highly recommended.Good game. It's very different from the old Castlevania game I played many years ago on my Gameboy. This game has well-written story, and well-made combat system. The difficulty levels are well-designed as well. Both beginner and hardcore player can find their good match. Also, I like Dracula a lot. He is super handsome and powerful <3. Have anyone watched "Hellsing OVA"? He is so much like Alucard lol.

Posted: April 22
												Game feels pretty boring for most of the part.The prologue and tutorial area already takes up like 2~3 hours of the game.Lords of shadows 1 is far better even though it was mission based (which actually wasn't bad at all).There are many other hack and slash adventure games on steam that are better.
